full_translation:
**Exegetical Commentary on the *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void***

**Title:** *Exegetical Commentary on the Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*
Authored by Duan Jingshun of the Tang, with supplements by Chen Jingyuan of the Song. Two scrolls.
Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Unity*, Cavernous Spirit Division, Jade Instructions Category.

---

**Preface to the *Exegetical Commentary on the Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void***

Before the birth of Zhuangzi, the Way of Liezi had already flowed boundless and formless, suffusing the Great Void without trace or sound. Thus, his writings elucidated the profound obscurities of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, dissecting the roots of life and death, stripping away concealments and unraveling entanglements, lancing boils and draining abscesses. His words spoke of spontaneity without self-awareness, of non-action while allowing all things to follow their course. His phrasing ranged freely, like withered leaves and dry husks, riding the wind east and west, drifting and admonishing between heaven and earth without limit.

Later, Zhuangzi frequently cited his words in discourses, and thus the world came to speak of "Lao-Zhuang" rather than "Lao-Lie." This is because Zhuangzi harmonized differences into unity, his meaning threading through all, distinguishing hardness and whiteness while embracing both being and non-being.

In the past, Liezi dwelled in seclusion in Putian for forty years, yet none recognized him; he concealed his form among the common folk, and even the lord of the state knew him not—such was his heavenly obscurity. A man may possess the Way yet receive no praise; how could the Way be trivial? A book may contain principle yet seldom be acknowledged; how could it be coarse? This man, this book—profound and distant, returning with things to their source—how lofty it is!

From my youth, I delighted in reading this work, yet suffered from the lack of phonetic glosses and explanations to resolve my confusions. In later years, while wandering beneath the watery canopy of Siming at Tongbai on Mount Tiantai, I obtained two tattered scrolls, their titles faintly marked as *Exegetical Commentary on Liezi*. The paper and ink were decayed, unfit for leisurely perusal, so I hastily transcribed them. Much was lost to moths and decay, obliterated and fragmented, with four or five parts in ten missing. Yet at the end of the scroll was inscribed: *"Compiled by Yin Jingshun, Vice Magistrate of Dangtu County, Tang; transcribed by Mo Xizi of Mount Heng."* I roughly copied and stored it in my satchel.

Later, on Mount Qian, I found a handwritten copy of *Liezi* by the Tang Daoist Xu Lingfu, along with Lu Chongxuan’s commentary preserved in a private collection. Comparing these with the printed edition from the Directorate of Education during the Jingde era, I collated discrepancies, noting variants and assembling a record of errors and divergences in one scroll, appended to the commentary. Subsequently, I filled lacunae and restored omissions, recovering the original order.

Among the finest explanations by earlier scholars was the identification of *cheng* (程) as a variant name for *biao* (豹), which in ancient script comprises the two characters *tai* (泰) and *bing* (丙). Such erudition and breadth of knowledge! Any oversights or omissions await the emendations and insights of like-minded scholars.

Written on the ninth day of the ninth month, second year of the Xining era, by Bixuzi.

---

**Exegetical Commentary on the *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*, Scroll One***
Compiled by Yin Jingshun, Vice Magistrate of Dangtu County, Tang
Supplemented by Chen Jingyuan, Bixuzi

**New Catalogue of *Liezi***

Surname: Lie. Given name: Yukou, or alternatively Yukou.
Preceding Zhuangzi, hence Zhuangzi’s references to him.
At the beginning of the Tianbao era, by imperial decree, he was enfeoffed as the Perfected of the Unfathomable Void, and his work was retitled *Classic of the Unfathomable Void*, its name heading the eight chapters.
This edition was compiled by Liu Xiang, who selected twenty chapters, removed redundancies, and titled it *New Book*.
In the fourth year of the Jingde era of the Great Song, the title was augmented with "Perfect Virtue," becoming *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*.
The collator, Liu Xiang, styled Zizheng, was a descendant of Liu Jiao, Prince Yuan of Chu during the Han.
Thus was this book collated and annotated. May the teachings of its sounds and meanings be revered!

Within the text, the character "与" frequently appears in this form.

臣参 (chén cān): pronounced as "seven" in the southern pronunciation.

Liu Xiang’s *Catalogue of the New Book of Guanzi* states: "The *Book of Minister Can* comprises forty-one chapters."

校雠 (jiào chóu): pronounced as "chou."
校 refers to comparing two texts, verifying through collation.
雠 means "like an enemy," signifying reciprocal verification.

除复 (chú fù): pronounced as "fu" in the "you" rhyme.
以尽 (yǐ jìn): pronounced as "jin" in the "zhi" rhyme, meaning "to exhaust"; the same applies below.

In the *New Book*, there is 栈 (zhàn), pronounced as "jian."
This refers to damage or destruction by bookworms.
Abbreviated as 刬 or written as 前, both equivalent to 剪 (jiǎn).

The *Rites of Zhou* includes the office of 剪氏, responsible for eliminating insects, fish, and bookworms.

杀青 (shā qīng) refers to scraping away the green skin of bamboo slips after drying.

郑缪公 (Zhèng Mù Gōng): pronounced as "Mu."
Contemporary with Duke Ai of Lu.

迂 (yū): pronounced as "yu."
诞 (dàn): pronounced as "tan" in the "han" rhyme.
迂诞 (yū dàn) denotes grandiose, exaggerated speech.

恢 (huī): pronounced as "hui" in the "hui" rhyme.
诡 (guǐ): pronounced as "wei" in the "wei" rhyme.
恢诡 (huī guǐ) refers to wildly strange or fantastical language.

推分 (tuī fèn): pronounced as "fen" in the "wen" rhyme.
乘背 (chéng bèi): pronounced as "pei."

孝景 (Xiào Jǐng), Emperor of Han, avoided the personal name "启" (Qǐ).

亦颇 (yì pō): pronounced as "po" in the "ke" rhyme.
偶言 (ǒu yán): pronounced as "yu."

Liu Xiang’s *Bie Lu* states: "偶言 (*ǒu yán*) refers to composing names of persons and making them converse with one another." The *Records of the Grand Historian* reads it as 寓 (*yù*). "列传 (*liè zhuàn*)" and "列传" are categories of the classics, both pronounced in the departing tone.

昧死 (*mèi sǐ*): pronounced as "shang" in the "zhang" rhyme.
永始 (*Yǒng Shǐ*): reign title of Emperor Cheng of Han.
湛 (*Zhāng Zhàn*), styled Chudu, was a *Guanglu Xun* of the Eastern Jin. He annotated this *True Classic*.
刘正舆 (*Liú Zhèngyú*), pronounced as "Yu," was a Jin Governor of Yangzhou, named Tao.
傅颖根 (*Fù Yǐnggēn*), named Fu, was a native of Beidi and served as *Congshi Zhonglang* to the Jin Chancellor.
并少 (*bìng shào*): pronounced as "zhao" in the "xiao" rhyme.
始 (*Shǐ*): the Zhou royal surname was Wang; Zhang Zhan’s grandfather was his maternal uncle.
从兄 (*cóng xiōng*): "从" is pronounced as "yong" in the "yong" rhyme.
正宗 (*Zhèngzōng*): Wang Hong, styled Zhengzong, was a native of Gaoping and served as a Jin *Shangshu*.
辅嗣 (*Fǔsì*): Wang Bi, styled Fusi, was a native of Shanyang and served as a *Shangshu Lang* of Wei.
皆好 (*jiē hào*): pronounced as "bao" in the "bao" rhyme.
先 (*xiān*): pronounced as "xian" in the "jian" rhyme; same below.
并卑 (*bìng bēi*): pronounced as "zheng" in the "zheng" rhyme.
仲宣 (*Zhòngxuān*): Wang Can, styled Zhongxuan, was a native of Shanyang and served as *Shizhong* of Wei.
几将 (*jī jiāng*): pronounced as "qi"; means "nearly."
总角 (*zǒng jiǎo*): The *Book of Songs* says, "总角胸兮." It refers to the time when a child’s hair is tied up.
及长 (*jí zhǎng*): "长" is pronounced as "zhang" in the "zhang" rhyme.
避难 (*bì nàn*): "难" is pronounced as "tan" in the "tan" rhyme.
各称 (*gè chēng*): "称" is pronounced as "zheng" in the "zheng" rhyme.
寇虏 (*kòu lǔ*): pronounced as "lu"; "尽" is pronounced as "jin" in the "ren" rhyme.
料简 (*liào jiǎn*): pronounced as "liao"; means "to arrange" or "to measure."
唯赍 (*wéi jī*): pronounced as "ji."
祖玄 (*Zǔ Xuán*): Fu Xuan, styled Xiuyi, was a native of Beidi. He composed *Zi Shu* in 120 pian and had a collected works of 50 juan.
咸 (*Xián*), styled Changwei, had a collected works of 20 juan. Father and son both served as Jin *Sili Xiaowei* and were enfeoffed as *Chungu Hou*.
仅有 (*jǐn yǒu*): pronounced as "jin"; means "few."

"Bǐ luàn" is pronounced as "bì lì." "Fù zài" is pronounced as "fú yòu." "Zhuó wù" is pronounced as "zhí lüè." "Zì sàng" is pronounced as "xī làng." "Shēng jué" is pronounced as "jiào." "Sì rèn" is pronounced as "ér zhèn."

Such examples are somewhat numerous, and one must again infer their meaning contextually. These often intermingle with Buddhist scriptures, just as it is said that Buddhist scriptures frequently intermingle with the *Liezi*. This is how writers compose their words, with phrases and expressions mutually presented.

"Shǔ cí" is pronounced as "zhú." *Zhuangzi*, named Zhou, styled Zixiu, was a native of Song. He served as the magistrate of Liang’s Qiyuan. He authored a work in fifty-two pian, which Guo Xiang later compiled into thirty-three pian and annotated. In the early Tianbao era, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the Perfected of Nanhua, and his work was titled the *True Scripture of Nanhua*. Within this scripture, there are often passages attributed to the Perfected of Chongxu.

Shen Dao was a native of Zhao. He preceded Shen Buhai and Han Fei, who both esteemed him. He authored a work in forty-two pian, and his learning was rooted in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi.

Han Fei was a prince of Han. He was sent to Qin, where Li Si plotted against and killed him. He authored a work in fifty-five pian, and his learning was also rooted in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor.

Shizi, named Jiao (pronounced *jiǎo*), was a native of Lu. He was the teacher of Shang Yang, the Chancellor of Qin. After Yang’s death, he fled to Shu and authored a work in twenty pian.

The *Huainanzi*, Liu An, was the grandson of Emperor Wu of Han and the eldest son of Liu Chang, the Prince Li of Huainan. He gathered retainers and composed the *Inner Book* in twenty-one pian, which contains many passages from the *True Scripture*. He also wrote the *Outer Book* in thirty-three pian, discussing the *New Discourses* and the *Xuan Shi*. Among Daoist works, there is the *Scripture of Xuan Shi in the Womb* in forty juan by Wang Gui of Chenliu. Additionally, Han Zhi of Chenliu authored the *Xuan Shi* in eight pian, offering an expanded exegesis of the *Five Thousand Character Text*.

The *Zhigui*: Yan Zun of Han, styled Junping, authored the *Zhigui* in fourteen pian, providing an expanded exegesis of the *Five Thousand Character Text*.

"Tiān Ruì" is the first chapter. "Fū" is pronounced as "fú."

This marks the beginning of the introductory phrase, and no further pronunciation guides follow. *Chuǎncuò* is pronounced as "chāngyǎn." *Zhī* is pronounced as "fùwèn"—the same applies below.

In *Liezi* and *Guanzi*, the honorific "zi" (Master) precedes the surname, signifying their status as teachers. The *Zhengpu* is pronounced as "bǔ." It refers to gardens and fields, the marshes and wetlands of Zheng, now located in Zhongmou County of present-day Rongyang.

*Suǒ yè* means "all." *Wú* may also be written as *wáng*, pronounced identically. *Zhī* is an ancient form of the character *shì* (to see). *Xíng* is pronounced as "mèng."

Huqiu Zilin—according to Sima Biao’s commentary, the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence* states: his name was Lin, a native of Zheng. *Yǔ* may also be written as *zhào*, meaning "to instruct" or "to inform." Bohun Maoren is pronounced as "mòhóu"—later instances of Bohun Wuren may also be read as *móu*. *Gào nǚ* means "to tell you." *Kuàirán* is pronounced as "kǒuduì." *Ér fù* is pronounced as "fúyòu," while *wǎngfù* retains its standard pronunciation.

Characters that are not annotated with pronunciation hereafter are all entering-tone words. *Bù dài* is pronounced as "dài."

The *Book of the Yellow Emperor*: The Yellow Emperor, surnamed Gongsun and named Xuanyuan, attained the Dao of longevity and reigned for a hundred years. According to the *Yiwen zhi* in the *Book of Han*, there are four pian of the *Book of the Yellow Emperor*, one pian of *The Yellow Emperor and His Ministers*, and six pian of *Inscriptions of the Yellow Emperor*, all of which resemble Daoist scriptures. *Xuánpìn* is pronounced as "pírěn." *Wú yǐng* is pronounced as "yǐng."

Mianmian is pronounced as *wǔyán*. *Cúnxié* is pronounced as *yǐzhē*. The same below. Xiang Xiu is pronounced as *xiǎng*. His courtesy name was Zǐqī, and he served as a *chángdài* in the Jin dynasty. He annotated the twenty-eight *pian* of the *Nanhua Zhenjing*. He possessed profound understanding of phonology. The same below. *Shànqún* is pronounced as *shíyàn*. *Búkuì* is pronounced as *kuì*. *Héyě*. *Dàyì* is pronounced as *tàiyì*. The same below. *Wèijiànxián* is pronounced as *biàn*. The annotation is the same. *Zhīchēng* is pronounced as *chǐzhèng*. The same below. *Yì* is pronounced as *hùjì*. *Hùnchéng* is pronounced as *húběn*. *Hún* is pronounced as *hún*; *lún* is pronounced as *lún*. The same below. *Xiānglí* is pronounced as *lìzhì*. It means "to depart." Some read it in the level tone. Near separation is called *lí*, while distant separation is called *bié*. Later, one must seek its meaning. *Bié* is pronounced as *bǐliè*. *Lísàn* is pronounced as *xiānhàn*. The same within this *juàn*. *Xúnzhī* is pronounced as *xún*. *Yìwúxíng*: The *Huainanzi* writes it as *xíngliè*. It refers to signs and omens. The *Qiánzáo Dù* writes it as *xíngpàn*. Following *hū* as a turning particle is an error. *Yìbiàn érwéiyī*: From one through nine, the number of the *tài yǎn*. *Hū* is pronounced as *hū*. *Huǎng* is pronounced as *kuàngwǎng*. *Yǐshù sèzhǔ* is pronounced as *sèzhǔ*. *Nǎifù* is an archaic form of *nǎi*. *Shàngwéi* is pronounced as *shízhǎng*. *Suǒyǐ* is pronounced as *yúqǐ*. *Tiāndì suǒpǐ* is pronounced as *púbǐ*. It means "blocked." *Zào* is pronounced as *qīdào*. *Zéhé* is pronounced as *ài*; *suǒshǔ* is pronounced as *zhú*. *Sùfēn* is pronounced as *fúwèn*. The same below for *míngfèn* and *xíngfèn*. *Tāoyù* is pronounced as *dào*. It means "to cover." *Zhēncuì* is pronounced as *suì*; *xìyú* is pronounced as *jì*. It means "to present and be seen." *Néngshān* is pronounced as *shílián*. *Dàolùn* is pronounced as *lúkùn*. *Shìwú* is pronounced as *shì*. *Míngzhī* is pronounced as *mízhèng*. It is the same as *zhào*. *Xiǎng* is pronounced as *xǔliǎng*. *Guāngjǐng* is pronounced as *yǐng*. Sima Biao said: *Tú* means "the side of the Way." One version writes it as *cóng*. *Dúlóu* is pronounced as *dúlóu*. *Qiān* is pronounced as *jiǎn*; *féng* is pronounced as *péng*. It means "mugwort" or "to pull out." *Bá* is pronounced as *pībā*. *Guòyǎng* is pronounced as *gǔwò*. *Shídàng* is pronounced as *dīnglàng*. *Zhǒng* is pronounced as *zhāngyǒng*. *Yǒujī* is pronounced as *jūqǐ*. *Ruòwā* is pronounced as *hùguā*. It refers to a toad. *Wéichún* is pronounced as *chún*. *Shìjiànxián* is pronounced as *biàn*. The *Mozi* states: "Among things, some endure long, while others do not. At the beginning, transformation occurs without duration, as when a toad becomes a quail." *Dé shuǐ wéi* is pronounced as *jì*. Sima Biao said: "Though the myriad things have signs and omens, only when moistened by water does their *qi* continue and give rise to life." *Wāpín* is pronounced as *bùtián*. Sima Biao said: "The roots of things lie at the boundary of water and soil. Spread in water, when viewed from above, they cannot be grasped, like silk floss submerged in water." The people of Chu call it the "garment of the *yíngpín*." *Língtún* is pronounced as *tún*. It means "mound." *Jiéchù* is pronounced as *chāngjù*. The same below. *Língxì* is pronounced as *xī*. It is also called *zéxì*, changing with moisture and dryness. *Yùqī* refers to dung and soil. *Wūzú* is the name of a grass. *Qícáo*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "It dwells within wood." Though now commonly called a scorpion, its habitat differs. *Húdié* is pronounced as *dié*. It is the *jiádié*. *Jiá* is pronounced as *jiá*. *Xū*: The *Shī Shuō* states: "*Xū* means 'little.'" It refers to the brief time of departure. *Shēng zào xià dé shú qì shēng ruò tuō*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "*Tuō* means 'to peel.'" *Qú* is pronounced as *qú*. *Duō* is pronounced as *dīngkuò*.

The *qúduō* is the name of an insect. *Gān yúxū*’s foam is pronounced *mò*. The *Nanhua Zhenjing* writes it as "bone." Li Yi states: "*Mèi* is the juice in the mouth." *Sīmí* is the name of an insect that feeds on vinegar, pronounced *xǐ xī*. *Kǔjiǔ* is the upper *mièměng*. It is also called *xī jī*. The lower is *sì*. *Yí lù*: the upper is *yí*, the lower *lù*. The *huáng kuàng*, pronounced *kuàng*, and *yí kuàng* are all insects. *Jiǔ yóu*: Li states: "*Jiǔ* should be *jiǔ*, meaning 'long-lived.'" *Yóu* is the name of an insect. *Piē mào* has two pronunciations: *móu*. *Yīn*, pronounced *ruì*, is a small insect that delights in flying about in swarms. *Fǔ*, pronounced *fǔ*. The *quán*, pronounced *quán* or *huān*, refers to the yellow beetle in melons. *Dì gāo*, pronounced *gāo*: Gu Yin’s *Hanshu Jijie* states it is like mud. Fu Lin’s *Shuowen* writes it as *lín*, and also as *lìn*, both referring to ghostly fire. The *Huainanzi* states: "Blood becomes *lìn*." Pronounced *lìn*. The *yào*, pronounced *zhuó*, becomes the *zhān*, pronounced *zhān*. The *zhān* becomes the *bù gǔ* tree, also written as *ké*. Lu Ji’s *Maoshi Niaoshou Shu* states: "The crane resembles the *zhān*, with yellow feathers, a chicken’s head, and a gray body, all similar. It flies swiftly and preys on turtledoves, pigeons, swallows, and sparrows." The *bùgǔ* is the *jiájú*, also called *shī jiū*, *jī gǔ*, *chéng jiū*, and the "mid-spring sparrow." The *yào* hawk and *zhān* transform into the *yào*. Pronounced *jū*. The swallow becomes the clam, pronounced *gé*. The *Jia Yu* states: "In winter, swallows and sparrows enter the sea and transform into clams." *Yàn* may also be written as *què*. The *Zhou Shu* states: "Sparrows enter great waters and transform into clams." The field mouse becomes the quail, pronounced *chún*. This transformation is the same as that of the frog. The *Shuowen* states: "The quail is the *yào*." The *Da Dai Li* states: "In the third month, the field mouse transforms into the *ān*." The *Zhou Shu* states: "It transforms into the *jià*." Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "*Jià* is also the *ān*." *Ān*, pronounced *ān*; *jià*, pronounced *rú*. The *xiǔ guā*, pronounced *xiǔ*, is old leeks, pronounced *jǔ yǒu*. They become the *guān*, pronounced *guān*, which resembles bulrush but is round; it is what is now used to make mats. Yang Chengqing’s *Zitong* states it is pronounced *è*. It is also written as *xiàn*, pronounced *hóu biàn*, a scribal error. The old *yú*, pronounced *yú*, is a female sheep, or a black sheep. It becomes the *yuán*, pronounced *yuán*. Fish roe is pronounced *lái duǎn*. *Dǎn yuán*: the upper is *chán*, the lower *yuán*. It resembles the *lí*, pronounced *lì*, but has *máo*, pronounced *máo*, meaning hanging hair. The female is pronounced *pí rěn*; the male, *mǒu*. The *yì*, pronounced *wǔ lì*: The *San Cang* states it is the *cāng yì*. Sima Biao states it is the young of birds. The pupil is pronounced *móu*. *Zhì* is an ancient form of *zhì*. The bee, pronounced *fēng*: Sima Biao states that the young bee with slender legs takes the silkworm, prays over it, and makes it resemble its own offspring. It then becomes pregnant, pronounced *zhèng*.

Here the text unfolds thus:

*hào* is pronounced *hū bào*. Hou Ji is read *zhǎng dīng*. The note says "same as." *Jiù* is water, pronounced *shuǐ jiù*; *Yǒu shēn* is read *shū zhēn*. "Infant" is sometimes written *yīng*, which is incorrect. Tang’s minister is pronounced *xī liàng*. *Jué zhāo*: Master Zengzi says it is *gū lí*, also called *jué zhāo*, which constantly circles its tree and cannot leave it. The *Shī Shuō* states: *gū lí* is the dragonfly. *Qīng líng* is pronounced *qīng líng*. It is born in dampness, pronounced *shī shī*. Through steaming, pronounced *zhēng*. *Xī jī* are *miè hào*. *Yáng xī* is read *bǐ*. *Hū bù* is bamboo shoot, pronounced *sǔn*. For long, bamboo gives birth to *qīng níng*—the *Nán Huá Zhēn Jīng* takes "from *yáng xī* to *qīng níng*" as one phrase. Sima Biao says: *Yáng xī* is a plant whose root resembles *yàn jīng*; when paired with old bamboo, they grow as unlike kinds. *Qīng níng* is the name of an insect.

*Shēng chéng*: The *Shī Zǐ* says: In the Central States it is called *bào*; the people of Yue call it *mò*. According to the *Ěr Yǎ*, the young of bear and tiger is *bào*. *Bào* is the offspring of bear and tiger. The *Shān Hǎi Jīng* says: In the southern mountains there are many *mó bào*. Guo’s note says: *Mò* is the white *bào*. *Bào* is born of tiger, an unlike kind. Thus *chéng* is another name for *mò*. Now *mò* resembles a bear, its fur yellow-black and lustrous—*mó* is pronounced *mò*. "Horse gives birth to man": The *Sōu Shén Jì* says: In the time of Duke Xiao of Qin, a horse gave birth to a man. Liu Xiang took it as a horse omen.

*Shēng xiǎng* is pronounced *xǔ liǎng*. Later the same. *Xiǎng yìng* is pronounced *yū zhèng*. "No longer" is read *fú yòu*. *Zhī chēng* is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. "Together to the end" is read *xié zhōng*; *liào* is pronounced *liáo*. "Advancing to the end" is read *zhōng jìn*. Below the same. *Xū mó* is pronounced *mò*. "Thus alternating" is read *dié*; "not long" is pronounced *bù jiǔ*. "Those not born" are first pronounced *xī jiàn*. Below the same. "And again" is read *fú yòu*. "Mark its" is pronounced *hú cān*—meaning strategy. One version writes "exhaust." This does not extend the meaning.

"That of spirit is Heaven’s *jiǔ*" is pronounced *yǒu*. Below the same. Written in seal script, it resembles the character for "long." According to the *Hàn Shū*, Yang Yùsūn said: "That of spirit is Heaven’s *yǒu*; that of bones and frame is Earth’s *yǒu*." Yùsūn often read this scripture. Now the Guozijian edition writes *fēn*. The root is pronounced *jiǎo*.

"Youth and strength" is read *shòu zhào*. Below the same. "Old and infirm" is pronounced *mào bào*. *Qì* drifts, pronounced *piāo*. *Dé* is flourishing, pronounced *yīn zhèng*. One version writes "thus." "Contend" is pronounced *zhēng*. *Jiàn* is pronounced *gǔ xiàn*—meaning separation. "Great mountain" is pronounced *tài*. *Hū chéng* is pronounced *chéng*—a city of Lu. "With rope" is pronounced *xiān gè*. "For joy" is read *lè*. Below the same. "Its distinction" is pronounced *bǐ liè*. "Fixed share" is read *fú wèn*. "Thus again" is read *fú yòu*. *Qiǎng* is pronounced *jū liǎng*. "Protect" originally was written *chèn bǎo*. The *Bó Wù Zhì* says: It is woven of thread, eight inches wide, twelve inches long, used to bind the infant to the back—*lín lèi* is pronounced *lèi*. Some write *yǐng*, a misrecognition.

"Base" is pronounced *dū lǐ*. "Wearing furs" is read *bèi*. "Forgotten grain" is pronounced *suì*. "Thus the furrow" is read *xī*. "Skirt" is pronounced *jū yùn*; *pú làng* is read *pú làng*. Below the same. It means walking beside the furrow. "That old man" is pronounced *xī kǒu*. "Have you tried going to ask him?" is read *yǒu shì wǎng xùn zhī*. One version omits "have." "His ridge" is pronounced *lǒng*. "Never" is read *céng bù chuò*—*dīng liè* means "to stop." "Knock on it" is pronounced *kòu zhī*. And it responds, pronounced *yū zhèng*. "Youth does not" is read *shào bù shī zhào*. "Diligent practice" is pronounced *qín xíng*; below the same, *xià mèng*. "Age does not" is read *zhǎng bù dīng wén*. Below the same. "What joy" is pronounced *hé lè*. "Can long life" is read *néng shòu*. "Dislike" is pronounced *wù*. "Not better" is read *bù yù*—*yǐ gào* is pronounced *gǔ wò*. The next chapter the same. "Suddenly" is pronounced *cāng mò*. "Reaching the limit" is read *zào jí*. "Leave that" is pronounced *qū bǐ*. "Permitted place" is read *xǔ chǔ*. "In loathing" is pronounced *yū yàn*. "Its grave" is read *qì kuàng*—meaning tomb pit. Xun Qing has this chapter.

*Yì rú* is pronounced *gāo*; *zǎi rú* means "like the prime minister." *Fén rú* means "like a grave mound." *Lì rú* is pronounced *lì*—its shape like a tripod, also pronounced *gé*. "Resting here" is written by Xun Qing as "resting here." "Joy of Heaven" is pronounced *lè*. Below the same.

"Leave that" is pronounced *qū bǐ*. "Separate" is read *lí*. "Dimly" is pronounced *mèi rán*. *Zhī bèi* is read *pú jiè*—meaning fatigue. *Zhī yì* is pronounced *yì*. Yanzi was a great minister of Qi, Yan Ying. "Joy of life" is pronounced *lè*. "Dislike death" is read *wù*. "Prudent conduct" is pronounced *shèn xíng*. "No satiation" is read *wú yàn*. *Zhī jiǎo* is pronounced *jiào*. "Human talent" is read *rén cái*. Below the same. "Lineage of worthies" is pronounced *zhǒng xián shì*. "Born to fame" is read *shēng míng yù*. "Straddle" is pronounced *kuà*. "Know oneself" is read *zhī jǐ*. "That which is left" is pronounced *suǒ qù*—the annotation same as above. "Awakening" is read *wù*. "Leave that" is pronounced *qù bǐ*. "Shatter" is read *pò huǐ*. "Loss and ruin" is pronounced *kuī sàng*. "Congee" is read *zhōu*. Xiong was the teacher of King Wen of Zhou, enfeoffed in Chu, and authored twenty-two chapters in the *Zi Shu*. "Gone already" is pronounced *wú yǐ*. "Grasp" is read *cāo*. "Follow the world" is pronounced *suí shì*. Below the same. "Reflect" is read in the upper tone. "Advance" is pronounced *jìn*. "That which is gazed upon" is read *suǒ zhǔ*—one version writes *瞻 (zhān)*. "From the world" is pronounced *zì shì*. Qi is read *qǐ*. The *Guo Xi Ben* states: "King Tang of Yin enfeoffed the Xia successor in Qi. The Zhou later enfeoffed it again. Today it lies in Yongqiu County of Chenliu, where the *Wude* era once established Qi Prefecture." "Collapse" is read *bēng suì*. "Constellations" are pronounced *xīng xiù*. Below the same. "Triumph" is read *shèng*.

"Injury" is read *dīng zhòng*. "Clod" is pronounced *kuài*. "Filled and blocked" is read *sū zé*. "Tread" is pronounced *chú*. "Step falteringly" is read *bù cǐ*. "Trample" is pronounced *tú dào*. These four words all describe the appearance of treading.

"Human dwelling" is read *rén shè*. Below the same.

Changlu Zi: The *Records of the Historian* states: "There was a Changlu Zi in Chu." The *Book of Han* states: "Changlu Zi authored nine chapters, belonging to the Daoist school."

"Rainbow" is read *hóng nì*. "To the utmost" is pronounced *zhī zuì*. "Great distance" is read *dà yuǎn*. "Together complete" is pronounced *xié quán*. "To see" is read *zhī xiàn*. "Where" is pronounced *chǎng jù*.

Shun asked Yu Cheng (a term for an assisting minister; one version writes *zhēng*). "There is" is read *yǒu fū*. "Heavy pillar" is pronounced *zhòng zhù*. Below the same. "Molt" is read *tuì*. "Return" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Xiang clan" is read *xiàng shì*. "Great earth" is pronounced *rú zhǎng*. One version writes *復 (fù)*. "Extend" is read *yǐ zhì*—meaning "to prolong."

"Without fail" is read *wáng bù*. Below the same. "With organs" is pronounced *yǐ zàng*. "First reside" is read *xiān jū*. "Said 'Alas'" is pronounced *yuē xī*—the sound of grief and sorrow. "I steal the timely benefits of Heaven and Earth" ends the sentence.

"Flow abundantly" is read *zhī pāng*. "Build" is pronounced *zhú*. "My wall" is read *wú yuán*. "Plant" is pronounced *shí zhí*. "Turtle" is read *biē*. "Extend" is pronounced *shī zhì*. "Net" is read *wǎng wén*. "Pass Dongguo" is read *guò dōng guō*—one version writes *遇 (yù)*. "Separate" is pronounced *lí*. "Ren (unit of measure)" is read *rèn ér*. "Weigh" is pronounced *chēng*. "Return" is read *fú yòu*. "For me" is pronounced *wéi wú*. "Store" is read *cáng*. "Great void" is pronounced *dà xū*. "Stingy" is read *lìn*. "Place" is pronounced *suǒ cuò*.

**Yellow Emperor, Second Chapter**
"Nurture the true" is read *yǎng zhèng*. "Scorched" is pronounced *jiāo rán*. "Complexion" is written as *肌色 (jī sè)*—one version writes *颜色 (yán sè)*. "Wrinkled" is read *gǎn*. *Měi* (黣) has no entry in other texts.

"Pīcāng" writes □ as the same character, pronounced *měi*, referring to trees damaged by rain that develop black speckles. *Gǎn* and *měi* are likewise.

"Not govern" is pronounced *zhí lì*. Below, "bring order" is the same. "Advance governance" is pronounced *jìn*. "Eulogy" is read *tàn*. "Excessive indulgence" is pronounced *shēn*. "Abandon the palace" is read *shě*. "Depart" is pronounced *zhí qiū lǚ*. "Bell suspension" is read *xuán*. "Dwell in seclusion" is pronounced *xián*. "Unite the heart" is read *zhāi*—same below. "Yǎnzhōu" is pronounced *yǎn*. "*Jī* (几)" is read *jū qǐ*. "Without leader" is pronounced *shuài suǒ lèi*—one version writes *师 (shī)*. "Elder" is pronounced *dīng wén*. "Teacher and elder" means the head and master.

"Desire" is pronounced *cháng èr*. "Intimacy" is read *jǐ*. "Know the back" is pronounced *pèi*. "Hew and strike" is read *zhuó*. "*Tà* (挞)" means to beat. "Point and scratch" is pronounced *tì sāo*. "Without *xiāo*" is read *xiāo*. "Itch" is pronounced *yú liǎng*. "*Xiāo* and itch" refer to pain and itching. The *Rites of Zhou* states: in spring, there is the ailment of head pain; in summer, there are the ailments of itching and scabies. Zheng Xuan says: "*Xiāo* means sour and emaciated." The *Shuowen* states: "Sourness is pain." Pronounced *zhōu xián biàn*.

"Not obstruct" is pronounced *wǔ gài*. "Thunder" is read *tíng*.

"Unsmooth" is pronounced *bù gǔ*. "Not stumble" is read *bù zhì*. "Cheerful" is pronounced *yí rán yǔ zhī qiè*. "Great" is read *dà*. "Mountain *jī*" is pronounced *shān jī*. The *Book of Han* states: "Great Mountain *Jī* was the teacher of the Yellow Emperor." "*Dì Xiāng*" is pronounced *xī liàng*. "Weary and sleep" forms a complete phrase.

Twenty-eight years—one version writes thirty-eight years. "Great governance" is pronounced *dà zhì*. "Almost like" is read *jī ruò*. "Borrow" is pronounced *jiǎ*. "Cry out" is read *hào zhī hù dāo qiè*. "Mountain of Liegu Ye" is pronounced *liè gū yè*. The mountain lies amid the sea and rivers. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "The state of Guye lies in the sea; to its west and south, it is encircled by the state. Sailing southward a hundred *li*, one reaches Mount Guye; proceeding another three hundred eighty *li* southwest, one reaches Mount Guye." Guo Pu notes: "It is where the river waters traverse the sea, speaking of gazing afar at the various Guye mountains, arrayed between the sea and rivers."

According to the *Account of the Western Regions*: "The Yellow River flows eastward into the Puchang Sea, then courses underground to enter the Central States." The Puchang Sea is also called the Salt Marsh, located in Jiaohé Prefecture. "Appear" is pronounced *xiàn shān xián biàn*.

Above dwell divine beings—this passage is largely the same as the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. "Inhale wind" is pronounced *xī fēng xǔ jí qiè*. "How could" is read *qǐ fù*. The first character of "deep spring" is read as "deep." "Pure" is pronounced *zì suì*. "Not cling" is read *bù wēi wū huī qiè*. "Love" also. "Not love, not cling" means sometimes hidden, sometimes visible. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "At the northern sea’s edge, its people dwell in water." "*Wēi* and love" mean concealed affection. The *Character Forest* states: "*Wēi* means vaguely seen, not clearly."

"Wish" is pronounced *yuàn*. "Abundant" is read *yǐn kǒu jiǎo qiè*. "Without fault" is originally written as *qiān*, pronounced *qù yán qiè*. "Constant balance" is read *cháng jūn*. "Premature death" is pronounced *zhá shāng cè bā qiè*. Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "The Yue people call death *zhá*." The *Zuozhuan* says: "People do not die prematurely." "Flaw" is pronounced *cī cái yí qiè*. "Illness" also. "Epidemic" is read *lì*. Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "*Lì* is illness caused by disharmonious wind and qi." "Spirit" is pronounced *líng xiàng*. "Advance" is read *jìn*.

Below, the same applies.

Cool and verdant, drifting down.

*Kòu* is pronounced *chǐ zhèng qiè*. *Shù* is read *sè zhǔ qiè*. Below, the same applies.

"Not perceiving" is read *bù xǐng xī jǐng qiè*. "By means of leisure" is pronounced *yīn xián*. *Qí* is read *qí*. *Duì* is pronounced *zhuì*, meaning "resentment." Alternatively, "not with fate"—one version omits the character *with*. *Nǚ* is read *rǔ*. *Nǎng zhāng zǎi* is pronounced *nǎi lǎng qiè*. *Zhāng zǎi* is the given name *Zǎi*; another version writes it as *Zhāng Dài*. "Regret" is read *hàn hú gàn qiè*. "Released" is pronounced *tuō rán tǔ huó qiè*. Here, *hū* is alternatively written as *yú*. *Jī* is read *jū*. *Nǚ* is pronounced *rǔ*. *Miǎn* is read *□*, meaning "sidelong glance." *Cóng xīn* is pronounced *zòng*, meaning "indulgence." Below, the same applies. *Gēng* is read *gēng*, pronounced *jū xíng qiè*, meaning "increase." Below, the same applies. *Yū nì* is alternatively written as *yǐ*. "Dao alignment" is read *dào qì kǔ jì qiè*. *Héng* is read in the departing tone; below, the same applies, meaning "unrestrained." "Not yet attained" is pronounced *wèi zào qī dào qiè*. "That which is relied upon" is read *suǒ yǐ yū qǐ qiè*. *Gān* is pronounced *qián*. *Ké* is read *kǒu jiǎo qiè*. *Zēng* is pronounced *céng wèi*. *Jiā* is read *shí zǐ xié qiè*. "Possible" is pronounced *kě jī*. "Greatly ashamed" is read *shèn zuò*. "Holding breath" means to restrain breathing as if not breathing. "Repeating" is pronounced *fú yòu qiè*. *Guān Yǐn* refers to *Guān Lìng Yǐn Xǐ*, styled *Gōng Dù*, who authored nine scrolls. "Concealed movement" is alternatively written as *jiàn*, also pronounced *qián*. "Not empty" is alternatively written as *zhì*, meaning "blocked." "Obstruction" is read *wéi hé*. "Not trembling" is pronounced *bù lì*. *Liè* is read *lì*. *Jī* is pronounced *jū*. *Yú* is read *wú*. "Speech" is pronounced *yǔ yú jù qiè*. *Nǚ* is read *rǔ*. "Far apart" is pronounced *xiāng yuǎn yú wàn qiè*. "Attainment" is read *zhī zào zāng zuò qiè*; the annotation is the same. "Herein" is pronounced *zhě yān yú qián qiè*. "Profound" is read *yín*. "Perceiving worth" is pronounced *jiàn xián biàn qiè*. "Nurturing one’s *qi*" is alternatively written as "preserving one’s true *qi*." "Attainment" is read *zào qī dào qiè*, meaning "to reach."

"Wú" is pronounced *xì*. Means "leisurely."

"Zhī" is pronounced *zhuì* when referring to falling.

"Chéng" is also pronounced *shí líng*.

"È wù" is pronounced *wǔ*. Means "to encounter." An alternative character is □, meaning "to avert one’s gaze when the heart does not wish to see," though this interpretation is somewhat forced. *Zhuāngzǐ* also uses □.

"Not breaking" is pronounced *zhī shè*.

"Not peeping" is pronounced *qù suí*.

"To act as lord" is pronounced *yú wěi*.

"No one" is pronounced *mò hóu*. The following instances are the same.

"Qióng dí" is pronounced *dí*.

"Cuò bēi" is pronounced *bì*.

"Elbow" is pronounced *zhú jiǔ*.

"Nock of an arrow" is pronounced *dí*. Originally written as *dí*.

"Fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*.

"Yǎo" is pronounced *tà*.

"Yù" is pronounced *yù*.

"Mǐn jié" is pronounced *jí yè*.

"Xiàng rén" refers to wooden puppets shaped like humans.

"Qūn" is pronounced *qī xún*.

"Èr fēn chuí" means the feet dangle with two parts exposed.

"To the heels" is pronounced *zhǒng*.

"Huī chì" is pronounced *chǐ*. Guo Xiang comments: "Huī chì means to be unrestrained." He also says: "Huī chì means to be vigorous and swift."

"Chù" is pronounced *chǒu lǜ*.

"Yǒu xùn mù" is pronounced *xún*. He Chengtian’s *Zuan* states: "The people of Wu call blinking *xùn mù*."

"To hit the mark" is pronounced *dīng zhòng*.

"Dài yǐ fú" is alternatively written as "shǐ yǐ fú."

"Piān féi" is pronounced *pí měi*.

According to the *Shuōwén* and *Zìlín*, both use □ or *yí*. All mean "to destroy." The character is an abbreviated form.

"Móu" is pronounced *móu*. Means "equal."

"Yú cháo" is pronounced *cháo*.

"Xiāng líng" is alternatively written as "xiāng jī."

"Jiè yì" is pronounced *jiè*. Means "to assist" or "to match."

"Shǎng" is pronounced *wài gǔ yíng*.

"Tián sǒu" is pronounced *xī kǒu*.

"Xiān" is pronounced *xī jiàn*.

"Jiǒng" is pronounced *qí yǔn*. Means "distressed."

"Hè" is pronounced *hú kě*.

"Běn" is pronounced *běn*.

"Kuì" is pronounced *kuì*.

"Lóng" means "to cage."

"Kuò shì" is pronounced *kǔ kuò*. Means "to gaze afar," "vast," or "expansive."

"Nè" is pronounced *nú cǎo*. According to the *Fangyan*: In the regions of Yang and Yue, when people belittle or mock others as ignorant, they call it *nè*. *Nè* means that the ears and eyes do not trust.

"Qī yí" is pronounced *dài*. According to the *Fangyan*: "to deceive one another." Originally written as *gěi*.

"Dǎng" is pronounced *gù guǎng*. According to the *Fangyan*: Today, people in Jiangdong also call pushing *dǎng*.

Also pronounced *kěn huǎng*. Means "to beat" or "to strike."

"Pú" is pronounced *pú jié*. According to the *Fangyan*: In general, pushing and grappling are called *pú*.

Also pronounced *fú bì*. Means "to push and strike."

"Āi" is pronounced *wū hài*. Means "to push."

"Dǎn" is pronounced *dīng gǎn*. According to the *Fangyan*: "to strike the back." Alternatively written as *kàng*, meaning "to resist" or "to oppose."

"Wáng suǒ" is pronounced *wú*. Means "nowhere."

"Yùn róng" is pronounced *yú wèn*. Means "an angry countenance."

"Jì" is pronounced *qú qí*.

"Dān" is pronounced *dān*. Means "exhausted."

"Bèi" is pronounced *yú pú jiè*. Means "fatigued."

"Jù shēng" is alternatively written as "jù chéng." *Chéng* means "to ascend."

"Màn yán" is pronounced *mò hàn*. Means "scattered" or "diffuse."

"Cháng bǎi" is pronounced *shǎng*. "Fēi fú" is alternatively written as "fēi níu."

"Yáng" is pronounced *yú liàng*. Means "like the swaying of things in the wind."

"Wěi gǔ" is pronounced *jī*. Note: *wěi* is the ancient form of *wěi* (委). The *Shuowen* states: "Of bones, bent or straight." The meaning here is somewhat forced.

"Wú" is pronounced *huǐ*.

"Ǒurán" is pronounced *wǔ kǒu*. Means "not yet fully grown." Alternatively written as *jù*.

"Yīn fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Zhī yín" is pronounced *shēn*.

"Wēi" is pronounced *wū huī*. Means "a bend in the water." Alternatively written as *yú*.

"Yǒng" is pronounced *yǒng*. Means "to swim submerged in water."

"Shuǐ dǐ" is pronounced *dū lǐ*.

"Zhòng fǎng" is pronounced *fēn liǎng*. Alternatively written as *fàng*.

"Nàn sè" is pronounced *nǎi hàn*.

"Āi" is not to be confused with *màn*; *āi* is alternatively written as *huàn*.

"Wú" is pronounced *wú*, with a falling tone.

"Yù" is pronounced *yú*. "Only fear that sincerity does not reach, that it does not proceed, that it does not suffice"—one version omits "that it does not proceed."

"Dárán" is pronounced *dīng dá*. Means "startled."

"Wēi xiǎn" is pronounced *xiǎn*.

"Zhì zhī" is pronounced *zhì*.

King Xuān of Zhōu was named Jìng, son of King Lì.

"Mù zhèng" refers to the chief herdsman responsible for raising animals.

"Liáng yāng" is pronounced *yāng*.

"Wěi" is pronounced *wěi*.

"Shí" is pronounced *sì*; the same applies to "feeding tigers."

"Diāo è" is pronounced *diāo è*.

"There is nothing that is not gentle and docile," pronounced *sōng lún*. Means "obedient." One version omits the character *xùn* ("docile").

"Zī" is pronounced *zī*, also pronounced *zì*. "Wěi zī wěi" refers to the mating of male and female. "Zī" denotes reproduction by birth, while "wěi" denotes reproduction by copulation.

"Bó shì" is pronounced *bó shì*.

Máo Qiūyuán: the surname is Máo, the given name Qiūyuán. Alternatively written as *yǔ*, pronounced *yú lǚ*.

"Transmission and reception"—one version omits the character *shòu* ("reception").

"Wéi" is pronounced *wěi*, with the same pronunciation below.

"Suì" is alternatively written as *jué*.

"Qí chái" is pronounced *zhù jiē*.

"Guǎng zé" is alternatively written as *kuàng*.

"Cāo" is pronounced *qī dāo*, with the same pronunciation below.

"Néng yóu fú shuǐ yuē yóu" means "to be capable of swimming and floating in water is called *yóu*."

"Shù néng" is pronounced *sè jù*. Means "technique." The annotation is the same.

"Zhuó zhōu" is pronounced *zhí xiào*. One version writes it as *jù*, an error for the character *kǒng*.

"Ér sù" is pronounced *suǒ liù*. *Zhuāngzi* writes it as *biàn*.

"Néng wù" is pronounced *mù*, meaning "duck." One version erroneously writes it as *jīn*.

"Yǔ □ tóng" — *□* is pronounced *yī*, a sighing sound.

"Wàn" is pronounced *wǔ guàn*, meaning "to practice."

"Dào yǔ" is pronounced *yú*.

"Qiě wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*.

"Wū wǎng" is pronounced *wū*.

"Xián" is pronounced *xián*.

"Wǎ kōu" — *kōu* means "to probe." To conceal an object in the hand and retrieve it by probing is called *kōu*. It is also called *cáng kōu*. *Fēngtǔ Jì* states: "After the sacrifices on the La festival, elders and children play the *kōu* game." Xīn Shì’s *Sān Qín Jì* records: "Lady Gōuyì of the Han had clenched fists, and people imitated her, hence the name *cáng gōu*." *Kōu* is pronounced *kǒu hóu*. *Zhuāngzi* writes it as *shū*.

The hook is made of silver and bronze.

"Dàn" is pronounced *dài hàn*.

"Hūn" is pronounced *hūn*. *Fāngyán* states: "confusion and *hūn*."

"Suǒ yào" is pronounced *yú yáo*.

"Yù zhòng" is pronounced *yǔ*. It means "to increase."

The original text writes *gǒng* as *zhuō*.

Lǚliáng is located in present-day Pángchéng Prefecture. *Ěryǎ* states: "A rock that cuts off water is called a *liáng*."

"Bìng liú" is pronounced *páng*.

*Shǐjì* and *Hànshū* write *bàng* ("beside") as *bìng* ("alongside") in phrases such as "beside the sea" and "along the river."

"Ér chéng" is pronounced *zhěng*. *Fāngyán* states: "*chéng* means to rescue from drowning." Some versions write it directly as *zhěng* or *zhěng*.

"Táng" is pronounced *táng* in *táng xíng*. The same pronunciation applies below.

"Dào zhī" is pronounced *dǎo*. The same pronunciation applies below. Guō Pú’s annotation to *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn* states: "*dào* means to follow."

"Chéng zǐ" is pronounced *zhěng*.

"Yuē wáng" is pronounced *wú*. The original text lacks this *wáng* character.

Sīmǎ of Qí states: "Qí refers to the Gǔ River, like grinding and *qí*." *Gǔ* is pronounced *gǔ hū*, meaning "surging waves." Guō Xiàng states: "That which swirls beneath and surges forth is *gǔ*."

"Jū" is pronounced *yǔ*. *Lǚ* is pronounced *lǚ*.

"Jū lǚ" refers to a hunched back, a spinal deformity.

"Chéng cháo" is pronounced *tiáo*. One version writes it as *tiáo*, meaning "cicada."

"Duō" is pronounced *duō kuò*, meaning "to pick up."

"Lěi" is the original form of the character *lěi*.

"Yuàn" is pronounced *wán*. Sīmǎ states: "It refers to piling pellets atop a pole."

"Zī zhū" is pronounced *zī shū*.

"Tiáo" is pronounced *tiáo*.

"Wú chǔ shēn" ("I dwell in the body")—one version writes it as "wú shēn" ("without a body").

"Jué zhū jū"—*jué* is sometimes written as *jué* (identical in meaning). It is pronounced *qí yuè*. The *Shuōwén* writes it as *jué*, meaning "the base of a tree." Lǐ Yí states: "*Jué* means upright." *Zhū jū* also refers to the stump of a withered tree. *Jū* is pronounced *jū*.

"Cuī zhuàn" is pronounced *quán*. He was a man of Qīnghé, a Discussant of the Jin dynasty, who annotated the twenty-seven inner and outer chapters of the *Nanhua Zhenjing*.

"Gǎo mù" is pronounced *hǎo qiē*.

"Yuē nǚ" is pronounced *rǔ*.

"Féng yī"—The *Lǐjì*’s "Rúxíng" chapter states: "In his youth, Confucius lived in Lu, wearing robes with wide sleeves. Later, he resided in Song, donning the *zhāngfǔ* cap." Zhèng Xuán’s annotation says: "*Féng* means 'large,' referring to robes with broad sleeves." Xiàng Xiù states: "Confucian robes are loose and long."

"Yǒu" is pronounced *hū bào*.

"Ōu" is pronounced *ōu*, referring to the osprey, a water bird. Those seen today by rivers and lakes—white as doves and flying in flocks—are of this kind.

"Bǎi zhù" is pronounced *shù*.

"Rǔ qǔ lái" ("you take and come")—one version writes it as "kě qǔ lái" ("you may take and come").

"Qù" is pronounced *qú lǚ*.

"Qí" is pronounced *yì*.

"Wǔ" is pronounced *wù*.

"Hài" is pronounced *xié*. The same below.

Zhào Xiāngzǐ’s given name was Wúxù, son of Jiǎnzǐ.

The discipline followed by his followers.

"Tián" is pronounced *tián*.

The *Shǐjì* states: "Zào Fù obtained for King Mù the horses *Huá liú*, *Lǜ ěr*, *Chì jì*, and *Bái xī*. Driving them on his travels, he visited the Queen Mother of the West and, delighted, forgot to return." This account aligns roughly with the *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn*. Guō Pú’s commentary notes: "All are named for their coat colors." Later, *Qú huáng*, *Yú yú*, *Dào lí*, and *Shān zǐ* were also counted among the Eight Steeds.

"Zào" is pronounced *qī dào qiè*. "Fù" is pronounced *fǔ*.

The *Shǐjì* states: "King Mu of Zhou rode *Huá liú* and *Lǜ ěr*, with Zào Fù as his charioteer, covering a thousand *lǐ* in a day." □ is pronounced *tài*. In seal script, it is written as *yì*.  is pronounced *bǐng*. The *Stone Classics* render it as *fēng*, while the *Zìlín* notes: "The hidden form resembles *miàn*." Originally written as . The upper part aligns, the lower converges, yet this bears no relevance to the meaning.

As for the right-hand passage, the *Huáinánzǐ* states: "The charioteers Qián Qiě and Tài Bǐng removed the bridle and bit, discarding the whip and goad." Gāo Yòu comments: "All were ancient masters of the Dao skilled in charioteering." *Qián* is pronounced *qí yán qiè*. *Qiě* is pronounced *zǐ yú qiè*. *Dào lí* is pronounced *lì yí qiè*. *Dào lí* refers to the *Xiān lí* mentioned in the *Xúnzǐ*. *Bǎi yāo* is pronounced *yú biǎo qiè*.
