"Jiù" is pronounced *jiù*. "Ē" is pronounced *ā*; "fǔ zàng cái" is pronounced *làng*. "Mài zhěn" is pronounced *zhǐ rěn*. "Qí chōu" is pronounced *chǒu jiū*. "Rán wú zhī fāng mì" forms a sentence. "Cóng zhī" is pronounced *zòng*. "Jué sī" is pronounced *sì*. "Cāo gē" is pronounced *qī dāo*. "Wǎng shù" is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. "Āi yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Hǎo" is pronounced *hū bào*. "Wù" is pronounced *wū lù*. "Kě fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Miào dāng" is pronounced *dīng làng*, or in one version, *shǎng*. "Péng shì" is pronounced *páng*. "Zǐ shào" is pronounced *shī zhào*. "Mí wǎng" is pronounced *wén liǎng*. "Guò chén" is pronounced *gē*. "Xiāng shǐ" is pronounced *xiàng*. "Āi yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Zhī yóu" is pronounced *yóu*. "Yān néng" is pronounced *yú qián*. "Chuán guī" is pronounced *shì yuán*. "Biàn zhēng" is pronounced *zhèng*. "Zhǎng yú" is pronounced *zhāng zhàng*. "Guò jìn" is pronounced *gē*. "Kuáng zhī" is pronounced *jiǔ kuàng*. "Qiǎo rán" is pronounced *qī xiǎo*. "Kuì rán" is pronounced *qiū kuì*. "Juān rán" is pronounced *xuàn*. "Hú quǎn" and "hú juàn" are both pronounced *èr qiè*. "Zì jìn" is pronounced *jīn*. "Yǎ rán" is pronounced *wū mò*. "Gěi ruò" is pronounced *dài*, meaning "to deceive." "Gèng" means "slight, minor"; those who write it as *chè* are mistaken.

"Zhòng Ní dì sì" reads *jí zhì*. "Qù qíng" is pronounced *qiū lǚ*, or in one version, *wàng*. Zhongni was a native of Qufu County in the state of Lu, born on Mount Niqiu of the Yan clan, hence his name and style, Zhongni. He was born in the twenty-first year of King Ling of Zhou, the *gēngxū* year. "Jiān jū" is pronounced *xián*. Zigong was Duanmu Ci, a native of Wei, styled Zigong, known for his eloquence and skill in speech. Yan Hui was a native of Lu, styled Ziyuan. "Yuán qín" is pronounced *yuán*. "Dú yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Zhī fēn" is pronounced *fú wèn*; the same below. "Qiǎo rán" is pronounced *qī xiǎo*. "Yǒu jiān" means "after a short while, his countenance changed for a time." "Yì jiá" is pronounced *xiá*, or in one version, *shī*. "Wáng biàn" is pronounced *wàng*, or in one version, *zhǐ*. "Nǎng wú" is pronounced *nǎi lǎng*. "Lǐ yuè" is pronounced *yuè*; the same below. "Yí lái" is pronounced *wéi jì*. "Jì zhì" is pronounced *zhí lì*. "Zhì luàn" is the same below. "Bù shě" is pronounced *shě*. "Wú hé" is pronounced *ài*. "Jiāng wéi" is pronounced *gān wěi*. "Yù juān" is pronounced *yuán*. "Pìn lǔ" is pronounced *pǐ zhèng*. "Fǎng fú" is pronounced *fāng fèi*. "Zhī liàng" is pronounced *liàng*. "Qí chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*; the same below. "Bó rán" is pronounced *pò*; the same below. "Kàng Cāngzǐ" is pronounced *Gēng Sāng*, named Chu. The *Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as *Kàng Cāngzǐ*. Jia Kui’s *Yao Shi Ying Lan* states: "In Wu Commandery, there is a clan named Gengsang, regarded as a scholarly family." "Chuán zhī" is pronounced *zhuān*. "Wéi rán" is pronounced *wéi guǐ*.

"Méi jié" is pronounced *jiē*. "Wéi huò" is pronounced *huǒ huó*. "Yǒu fèn" is pronounced *fú wèn*. "Liù zàng" is pronounced *cú làng*. The heart, lungs, liver, spleen, and kidneys are called the five *zàng*. Now, the six *zàng* refer to the kidneys being two: the left is called the kidney, and the right is called the *Mingmen* (Gate of Life), which is where the spirit resides. In men, it stores essence; in women, it connects to the womb. Its *qi* communicates with the kidneys, hence it is said there are six *zàng*. "Shāng dà" is pronounced *tài*. "Zǎi Shāng" refers to the state of Song. The capital of Song was Shangqiu, hence the two names. "Dà zǎi" is an official title. "Shì" is pronounced *xiàn biàn*. "Jiǎn pǔ" is pronounced *piàn jué*. "Bù zhì" is pronounced *zhí lì*; the same below for "zhì". "Qiǎng" is pronounced *qiǎng*. "Wéi" is pronounced *wéi*. "Dé biàn" is the same as *biàn*. "Chóng jué" is pronounced *jiāo wù*. "Hào máng" is pronounced *máng*. "Mò rán" is pronounced *mò*. "Wú yǔ" is pronounced *yú jù*. "Nè" is pronounced *nú hū*. "Yī xíng" is pronounced *xià mèng*. "Bù èr" means unwavering resolve. "Tóng yào" is pronounced *yī yáo*. "Piē" is pronounced *mò xiá*. "Nǎi jū" has an alternate version reading *fǎn jū*. "Yuē shù" is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. "Liào jiǎn" is pronounced *liáo*. "Wú tì" is pronounced *tā lì*. "Yuè" is pronounced *yuè*. "Qī pò" is pronounced *piàn gè*; the *Character Book* writes it as *qī lèi*, meaning facial ugliness. "Lèi" is pronounced *piàn gè*. "Xíng sàng" is pronounced *xī làng*. "Sī lǜ" is pronounced *sì*. "Wèi xíng" is pronounced *hù láng*. "Kàn kàn" is pronounced *kǒu hàn*. "Zài xióng" has an alternate version reading *cún xióng*. "Hài" is the same as *hài*. "Jìn zhī" is pronounced *jìn*. "Néng lí" is pronounced *lì zhì*. "Zhī chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. "Yī miǎn" is pronounced *miàn*, meaning a sidelong glance. "Cóng xīn" is pronounced *zòng* (with *xīn* in the departing tone). "Wài jìn" is pronounced *jìn*. "Yǐ zhòng" is pronounced *zhù yòng*. "Hào yóu" is pronounced *hū bào*; the same below.

"Zhī lè" is pronounced *luò*. "Líng cuì" is pronounced *jí zuì*. "Zhě" is pronounced *xī qiǎn*. "Bù zhī wù nèi guān" has an alternate version reading *bù rú guān*. "Gǔ" is pronounced *luàn*; the same below. It means to scrutinize. "Kǒu wā" is pronounced *wū guā*. "Wēn zhēng" is pronounced *zhèng*. "Zì nì" is pronounced *ní lì*. "Zhě" is pronounced *nán nǎi dàn*. "Gù" is pronounced *zhù yòng*. "Suǒ shì" is pronounced *shì*. "Wén zhì" is pronounced *zhì*.

Wen Zhi was a man of the Warring States period, though some say he was a skilled physician of the State of Song during the Spring and Autumn period. He once treated King Wei of Qi—or King Wen of Qi—by provoking the king’s anger to cure his illness.

"Suǒ tīng" is read in the level tone. "Fán cǐ zhòng jí" has an alternate version reading *zhòng shù*, which is incorrect. "Āi lè" is pronounced *luò*. "Bèi míng" is pronounced *pèi*. In later texts, Wen Zhi faces the light to gaze—versions adding *cóng* (from), *jí* (and), or *zì* (self) are all incorrect.

"Zhī fèn" is pronounced *fú wèn*. "Yóu sǐ ér shēng bù xìng yě" originally lacked the character *bù* (not), but judging from the context, it is logically incomplete, so it has been added here. "Shī zhōng" is pronounced *dīng zhòng*. "Jiāng miǎo" is pronounced *wáng shǎo*. "Xiān dǔ" is pronounced *dǔ*. "Wén ruì" is pronounced *ér kuì*. "Zī" is pronounced *yān*. "Miǎn" is pronounced *shèng*.

The Zī River rises in Laiwu County, Lu Commandery, while the Miǎn River flows westward from the borders of Qiancheng County in Beihai Commandery to Shouguang County, where the two rivers converge. The *Shuō Fú* chapter states: "The blending of the Zī and Miǎn is as indistinguishable as Yi Ya’s palate." "Nán bié" is pronounced *bǐ liè*; the same below.

"Jiāng jiāng" is pronounced *jiāng*. "Xiān jí" is pronounced *qù lì*; the *Fangyan* states: "*Jí* means to receive." "Bēn yì" is pronounced *bēn yì*. "Pū yě" is pronounced *fù*. "Kě yú" is pronounced *yú*. "Kàng" is the same as *kàng*. "Yào zào" is pronounced *qī dào*. "Hòu huán" is pronounced *xuán*. The marsh of Zheng is Pǔtián; it is located in Zhongmu County.

"Yǒu zhì" is pronounced *zhí*. "Xíng guò" is pronounced *gē*. "Dèng Xī" is pronounced *xī*. "Wéi ruò" is pronounced *yú wěi*. "Xiāng cháo" is pronounced *zhāng jiāo*. "Diào" is pronounced *tiáo*. "Suǒ yuàn zhī yě" — *zhī* is in one version written as *rú*. "Yǎng" (first instance) is pronounced *yú liàng*; (second instance) is read as written. "Zhǎng yòu" is pronounced *zhāng zhàng*. "Láo" originally written as *qián*, pronounced *cè zhàn*. *Láo* refers to animal pens or enclosures; *qián* means to surround with bamboo or wood, or to stab. The *Rites of Zhou · Bièrén* states: "They catch fish, turtles, and clams at the proper time." The *Guoyu* also says: "They net and trap fish." The *Zhuangzi* states: "To overlook the animal pens." Li Yi comments: "*Láo* is a pigsty, fenced with wood." Though the characters differ, their meaning is the same. "Jí" is pronounced *zhà*. "Páo chú" is pronounced *páo*. "Cóng zhě" is pronounced *cái yòng*. "Wú xiāng xī" is pronounced *xī liàng*. "Ér zhī" is pronounced *zhì*. Below: "seek it with intention." "Bìng wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*. Below: "seek it with intention." "Wú hào" is pronounced *hū bào*. "Wú wù" is pronounced *wū lù*. "Xún Cān" is pronounced *qī hàn*. "Fù Gǔ" is pronounced *jiǎ*. "Zhì jú" is pronounced *qú zú*. "Gōngyí Bó" and "Tángxī Gōng" — *Gōngyí* and *Tángxī* are surnames; both were worthy gentlemen of Zhou. "Nuò fū" is pronounced *nǎo wàn*. "Nǚ zhī" is pronounced *rǔ*.

The pronunciation of "折" is *zhé*. "春蠡" is pronounced *zhōng*. One says it is a locust. The pronunciation of "股" is *gǔ*. "裂" may also be written as "分." "犀兕" is pronounced *xú zǐ*. "曳" is pronounced *yì*, similar to "憾," which is pronounced *hù àn*. "窥" is pronounced *kuī*. "易" is pronounced *chǐ*. Below, the same. "舆薪" is pronounced *yú*. "撞钟" is pronounced *zhái hóng*. "雷霆" is pronounced *tíng*. One family’s version writes "一道" instead of "一," but it does not extend the meaning.

"子牟" is pronounced *mò hóu*. "好与" is pronounced *hū bào*. "不恤" is pronounced *suī lǜ*. "子舆" is pronounced *yú*. "行无" is pronounced *xià mèng*. "不中" is pronounced *dīng zhòng*. "漫" is pronounced *wàn*. "衍" is pronounced *yǐ zhàn*. "韩檀" is pronounced *bù ān*. "肄" is pronounced *gē èr*. "肄" means to practice. "桓团" is pronounced *dà duān*. "囿" is pronounced *yòu*. "诒" is pronounced *dài*. It means to deceive. Below, the same. "镞" is pronounced *mù*. "中" is pronounced *zhòng*. Below and in the annotation, the same. "相属" is pronounced *zhǔ*. The annotation is the same. "矢造" is pronounced *qī dào*. "着" is pronounced *zhí lüè*. Below, the same. "堋" is pronounced *péng*. "复" is pronounced *fú yòu*. Below, the same. "凑" is pronounced *qī dòu*. "逢蒙" is pronounced *bó jiāng*. "乌号" is pronounced *hù gāo*. "綦卫" is pronounced *qí*. The *Records of the Historian* states: "Bamboo from the state of Qí." Jin Zhu says: "The gardens of Wei abound with bamboo and *yao*." "射" is pronounced *yì*. The end of the arrow is also written as "来."

The pupil is pronounced *mò hóu*. The eye socket is pronounced *kuāng*. "不睫" was originally written as "", meaning the blinking of the eye. Below, the same. "" is pronounced *qià*. The arrow’s path is pronounced *zhuì*. A strong crossbow is pronounced *qí liǎng*. "撒" is also written as "穿". "鲁缟" is pronounced *gǔ lǎo*. "与" is pronounced *yú*. "掷" is pronounced *zhí zhì*. "分" is pronounced *fú*. "符" is pronounced *wèn*. "差跌" is pronounced *cuō jīng*. "语张" is pronounced *yú jù*. "焉得" is pronounced *yú qián*. "故借" is pronounced *zǐ yì*. "见在" is pronounced *xián biàn*. "孤犊" is pronounced *dú*. "胜言" is pronounced *shēng*. "可解" is pronounced *xiè*. Below, the same.

Gongsun Long was a retainer of Lord Pingyuan, styled Zibing, a native of Zhao. "之呜" is also written as "公孙龙於马". The annotation omits "无", differing from "鸣", and is also written as "无异於马". "云马" refers to the meaning of the *White Horse Discourse*. "云鸣" means merely to cry out without reason or principle. The error in taking the wrong standard would be great indeed.

"余窍" is pronounced *kǒu diào*, meaning a filthy orifice. "余日" is pronounced *rén zhì*. "尧治天下" forms a phrase. "欲治" is pronounced *zhí lì*. "治欤" refers to the name of governance; "治道" is the same. "道洽" was originally written as "合". "外朝" is pronounced *cháo*. "禅" is pronounced *shàn*. "□" is the ancient form of "畴", pronounced *zhí liú*, meaning "who". "泛然" is pronounced *fāng jiàn*. "无系" is pronounced *jì*. "其应" is pronounced *yìng*. "道亡" is pronounced *wú*. "违物" is also written as "道不违物". "亡情" was originally written as "忘". "发无知" is also written as "废无知". Below, it is written as "废无能". Though it is non-action, it is not contrary to principle—one version omits the character "为".

*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume One* concludes.
*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume Two* begins.

Master Yin Jingshun of Dangtu County, Tang Dynasty, compiled; Chen Jingyuan of Bixu supplemented omissions.

*Tang Asks, Fifth Chapter*

"Qi" is pronounced *cái xì*. "Yin Tang" (Tang of Yin): surname Zi, or Lü, style Tianyi. "Xia Ji" is pronounced *jí*. Xia Ji, style Ziji, was a grandee of Yang. "Hun mang" is pronounced *máng*. "Wu" (evil) is pronounced *wū* below, the same. "Bi fu" is pronounced *fú yòu* below, the same. "Chong zhu" is pronounced *zhù yòng* below, the same. "Hua ran" is pronounced *huò*; one version writes "exhausted." *Erya* of Qi State states: south of Qi, wearing the sun is called Danxue; north of it, wearing the Dipper and Pole is called Kongtong. "Ju" means "to distance." "Qi" means "center." Eastward to Ying—present-day Liucheng, ancient Yingzhou—eastward to the sea. Westward to Bin, also written as "邠." "Four Seas, Four Wastes, Four Poles": *Erya* states: the Nine Yi, Eight Di, Seven Jie, Six Man are called the Four Seas. Guzhu, Beihu, Xiwangmu; "sun’s descent" refers to the Four Wastes: Dongqin, Yuanxi, Jiaoguo, Nanpu. Yanci, Zhu, Li are called the Four Poles.

"Yi" is pronounced *xiàn biàn*. "Da xu" is pronounced *tài* below, the same. "Long zhao" is pronounced *zhào xiào*. "Yi yan" is pronounced *yú qián* below, the same. "Zhi ji" is written as "ji" in one version; likely a character error. "Huo shi" is pronounced *hū kuò*. "Wu yin" is pronounced *yín* below, the same; one version writes "limit." "Jie ju" is pronounced *jū*. "Zhi gu" is pronounced *zhì gǔ*. "Zi jie" is pronounced *xiè*. "Ku zhuo" is pronounced *kū*. "Kua da" is pronounced *kǒu huā*. "Dan" is pronounced *tā gān*; the name of Laozi. "Zhou" is the name of Zhuangzi. "Nü Wa Shi" is pronounced *guā*; an ancient Son of Heaven, of the Feng clan. "Duan Ao" is pronounced *duàn āo*; explained later. "Gong" is pronounced *gōng*. "Gong Shi" was an ancient emperor. "Zhuan Xu" is pronounced *zhuān xù*. "Fu" is pronounced *fú*. "Xi" is pronounced *xǔ yí*. "Shui lao" is pronounced *lǎo*. "Bo Hai" is present-day Le’an Prefecture. "Da he": *Shanhaijing* states: beyond the Eastern Sea lies a great abyss. "Gui xu" is also written as "Gui tang." "Ba xian" is pronounced *hóng*. "Dai yu" is pronounced *yú*. "Yun qiao" is pronounced *qú miào*; mountains sharp and towering. "Fang hu" is also called Fangzhang. "Ying zhou" is pronounced *yíng*. "Peng lai": *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Fangzhang, Yingzhou, Penglai—these three divine mountains lie in the Bohai Sea. Some have reached them; immortals and the elixir of death reside there. Before arrival, they appear like clouds; when approached, they recede.

Yet none could ever reach them.

"Zhou Fan" is also written as *fan wei* (范围) or *zhou xuan* (周旋). "Chun" is pronounced *chún*. "Gao" is pronounced *gǔ lǎo*. "Zhu gan" is pronounced *gān*. "Ke" (可) is pronounced *shǔ* (数), meaning "to count"; the annotation is the same. "Lian zhuo" is pronounced *zhí lüè*. "Bo shang" is pronounced *shí zhǎng*. "Zan zhi" is pronounced *zhí lǐ*. "Xian sheng du zhi" (仙圣毒之): *du* (毒) means "to afflict."

"Yu Qiang" is pronounced the same as *yu* (隅). *Shenxian Zhuan* states: the northern deity is named Yu Qiang, styled Xuánmíngzǐ. *Shanhaijing* says: in the great wilderness, there is a spirit with a human face and a crow’s body, called Yu Qiang. *Tongwen* notes: this is the sea god.

"Ju Ao": *Liexian Zhuan* states: the giant turtle bore Mount Penglai upon its back and danced in the midst of the deep. *Xuanzhong Ji* says: this is the giant turtle. "San fan" is pronounced *fān*, meaning "to alternate." "Ying shu" is pronounced *shǔ* (数), meaning "full measure." "Bu" is also written as *qian* (千). "Diao" is also written as *gou* (钩). "Er qu" is pronounced *qū*. "Zhuo qi" is pronounced *zhuó*. "Yi shu" is pronounced *shù*, meaning "to calculate." "You zuan" is pronounced *niǔ guān*.

"Kun Peng" is pronounced *kūn péng*. "Wen rui" is pronounced *wén ruì*. "Zao shi" is pronounced *zǎo sè*. "Di Feng" is pronounced *fèn*. "Jin jian" is pronounced *zǐ jìn*; also written as *qin* (侵). "Shi e" is pronounced *wū mài*. "Jiao Yao Guo" is pronounced *jiāo yáo*; the name of a land of short people. *Records of the Grand Historian* states: the Jiao Yao people stand three feet tall, the shortest of all. Wei Zhao says: Jiao Yao is another name for the southwestern barbarians. According to *Kuodi Zhi*, it lies northwest of Da Qin. By the eras of Fuxi and Shennong, the people of this land were still several thousand *zhang* tall—elsewhere written as several tens of *zhang*. For details, see *Xian Pian* (贤篇); the annotation below is the same.

"Contentious person" is pronounced *zhēng rén*. *The Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: beyond the Eastern Sea, there are small people called "contentious ones"; also the name of the *Mingling* tree, which grows south of the Yangtze. Its leaves sprout in spring and fall in autumn.

"Great *chun*" is pronounced *chǒu lún*. A tree name, also called *shùn*.

"*Jūnzhī*" is pronounced *qí yīn*. Cui Zhuan says: the *zhī* grows on dung, appearing at dawn and dying by dusk. Emperor Jianwen says: the *zhī* springs forth suddenly.

"*Měng*" is pronounced *mò kǒng*; "*ruì*" is pronounced *ruì*. These refer to *mièměng* and *wénruì*, both small flying insects.

North of *Zhongfa*—elsewhere written as north of *Zhongbei*—lies the *Ming Sea*. *Records of the Ten Continents* states: waters of black color are called the *Ming Sea*. Its vastness is pronounced *shàng gǔ kuàng*, *xià sè zhǔ*; its length is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*—the same below. It is the domain of the *kūn* and whale.

"*Peng*" is pronounced *bù dēng*; "*suī*" is pronounced *yǔ jù*; "*míng*" is pronounced *mí zhèng*, identical to *ming* (铭), meaning "to record and inscribe."

"*Yāo* insect" is pronounced *wáng guǒ*. *The Character Book* states: *yāo* means small.

"*Jiāomíng*" is pronounced *míng*; "*wénjié*" is pronounced *jiē*; "*shì*" is pronounced *shì*; "*zì*" is pronounced *zài yì*, referring to the corners of the eyes.

"*Chú*" is pronounced *chú yǐ*. Yu and Shi Kuang were men of ancient times with keen hearing.

"*Tī* ear" is pronounced *tì*; "*fǔ* head" is pronounced *miǎn*.

*Kongtong*: *Records of the Grand Historian* states: the Yellow Emperor, reaching the river, ascended Mount Kongtong. It now lies in Liquan Prefecture.

"*Pēng* sound" is pronounced *pǔ gēng*.

Thunder is pronounced *tíng*.

"*Yòu*" is pronounced *yòu*. *The Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: Jing Mountain abounds with orange and *yòu*. *Yòu* resembles the orange but is larger, with thick skin and a sour taste.

"*Sì fèn*" is pronounced *fáng wěn*, referring to the swiftness of its *qi*.

When it crosses northward, it transforms into the *zhǐ*. *The Rites of Zhou* states: the orange, upon crossing the Huai River to the north, transforms into the *zhǐ*.

"*Qúyù*" is pronounced *dí yù*.

It does not cross the Ji. "*Bù yú Jǐ*" is pronounced *zǐ lǐ*.

"*Mò*" is pronounced *hè*, resembling the fox and fond of sleep, a beast.

If it crosses the Wen, it dies. "*Yú Wèn*" is pronounced *wǔ jīn*. Deng Yuan’s *Commentary on the Water Classic* states: the Ji River originates from Mount Wangwu, forming the *duì* sound. As the Yan River, it flows east through Wen, becoming the Ji River, then enters the Yellow River over ten *li* downstream. Southward, it meanders into the river, forming Rong Marsh, and further flows through Jiyin and nine other commanderies before reaching the sea. *The Rites of Zhou* states: the *qúyù* does not cross the Ji, and the *mò*, if it crosses the Wen, dies—such is the influence of the land’s *qi*. Zheng Xuan notes: the Wen River lies north of the city of Lu, and earlier scholars, following one another, mistakenly took it for the Wen River of Lu. This is a grave error. According to *Records of the Grand Historian*, the Wen shares the same pronunciation as *□*, *wǔ jīn*, referring to the Wen River of Jiang. It is not the Wen pronounced *wèn*. As *The Classic of Mountains and Seas* records: the Great River emerges from Mount Wen. Guo Pu comments: it flows southeast toward Shu Commandery, northeast toward Badong and Jiangxia, and reaches the sea at Guangling. *Han’s Outer Commentary on the Book of Songs* states: of old, the Jiang River issued from Mount Wen; at its source, it was but a shallow stream, sufficient to float a winecup. The *Songs of Chu* also speak of "the clear Jiang of hidden Mount Wen." This is conclusive. Moreover, *Liezi* and *The Rites of Zhou* both affirm that the nature of water and soil differs, and transplantation causes harm. Thus, the four great rivers are cited as examples. Now, the Wen River of Lu spans no more than a few dozen paces, its source extending no farther than two hundred *li*. Even Yang Li crosses it with ease, traversing it in moments. How could the fox or *mò* perish merely by briefly venturing across? *The Explanation of Graphs* states: the *mò* is a kind of fox, all of which thrive in hilly, arid lands. Today, people living by the river say: "The *zhuā* does not ford the Jiang." Clearly, crossing great waters harms their innate nature, leading to their death.

The phrase ends at "*yǐ*." One version reads: "the balance of *qíng* and *xìng*."

"*Fēn*" is pronounced *fú wèn*.

"*Dà xíng*" is pronounced *tài xíng*; the annotation is the same.

"*Dōng yuán*" is pronounced *yuán*.

"*Chéng* mountain" in *Han’s Outer Commentary on the Book of Songs* means "to suffer." "*Zhī yū*" is pronounced *yú*, with the same pronunciation below.

Miscellaneous pronunciations: *zá rán* as *qī hé*. The same below.
*Yóu* as *qiān* (七廉切).
*Zhì nán* as *nǎi dàn*.
*Céng bù* as *céng*. The same below.
*Kuí fù*: *Huainanzi* writes it as *kuí fù* (魁阜), meaning small hills resembling mounds.
*Qiě* as *yú* (於虔切).
*Hè* as *hú kě*.
*Yán* as *dīng gān*.
*Kòu shí*: striking stones.
*Kěn rǎng* as *kǔ hèn*: turning soil.
*Jī běn*: *bèn* (音本), a basket.
*Zhī shuāng* as *shuāng*.
*Shǐ chèn* as *chū rèn*: *Han’s Outer Commentary on the Book of Songs* states: "At seven, boys and girls may lose teeth, called *chèn*."
*Tiào wǎng* as *tiáo*: leaping.
Alternatively written as *tiào*, an error.
*Kě chè* as *chǒu liè*.
*One version reads*: *hé ruò* (何若), another *kǔ* (苦).
*Cāo shé* as *qī dāo*.
*Gāo fēng zhuì wéi yōu gǔ*: one version reads *gāo àn suì wéi yōu gǔ* (高岸遂为幽谷).
*Fèi shě* as *shè*.
*Dǐ lì* as *zhǐ cè*.
*Kuā é shì*: one version reads *kuā yǐ shì* (夸蚁氏).
*Kuā* as *kǒu huā*.
*Yī cuò* as *cuò*.
*Lǒng duàn* as *lì zhǒng*.
*Yǔ lí* as *lí*.
*Yǐ shěn*: *shì rěn*.
*Chī* as *chì* (赤之切).
*Chá yǔ* as *yú*.
*Kuā fù* as *kǒu huā*; *fù* as *fǔ*. *The Classic of Great Wilderness* states: "There is one who wears two yellow snakes as earrings and grasps two yellow snakes, named *Kuāfù*."
*Suǒ jìn* as *zǐ jìn*.
*Yào zhī* as *yáo*.
*Dà suì* as *tài*.
*Qí fēn* as *fú wèn*.
*Zēng* as *sì líng*.
*Kuàng* as *kuàng*.
*Zhōu chē* as *jū*.
*Qí xiàn* as *zǐ xì*.
*Qiáo zhì*: *Erya* states: "*Qiáo* means high and crooked." It also states: "Three mountains overlap in *zhì*." Guo Pu comments: "Layered ridges."
*Dān* as *dīng gān*; *zhuì* as *zhí wéi*. *Dān zhuì* refers to earthen jars.
*Shén fèn* as *fǔ wèn*. Guo Pu comments: "Today, in Fenyin of Hedong, there is a body of water, round like a wheel, bubbling and surging forth, bottomless, called *Hàn zì*."
*Fén shàng qǐng*.
*Lán jiāo* as *jiāo*.
*Láo lǐ* as *láo lǐ*.
*Sì liè* as *liè*.
*Wáng bù* as *wú*. The same below.
*Zhá* as *cè bā*: *lì zhá* means death from epidemic.
*Xìng wǎn* as *yuàn*.
*Zhǎng yòu* as *zhāng zhàng*.
*Chái* as *jū shì jiē*.
*Bù pìn* as *pìn*: to multiply; to flourish.
*Sú hào* as *hū bào*.
*Dié* as *zhí*.
*Yáo* as *yáo*.
*Quán* as *juàn*.
*□* as *chāng liǎng*.
*Shuò* as *sè zhǔ*.
*Yuè* as *nǎi* (ancient form of *nǎi*).
*Jǐ kè* as *qí jì*.
*Xí péng* as *xí*.
*Jūn shě* as *shè*.
*Sì* as *chì*.
*Zhà* as *zhì jià*.
*Tú zú* as *zǐ hū*.
*Shì huī* as *zhǐ huī*.
*Zhòng fù* as *fǔ*.
*Zhī mào* as *mò bào*.
*Wěi* as *yú guǐ*.
*Chén kǒng* in falling tone.
*Xī liàn* as *lì juǎn*: "of it" or "to go."
*Zhù fà* as *zhī liù*. Kong Anguo’s commentary on *The Book of Documents* states: "*Zhù* means to sever the hair." *The History of the Han* states: "The people of *Yí* cut their hair and tattoo their bodies to avoid harm from *jiāo* dragons." One version reads *bèi* (被), likely an error.
*Ér luǒ* as *hū wǎ*: meaning not covering the body with clothes.
*Hé jīn* as *mò*. *Fangyan* states: "Commoners’ *mò* headwear." *Mò tóu* is *qiāo tóu* (幧头). *Mò* is also written as *hé*, *mà*, or *mò* (帓), pronounced *wáng bā*.
*Cǎo* as *qī xiāo*.
*Cí fáng* as *jí yí*.
*Yí mò* as *mò*.
*Yuè zhī dōng yǒu zhé xiū zhī guó*: *Zhé* (辄), *Shuowen* writes as *qǔ* (取), *zhū shè*, meaning long earlobes; *xiū* means beauty. Likely referring to the *dān ěr* (儋耳) people. Other texts write *□ mù*, an error.
*Zhǎng zǐ* as *dīng zhàng*.

When alive, they consume it fresh—Du Yu’s commentary on *The Zuo Tradition* states: "Those who do not die of old age are called *xiǎn*, meaning young." To eat is pronounced *dàn* (去声). Originally written as *yán*. Some versions write *gǔ* (骨), pronounced *guǎ*. To strip flesh. Also pronounced *xiǔ*. *Nǎi* is the ancient form of *nǎi* (乃). *Yíqú* is pronounced *péng*. *Chái* is pronounced *chái*. *Shuowen* states: "To burn firewood and kindle flames in sacrifice to the heavenly spirits." Sometimes interchangeable with *chái* (柴). *Jī* is pronounced *zhì*, meaning to gather. When smoking, pronounced *xūn*. Smoke rising is pronounced *shàng* (时掌切). *Biàn dòu* is pronounced *dū dòu*. *Chuàngchuàng* is pronounced *chū liáng*. Some versions write *cāng*. *The Book of Zhou* states: "Between heaven and earth, there is *chuàng* heat; those who skillfully apply the Dao will never exhaust it." Kong Chao’s commentary says: "*Chuàng* means cold." Huan Tan’s *New Discourses* also records this as *chuàng liáng*. *Cháo* is pronounced *cháo*. *Liángliáng*: *Zilin* states: "*Liáng* means slight cold." *Bù wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi*. Below the same. *Liánzhǔ* is pronounced *zhú*. Below the same. *Wēi cuì* is pronounced *qī suì*. *Jūn chǔ* is pronounced *chāng jù*. *Zhān Hé* is pronounced *zhān*. *Dú jiǎn* is pronounced *diǎn*. *Máng zhēn* is pronounced *wáng zhēn*. *Jīng xiǎo* originally wrote *tiáo*. To split is pronounced *piàn* (口切). *Lì* is pronounced *lì*. *Gǔ liú* is pronounced *gǔ wù*, meaning swift. *Bù náo* is pronounced *nǎi xiào*, referring to bent wood. *Máng ěr* is pronounced *réng ěr*. *Guà wēi* is pronounced *guà*. To apply or discard is pronounced *shè*. *Xié háng*: above pronounced *hú jié*, below *hù láng*. *Pú jū* is pronounced *zǐ yú*. *Xiān zhuó* is pronounced *zhuó*. *Shuāng cāng* is pronounced *cāng*. To release is pronounced *fēn* (分两切). *Jù mò* is pronounced *mò*. *Lǔ Gōng Hù* is pronounced *hù*. *Biǎn Pú* is pronounced *diǎn*. *Què*: *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "Bian Que was a man of Bohai Commandery, surnamed Qin, named Yue Ren. Skilled in medicine, he could examine illnesses and fully perceive the ailments of the five viscera." *Rǔ Xiāng* is pronounced *nǎi lǎng*. *Fǔ zàng* is pronounced *cú làng*. Below the same. *Xié zhǎng* is pronounced *zhāng zhàng*. Now pronounced *yú wěi*. *Yú duàn* is pronounced *dīng guàn*. Below the same. Then to drink is pronounced *yú jìn*. To split the chest is pronounced *piàn* (口切). *Huà* is pronounced *hù*. *Tā* is pronounced *zhì*. To eviscerate is pronounced *kū*. To rinse is pronounced *jiān*. To wash is pronounced *xiān lǐ*. To contemplate is pronounced *yì*. To conjecture is pronounced *yì*. *Hù Bā* is pronounced *hù*. To press the string is written as *zhù* in one version. *Gōu* is pronounced *jūn*. To set aside the zither is pronounced *shě*. To not respond is pronounced *yú zhèng*. *Hòu Hé* is pronounced *hú wò*. *Wú jǐ* is pronounced *jū qǐ*. *Hé fù* is pronounced *fú yòu*. To knock is pronounced *kǒu hóu*. A cool breeze suddenly arrives—one version writes *zǒng zhì*, which is an error. To stimulate is pronounced *jī*. *Jiá zhōng* is pronounced *gǔ qià*.

To strike the *yu* note is pronounced *wáng yù*. Violent is pronounced *bào*. Freezing is pronounced *hú gǔ*. To march is pronounced *zhì lǐ*. *Ruibin* is pronounced *rú jiā*. Fierce and blazing is pronounced *chǐ zhì*. *Lǐ* spring is pronounced *lǐ*. To act is pronounced *yú wěi*. *Zōu* is pronounced *cè yóu*. To extend is pronounced *yǐ zhàn*. A man of *Qí*, tutor to King Zhao of *Yān*. He resided at *Jìxià* and was styled *Tántiān Yǎn*, authoring forty-nine scrolls. He also composed *Zhōngshǐ* in fifty-six scrolls. None is pronounced *wú*. To carry under the arm is pronounced *xié*. To chant is pronounced *ōu*. Skill is pronounced *qú qǐ*. Echoes are stilled, pronounced *wū gě*. Provisions are pronounced *guō*. *Yōngmén* is pronounced *yì*. A place name—*Dù Yù* states: a city gate of *Qí*. To sell songs is pronounced *yù*. *Liánglì* is pronounced *lì*, referring to the ridgepole of a house. Drawn-out singing is prolonged singing. One *lǐ*—one version writes *ten lǐ*. Tears fall, pronounced *tì*. Sunlit moisture. Again is pronounced *fú yòu*. To leap and clap is pronounced *biàn*. To restrain oneself is pronounced *jīn*. To release is pronounced *fēn liǎng*. Lofty is pronounced *é*. Finally encountering is pronounced *cūn* (entering tone). Drenching rain is pronounced *lín*. The melody *Zhī Cāo* is pronounced *qī dào*. Then to set aside is pronounced *shě*. The heart’s resolve is pronounced *fú*. *Yǎn* is pronounced *yǎn*, the place where the sun enters the mountains. *Wáng Jiàn* in *Guǎngyǎ* is pronounced *jìn*. Below the same. The next day—one version writes *the following day*. To request an audience is pronounced *xiàn biàn*. Below the same.

Skilled singers are pronounced *chāng*. Actors are pronounced *bù jiē*. To hasten is pronounced *qū*. Craftsmen are pronounced *fú*. To nod is pronounced *qū*; also pronounced *wǔ gǎn*. To shake the head is pronounced *lǐng*. The jaw is pronounced *yí*. To blink is pronounced *shùn*. To tremble greatly is pronounced *shè*. All are pronounced *fù*. To observe closely is pronounced *dū jì*. To assess strength is pronounced *diào*. The liver is pronounced *gān*. The gallbladder is pronounced *dīng gǎn*. The heart and lungs are pronounced *fāng fèi*. The spleen is pronounced *pí*. The kidneys are pronounced in the upper tone. Sinews are pronounced *jīn*. To meet again is pronounced *fú yòu*; also read as written. To sigh—one version writes *gū tàn*. Nearly is pronounced *jī hū*. Cloud ladders are pronounced *tā xī*. Mò Dí is pronounced *Dí*. Flying kites are pronounced *yuān*. Qín Gǔlí is pronounced *Gǔ Lí*, a disciple of Mò Dí. To dare to enumerate is pronounced *shuò*. Gān Yíng is pronounced *Yú Líng*. A bow’s frame is pronounced *gòu*, meaning to draw a bow. To change is pronounced *gēng*. To be full is pronounced *yíng*. To pull taut is pronounced *tú dǐng*. A trigger mechanism is pronounced *nǚ zhé*. The tip of an awl is pronounced *jiā*. To invert is pronounced *dū dǎo*. The corner of the eye is pronounced *zì*. Secondary is pronounced *wū jià*; also means "next." One version writes *bì xué*, which is incorrect. With yak hair is pronounced *máo*. To suspend a louse is pronounced *suǒ yǐ*. Gradually is pronounced *zǐ jìn*. Things are measured as pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. A bow of Yan horn is pronounced *Yān*. The bow of *zhī* is pronounced *hú*. The arrow shaft is pronounced *gǎn*. To shoot is pronounced *shí*. To strengthen is pronounced *liǎng*. To strike the chest is pronounced *fǔ yīng*. The arrowhead is pronounced *fēng*. To fall—one version writes *duì*. To ward off is pronounced *hàn*.

The arm-cutting rite—*Huainanzi* states: "The Central States draw blood from the *shà*, while the Yue people cut their arms—both are one and the same." Xu Shen explains: "To cut the arm and draw blood." *Shà* is pronounced *suǒ jiǎ*. To drive is pronounced *zào qī*. Father is pronounced *fù*. To exchange is pronounced *shì chǐ*. My course is pronounced *qū*; same below. Six reins are pronounced *liù pèi*. Barely is pronounced *jǐn*. Loose and dense is pronounced *shū jì*. Without stumbling is pronounced *wú diē*. Swift is pronounced *jié hū*. Harmonious is pronounced *qí jí*. *Shuowen* states: "*Jí*—the carriage body." Regarding the juncture of reins and bit, this speaks of Zaofu’s mastery in driving, achieving harmony in the carriage body precisely at the reins and bit. It metaphorically illustrates that when a ruler wins the people’s hearts, the state is at peace. Lips are pronounced *chún wěn*. Chest is pronounced *xiōng yì*. Centered on the compass is pronounced *zhòng guī*; same below. Eyes fixed is pronounced *mù zhī*; also written as *shì*. To mark is pronounced *shí zhī*. To be close is pronounced *nì*. Hills and ridges are pronounced *qiū bǐng*. Ability is pronounced *néng chèn*. Body weak is pronounced *tǐ léi*. Fierce resolve is pronounced *hàn zhì*. Blade’s edge is pronounced *máng è*. Scar is pronounced *hén*. To whip is pronounced *tà*. Chick is pronounced *chú zhù*. A fledgling still needing to be fed is called *gǔ*, while one that feeds itself is called *chú*. *Jiǎ tuó* is pronounced *tuó*; also pronounced *bào*. One version writes *bào*. To exchange is pronounced *shì chǐ*. To act for me is pronounced *wéi wǒ*. Servant boy is pronounced *tóng zǐ*. Vanishing is pronounced *mǐn rán*. Vast is pronounced *dàn dàn*. The sound of breaking is pronounced *huō*; a crashing noise. To transmit is pronounced *zhuàn*. A case is pronounced *xiá*, same as *xiá*. Essence is pronounced *zhì yào*; same below. To hasten is pronounced *qū*.

Three beckonings—one version writes *niān*. Pronounced *nú xiàng*. To point and take an object. Also pronounced *diǎn*. My throat is pronounced *wǒ yì*. The upper part of the throat. *Zhī qiáng* is pronounced *qí liǎng*. Its *yàn* is pronounced *yú rǎn*. The character 木 is also written 压, pronounced *wū xiá*. The sword *kūn wú* is the Dragon Sword. The *River Chart* states: "Yíngzhōu has many piled stones, called *kūn wú*, which can be made into swords." The *Master Shi* says: "The *kūn wú* sword can cut jade." Fire-washed cloth is pronounced *huǒ huǎn*. The *Record of Strange Things* states: "In the kingdom of Xīndiào, there is a Fire Continent with trees and rats; their fur and skin are made into cloth, called fire-washed cloth." *Zhǐ* is pronounced *zhǐ*. Eight *cùn* are called *zhǐ*. Refined steel is pronounced *liàn gāng*. *Hào rán* is pronounced *gǎo*. Also written 皓. Pronounced *hú lǎo*. *Zhāng duàn* is pronounced *dà guàn*.

**Section on the Mandate of Strength and Fate**

*Fēn fú* is pronounced *wèn*. Longevity and early death are pronounced *yú zhào*. *Xì* is pronounced *jì*. *Xíng* is pronounced *xià mèng*. Jì Zhá was a descendant of Tài Bó of Wú. Virtuous, he yielded his position, abandoned his household to farm, and was later enfeoffed at Yánlíng, hence called Yánlíng Jìzǐ. Love and hate are pronounced *wū lù*. Disorder and order are pronounced *dí*. *Xùn* is written as 徇 in one version, meaning to seek. To be minced is pronounced *bèi hǎi*. To knock is pronounced *kòu qí*. *Bìng xíng* is pronounced *xià mèng*. *Shù* is pronounced *shù*. *Hè* is pronounced *hè*. The *Fāngyán* states: "*Shù* is a double-layered jacket." Xǔ Shèn’s commentary on the *Huáinánzǐ* says: "The people of Chǔ call a robe *shù*." The *Shuōwén* states: "It is coarse clothing, or a worn cloth jacket." It also says: "A short *chānyú* is called *shùyú*." Those who write it as short *hè* are mistaken. The *Xúnzǐ* writes it as *shù hè*. Yáng Jìng’s commentary states: "The coarse clothing of young servants." This interpretation is also strained. *Zī* is pronounced *jí yí*. *Lì* is pronounced *lìng dá*. *Zī* is a rice cake. The *Shēnglèi* says *hé* is unbroken rice. The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "Chén Píng ate chaff *hé*." Mèng Kāng explains: "This refers to unbroken wheat chaff." It generally means coarsely pounded millet or wheat, made into cakes for eating. *Lián lì* is pronounced *lì*, meaning a roof beam. *Xī rán* is pronounced *yí*. The *Zìlín* states: "It means joyful laughter." *Zài cháo* is pronounced *cháo*. *È rán* is pronounced *è*. *Áo zhèn* is pronounced *ào*. *Yǔ yǔ* is pronounced *qiū péng*. One version writes it as 踽.

The *Zìlín* states: "The appearance of walking in sparse formation."

*Jiāng shě* is pronounced *shè*.
*Yán xíng* is pronounced *xià* (Mèng cut).
*Zǐ yǔ* is pronounced *yú jù*.
*Shí fū* is pronounced *fú*.
*Fù yán* is pronounced *fú yòu*.
*Yī qí* is pronounced *wū jì*.
*Hú hè* is pronounced *hú hè* (the character 鹤 is a variant).
*Róng shū* is pronounced *róng shū*.
The *Ěryǎ* states: "*Róng shū* is called *rěn shū*, that is, barbarian beans." The *Guǎnzǐ* states: "Duke Huán of Qí went north to Mount Dài and gathered winter onions and *róng shū*, which he then spread throughout the land." Zhèng Xuán comments: "This refers to soybeans."

*Bì qí* is pronounced *bì lì*.
*Bì* is pronounced *bì*.
*Lù* is pronounced *lù*.
The *Zuǒzhuàn* states: "A firewood cart."
*Yōu* is pronounced *yóu*, meaning a self-contented appearance.
The later *Yáng Zhū* chapter uses the same pronunciation.
*Yǐ gài* is pronounced *gǔ dài*.
*Néng hū* is pronounced *wù*.
*Yì* is pronounced *chǐ*.
*Dá* is pronounced *dāng gē*.
The variant *wù* is incorrect.

Guǎn Yíwú and Bào Shūyá were both from Yǐngshàng.
Bào Yá was a grandee of Qí, and his tomb is in Yíngzhōu.
*Gōngzǐ Chǒu* is pronounced *guī yǒu*.
*Dí shù* is pronounced *dí*.
Qí Xīgōng is pronounced *xǔ qí* (or written as *lí*).
*Shào Hū* was originally written as *Shào*.
He fled to *Jǔ*, pronounced *jǔ*.
*Chù* is pronounced *chù* (no sound) or *shì hū*.
*Zhì fú* is pronounced *zhì*.
*Suì shā* is pronounced *shì*.
*Shè* is pronounced *shí yì*.
*Zhòng Dīng* is pronounced *zhòng*.
*Lā* is also written as *xié*.
*Governing the state* is pronounced *zhí lì*.
*To be capable* is pronounced *yú wěi*.
*Hegemon* is pronounced *yú kuàng*.
*Bì shě* is pronounced *shì*.
*Táng fù* is pronounced *fù*.
Jiǎ Kuì states: "Tángfù is the northern border of Lǔ." Dù Yù states: "It is a place in Qí, Dōngguǎn."
*Ér jiàn xián* is pronounced *biàn*.
*Shēn xià* is pronounced *xiá jià*.
*Zhòng fù* is pronounced *fǔ*.
*Shū Jiǎ* is pronounced *gǔ*.
*Cháng wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi*.
*Fù huì* is pronounced *fú yòu*.
*Wū hū* is pronounced *wū*.
*Shǔ guó* is pronounced *zhú*.
*Yù yú* is pronounced *yú*.
*Xù lián* is pronounced *jié*.
*Qì xiá* is pronounced *xiá*.
*Xí Péng* is pronounced *xí*.
*Xián xià* is pronounced *xiá jià*.
*Bù gǔ* is pronounced *gǔ*.
*Gù jǐn* is pronounced *jìn*.
Dèng Xī is pronounced *xī*.
Dèng Xī wrote two chapters; he was a man of Zhèng and a contemporary of Zǐ Chǎn. Both *Lièzǐ* and Xún Qīng state that Zǐ Chǎn killed Dèng Xī. However, according to the *Zuǒzhuàn*, in the twentieth year of Duke Zhāo, Zǐ Chǎn died. In the ninth year of Duke Dìng, Sì Luán killed Dèng Zhú and adopted his bamboo penal code, so it was not Zǐ Chǎn who killed him.
*Cāo* is pronounced *qī dāo*.
*Shù* is pronounced *shuò*.

*Nán* is pronounced *nǎn*.
*Lù* is pronounced *lù* or written as *dào*.
*Sì Luán* is pronounced *chuán*.
*Chǎn* is pronounced *zhú* in *zǐ chǎn*.
*Zhī xíng* is pronounced *xià mèng*.
*Ér chóng zhù* is pronounced *yòng*.
*Wú fēn* is pronounced *fú wèn*.
(Annotation identical to previous.)
*Guǐ mèi* is sometimes written as *guǐ mèi*.
*Yí sàng* is pronounced *xī làng*.
*Bù wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi*.
*Fú* is pronounced *yú liè*.
*Bù jiě* is pronounced *xiè*.
*Jiǎo shì* is pronounced *jū yāo*.
*Zhěn* is pronounced *zhī rěn*.
(Diagnosing the pulse.)
*Nǚ hán* is pronounced *rǔ*.
(Identical below.)
*Qì* is pronounced *huī*.
*Píng* is pronounced in the upper tone.
(To remove.)
*Rǔ dòng* is pronounced *zhù yòng*.
(Milk.)
*Qiě shí* is pronounced *sì*.
*Zhī fēn* is pronounced *fú wèn*.
*Chóng kuàng* is pronounced *kuàng*.
*Zì chōu* is pronounced *chóu*; *yù* is pronounced *yù*.
*Xióng yǔ* is pronounced *yú jù*.
(Identical below.)
*Suàn* is pronounced *xiān wàn*.
*Suǒ wáng* is pronounced *wú*.
*Dān* is pronounced *tā gān*.
*Suǒ wù* is pronounced *wū lù*.
*Chuǎi* is pronounced *chū wěi*; *lì* is pronounced *liào yǐ*.
*Yǒu rén yú cǐ nián xiōng dì yě* — *zī* is pronounced *jí yí*.
(Should be *zī*, the character for wealth. One version writes *yán*.)
*Zhì* is pronounced *zhì*.
*Mèi mèi* is pronounced *huì*.
*Wáng shòu yāo* is pronounced *yuán*.
(Identical below.)
*Què yǐ* is pronounced *kǒu jué*.
*Xī lè* is pronounced *luò*.
*Dòng ruò xiè* is pronounced *hù jiè*.
(One version writes *jiè*.)
*Bù wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi*.
(Annotation identical to previous.)
*Ài* is pronounced *ài*.
*Mò chī* is pronounced *méi chī*.
(According to the *Fāngyán*, *mò chī* in the Jiang-Huai region means *wú lài*. The *Guǎngyǎ* states: *mò* is pronounced *mù*; *chī* is written as *qī*.)

From these twenty individuals onward, their intelligence, skill, talent, and conduct diverged in opposing pairs, yet they could remain harmonious and united throughout their lives, each following their true nature.

*Dān* is pronounced *zhàn*.
*Zhì zhàn* — *zhì* means "to the utmost."
*Tān* is pronounced *chǐ rán* or *tā dān*.
*Xuān* is pronounced *xuān* or *hū yuǎn*.
(Zheng Xuan’s annotation to the *Lǐjì* states: *xuān* means "relaxed and spacious." The *Shuōwén* states: *xuān* means "a relaxed and unburdened state of mind.")
*Biē* is pronounced *piē miè*.
*Fū* is pronounced *fū*.
(According to the *Fāngyán*, *fū* and *fū* are pronounced *fú* and mean "impetuous.")
*Xū* is pronounced *jū*.
*Rú xū* means "mutual"; *xiāng* means "to follow."
(Each follows their own will.)
*Qiǎo nìng* — cunning speech and perverse flattery.
*Yú zhí* — foolish and straightforward like a simpleton.
*Nǎn* is pronounced in the upper tone.
*Zhuó* is pronounced *zhuó*.

"Zhuì" is pronounced "zhī shuì qiè." "Wěi" is pronounced "kǒu huì qiè," or alternatively "rú wěi qiè." It means dull and stagnant. The *Ěryǎ* states: "zhuì wěi" means to shift blame away. **Yang Zhu, Chapter Seven: "Attaining Life"**

Yang Zhu—some say his courtesy name was Ziju—was a man of the Warring States period, later than Mozi. In debates with Qin Guli, his doctrine centered on self-love, refusing to pluck even a single hair for the benefit of the world, directly opposing Mozi. Lu Deming notes: "Yang Rong, courtesy name Ziju"—but fears Ziju may not have been Yang Zhu.

"Without resentment" is pronounced *wú yùn yī wèn qiè*.

"Prince" is pronounced *gōng zǐ chú shì yú qiè*.

"Duke’s awakening" is pronounced *gōng wù* as *wù*.

"To have a rift" is pronounced *yǒu xì qù nì qiè*.

"Harmony" is pronounced *yōng* as *yōng*.

"Appearance" is alternatively written as *yǎn*.

"Eyebrows and eyelashes" is pronounced *méi jié* as *jiē*.

"To steal" is pronounced *dào wéi yú wěi qiè*.

"And bed" is pronounced *ér chuáng* as *qiáng*. The same below. Alternatively written as *cán*.

"Great terror" is pronounced *dà hài* as *hài*.

"To anticipate" is pronounced *zhì liào* in the falling tone.

"To expose" is pronounced *yǐ zhì zhí gé qiè*.

"Round" is pronounced *huán liú* as *yuán*.

"To wade through water" forms a phrase.

"To combine" is pronounced *bìng pú làng qiè*.

"Bank" is pronounced *yá* as *yá*.

"To misjudge" is pronounced *cuò yì qī gù qiè*.

"You recognize" is pronounced *zǐ shí* as *zhì*.

"Not again" is pronounced *bù fù fú yòu qiè*.

"Fèi Wújí" is pronounced *fèi wú jí fáng wèi qiè*.

"To triumph" is pronounced *shèng shī zhèng qiè*.

"Bái Gōng" is a name.

"To issue orders" is pronounced *bào lìng láng dìng qiè*.

"Zī" is pronounced *zī zè qí qiè*.

"Miǎn" is pronounced *miǎn* as *chéng*.

"Again" is pronounced *fù wéi fú yòu qiè*.

"To distinguish" is pronounced *suǒ bié bǐ liè qiè*.

"Those who pursue" is pronounced *zhě qù* as *qū*.

"Not joy" is pronounced *fēi lè* as *luò*.

"To abandon words" is pronounced *qù yán qiū lǚ qiè*.

"Shallow wisdom" is pronounced *qiǎn zhī* as *zhì*.

"To understand" is pronounced *jiě xiǎn xī qiǎn qiè*.

"In difficulty" is pronounced *yú nàn nǎi dàn qiè*.

"Xīn Gǎn Mùzǐ" — Xīn Gǎn Mùzǐ was a grandee of Jin, also called Xīn Suì Zhìgǒu.

"To attack Dí" is pronounced *gōng dí* as *dí*.

"To triumph" forms a complete phrase.

"Courier" is pronounced *jù rén* as *jù*.

"Courier’s report" is pronounced *jù zhuàn* in the falling tone.

"Whirlwind" is pronounced *piāo fēng fú xiāo qiè*.

"Virtue and conduct" is pronounced *dé xíng xià mèng qiè*.

"Suddenly" is written as *zú rán*.

"To restrain" is pronounced *zǐ lǜ qiè*.

"Its strength" is pronounced *zhī jìn jū shèng qiè*. It means "strength."

"To extend" is alternatively written as *zhāo*. Li Shan’s commentary on *The Wen Xuan*’s *Wu Capital Rhapsody* states: *zhāo* is the same as *qiào*. *The Huainanzi* writes it as *biāo*. Xǔ Shèn states: *biāo* means "to pull." In ancient times, the lower part of a suspended gate was pulled upward—this was difficult.

"Gōngshū Bān" is pronounced *gōng shū bān* as *bān*.

"To love" is pronounced *hǎo hū bào qiè*.

"Unremitting" is pronounced *bù xiè* as *xiè*.

"Again" is pronounced *fù* as *fú*.

"To oppose" is pronounced *wǔ* as *wù*.

"To besiege its city" — Xǔ Shèn’s commentary on *The Huainanzi* states: During the reign of King Zhuang of Chu, the siege of Song lasted nine months. One version writes it as "state" (*guó*), which is incorrect.

"To break bones" is pronounced *xī hái* as *xī*.

"More than half" is pronounced *dà bàn* as *tài*.

"Lanzi" — The *Records of the Grand Historian* commentary states: One without a tally or pass entering or leaving is called *lán*. Yīng Shào says: *lán* means "reckless." This so-called *lánzǐ* refers to one who wanders recklessly by means of skill. It is suspected that *lán* is the same as *lán*.

"To employ" is pronounced *yǐ jì* as *qǐ*.

"To summon" is pronounced *shǐ jiàn* as *biàn*.

"Twice as long" is written as *zhǎng bèi*, following the original character.

"To entrust" is pronounced *zhǔ* as *zhú*.

"Shin" is pronounced *jī jìng* as *jìng*.

"Again" is pronounced *fù* as *fú*. The same applies below.

"Sojourner" is pronounced *qiáo rén* as *qiáo*. It means "to lodge."

"No need to employ" forms a phrase.

"Detained and about to be executed" — one version omits the character *nǐ*.

"To anticipate" is pronounced *yù yāo* as *yáo*.

"Advanced in years" is pronounced *nián zhǎng* as *zhàng*.

"To physiognomize" is pronounced *shàn xiàng* as *xiàng*. The same applies below.

"Sinews and bones" is pronounced *jīn gǔ* as *jīn*.

"Resembling" is pronounced *fǎng fú*: the first as *fǎng*, the second as *fáng wèi*.

"Confused" is pronounced *huǎng hū* as *huǎng hū*.

"To cease" is pronounced *mǐ* as *mǐ*.

"To erase traces" is pronounced *chè jì*. One version writes it as *彻*.

"Together" is also written as *gòng*. One version writes it as *供*.

"To carry" is pronounced *dān* as *dān*.

"Rope" is pronounced *mò* as *mò*.

"Jiufang Gao" is pronounced *jiǔ fāng gāo* as *gāo*. In one version, this is written as *bǐ*.

"To request an audience" is pronounced *qǐng jiàn* as *biàn*. The same applies below.

"To err" is pronounced *yǒu guò* as *gù*.

"Female" is pronounced *pìn* as *pín*.

"Male" is pronounced *mǔ* as *mǔ*.

"And black" is pronounced *ér lí* as *lí*.

"Not pleased" is pronounced *bù yuè* as *yuè*.

"Its general form is the same as a deer’s."

"Zhān Hé" is pronounced *zhān hé* as *zhān*.

"Personal governance" is pronounced *shēn zhì* as *zhì*.

"State governance" is the same.

"Sunshu Ao" is pronounced *sūn shū áo* as *áo*. He was a grandee of Chu.

"Elder" is pronounced *zhǎng lǎo* as *zhàng*.

"To abhor" is pronounced *zhǔ è* as *wù*.

"My act" is pronounced *wú shī* as *shì*.

"The king repeatedly" is pronounced *wáng jí* as *jí*. It means "urgent."

"For me" is pronounced *wéi wǒ* as *wèi*.

"Human mechanism" is pronounced *rén jī* as *jī*.

"It is an omen" — also pronounced *jī*.

The Sleeping Mound lies in Gushi. *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Sunshu Ao was skilled in favoring You Meng. Later, You Meng spoke to King Zhuang, who summoned Sunshu Ao’s son and enfeoffed him at the Sleeping Mound.

"Niu Que" is pronounced *niú quē* as *quē*.

"Handan" is pronounced *hán dān*.

"Alas" is pronounced *yuē xī* as *xī*.

"*Yǐ fú*" is pronounced *yǐ fú* as *fú*.

"Go to see the Lord of Zhao and take me as your task—he will surely distress me" forms a complete sentence. One version reads: "Go to see the Lord of Zhao, and he will surely take me as a distress."

"To the pass" is pronounced *zhì guān* as *què* in one version.

"His elder brother" is also written as *yì* in one version.

"Strenuous contention" is pronounced *lì zhēng* as *zhèng*.

"Where will benevolence be?" is pronounced *rén jiāng yān* as *yú*.

"Vast measure" is read in the departing tone.

"Wealth and goods without limit" is pronounced *cái huò wú zī* as *zī*. It means "immeasurable." Jia Kui’s annotation to *Discourses of the States* states: *zī* means "measure."

"Striking at *bo*"—*jī* means "to strike," as in the modern game of *shuanglu* at dusk. Wei Zhao’s *On Gambling* states: "Setting up wood and striking it is the method."

*The Classic of Ancient Bo* states: The rules of *bo* require two players to sit facing each other across a board divided into twelve paths, with the two ends at the center called "the waters." Twelve *mu* pieces are used—six white and six black—along with two fish pieces placed in the waters. The dice are made of *qiong*, a square of one *cun* and three *fen*, five *fen* in length, with pointed ends and drilled indentations on four sides called "eyes" or "teeth." The two players take turns casting the dice to move their *mu* pieces. When a *mu* reaches a position, it is stood upright and called a "valiant *mu*," which then enters the waters to eat the fish—also called "leading the fish." Leading one fish earns two tallies; flipping one fish earns three tallies. If one has already led two fish but fails to win, it is called "being flipped with double fish," and the opponent gains six tallies, achieving a great victory.

*Cè* is pronounced *cè*.

"*Bo* is akin to archery" forms a complete sentence.

"Shí" is pronounced *qiè*. "Míng qióng" is pronounced with *zhāng* as in *zhōng* and *dīng* as in *zhōng qiè*. "Fǎn" is pronounced *fān*. "Liǎng" is pronounced *tā là*.

In all games where players contend in skill to hit a target, it is called "shooting" or "casting." Péi Sì states: "Reporting the *cai* means capturing the fish." The character "qín" in some versions of the *True Classic* is written as "fish." According to the *Great Bo Sutra*, it is written as "dié," the flatfish. This likely refers to the two fish as a pair, like the eyes of a brave one. Here, it means that upon reporting the *cai* and hitting the mark, one flips the two fish to achieve a great victory and laughs.

"Dié" is pronounced *tā là*. Modern versions read "□ fish," which contains an extra character. By meaning, "dié" is used, not "fish"; "fish" is used, not "dié."

"Fēi yuān" is pronounced *yuán*. "Shì" is pronounced *zhǐ*. "Duì" is pronounced *zhuì*. "Fù lè" is pronounced *luò*. "Qīng yì" is pronounced with *qǐng* as in *gǔ qiè*. "Lì" is pronounced *qín*, meaning "brave." "Lù lì" is pronounced *liú*, meaning "to join forces." "Jīng bīng" in one version is written as "accumulated troops." "Zhī xíng" is pronounced with *xíng* as in *xià mèng*. "Hú fù" is pronounced *fǔ*; the same below. "Hú" is pronounced *sūn*, meaning "water-soaked rice." "Yǐ bǔ" is pronounced *fǔ*. "Yuē xī" is pronounced *xī*. "Shí wǒ" is pronounced *sì*. "Ér ōu" is pronounced with *ōu* as in *yī kǒu qiè*. "Kā" is pronounced *kè*. "Fú dì ér sǐ" in one version omits the character "dì." "Shí líng" is pronounced *líng*. "Qiàn" is pronounced in the third tone; in one version, it is written as "qiàn." "Shí xiàng" is pronounced *xiàng*. "Yǒu nàn" is pronounced with *nàn* as in *nǎi dàn*. "Jīn sǐ ér fú sǐ" in one version omits the three characters "ér fú sǐ." "Bù zhī jǐ" is pronounced *jǐ*. "Mù yǐ wéi bù zhī jǐ zhě jū hǎi shàng" in one version reads "ér qù hǎi shàng." "Duì" is pronounced *zhuì*. "Yǐ wàng" in one version is written as "wáng." "Wéi qǐng" is pronounced *jīng*. The *Zì lín* states: "Jīng means sincerity." In one version, it is pronounced *qíng*. The *Shuō wén* states: "It is the yin *qi* of a person, having desires." Xú Guǎng says: "The ancient form of *qíng*." Sometimes borrowed as "qǐng." "Shí fǎn" in one version is written as "jí," which is incorrect. "Qī rán" is pronounced with *zǐ* as in *zǐ liù*. "Jiàn chù" is pronounced *chǒu jiù*. "Yǒng yú qiú" is pronounced *qiú*. "Cāo" is pronounced *qī dāo*. "Jī bàn" is pronounced *qí*. "Zhī yū" is pronounced *yú*, meaning "curved." "Zhī pì" is pronounced *pì*. "Sàng" is pronounced *xī làng*; the same below. "Wéi wáng" is pronounced *wú*; the same below. "Zǐ zhǎng" is pronounced with *zhǎng* as in *zhāng zhàng*. It is a modal particle. "Yī" is pronounced *yū jì*; the same below for "clothing." "Zī yī" is the same. "Sù yī" is read as written. "Pǔ" is pronounced *piàn bǔ*. "Xiāng zhě" is pronounced *xiàng*. "Shǐ rǔ jiàn gǒu" in one version omits the character "jiàn." "Yǔ zhēng" is pronounced *zhèng*; the same below.

"Huàn nàn" is pronounced with *nàn* as in *dàn qiē*. "Bù jié" is pronounced with *jié* as in *jiē qiè*. "Qí shǐ" is pronounced *suǒ lì*. "Zì sàng" is pronounced *xī làng*. "Xī wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*. "Hán dān" is pronounced *hán dān*. "Kè" is pronounced with *hé* as in *hú wò*. "Xiāng wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*; the same below. "Wén" is pronounced *wén*. "Ruì" is pronounced *ruì*. "Zǎn" is pronounced *zǐ là*. "Qí jí" is pronounced with *jí* as in *qù lì*, meaning "frequent." "Zhī jiù" is pronounced *jiù*. "Fēn" is pronounced *jì* as in *fú wèn*. "Wú fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*.

There was a man of Song who was traveling on the Way—one version reads "There was a man of Song on the Way." "Yí qì" is pronounced *kǒu jì*, referring to a wooden tally used to record matters. "Mì shù" is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. "Lín fù" is pronounced *fǔ*; the same below. "Rén" is the ancient form of *nǎi*. "Wáng fū" is pronounced *fǔ*, meaning "axe." "Yuè" is also meant. "Ér hú" is pronounced *hú mò*, the ancient form of *jué*. Another pronunciation is *qí yuè*; one version writes it as "xiāng," which is incorrect. "Fù jiàn" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Bái Gōng Shèng" is pronounced with *shèng* as in *shī zhèng*. "Cè zhuì" is pronounced *zhāng liè*. Xǔ Shèn’s commentary on the *Huainanzi* states: "The tip of a horsewhip has a sharp metal point, used to spur a horse that refuses to advance." "Zhǔ" is pronounced *zhú*. "Zhuó" is pronounced *zhí lüè*.

The foot stumbles, pronounced *zhì*, meaning "obstructed." "Zhū kǎn" is pronounced *kǎn*. The head strikes, pronounced *dīng lǐ*. "Clothing and cap" are both read in the departing tone. "Shì yù" is pronounced *yù*, meaning "to sell." "Yīn jué" is pronounced *jué*, meaning "to snatch." The officer arrests, with *chāng* pronounced *chāng*, meaning "to mock or toy with." One version reads "obtains it." "Why do you snatch another’s gold?"—one version omits the character "why." "Mí zhuó" is pronounced *zhí lüè*. "Bó rán" is pronounced *pò*, describing a state of calm and stillness. *The Exegetical Commentary on the Perfect Scripture of the Dao of Utmost Emptiness and Primal Virtue*, Scroll the Lower, concludes.

chunks.original_text: 冲虚至德真经释文 经名：冲虚至德真经释文。 唐段敬顺撰，宋陈景元补遗。 二卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 冲虚至德真经释文序 夫庄子之未生，而列子之道已汪洋汗漫，充满于太虚而无形蛶可闻也。 故着书发扬黄老之幽隐，剖抉生死之根柢，堕弢解衾，决疣溃痈，语其自然而不知其然，意其无为而任其所为。 辞旨纵横，若木叶乾壳； 乘风束西，飘讽乎天地之间无所不至。 而后庄子多称其言，载于论说，故世称老庄而不称老列者，是繇庄子合异为同，义指一贯，离坚分白，有无并包也。 昔列子陆沈圃田四十年而人莫识，藏形众庶在国而君不知，天隐者也。 人有道而人莫誉，道岂细也夫； 书有理而世罕称理，岂粗也夫。 之人也，之书也，深矣远矣，与物返矣，不其高哉！ 仆自总角，好读是书，患无音义，解所暗惑。 及长游天台山桐柏於司马微水帐之下，获烂书两卷，标题隐约乃列子释文，纸墨败坏，不任展玩而急手抄录。 其脱落蠹碎，墁灭栈损，十亡四五矣，而纸尾题云唐当涂县丞殷敬顺纂衡岳墨希子书，遂草写藏于巾衍。 后於潜山览有唐道士徐灵府手写列子，洎卢重玄注就於藏室，翻景德年中国子监印本，参有校无，会同帖异，比得国子监印本经并注，脱误长乙共一百六十字，集成讹谬同异一卷，附于释文之后，已而补亡拾遗，复其旧目。 前人所解最善者，如程是豹之别名乃泰丙两字。 古文此其博学而多识者，其有越略惟俟同志损益启悟。 熙宁二年九月九日碧虚子题序。 列子冲虚至德真经释文卷上 唐当涂县丞殷敬顺撰 碧虚子陈景元补遗 列子新书目录 姓列，名御寇，或名圄寇。 先庄子，故庄子称之。 天宝初，奉旨册为冲虚真人，其书改题曰《冲虚真经》，名冠八篇之首。 此是刘向取二十篇除合而成，都名《新书》焉。 大宋景德四年，动加至德二字，号曰《冲虚至德真经》护左都水使者臣向姓刘，名向，字子正，汉楚元王交玄孙。 校定此书也。 校音教谨欤音与。
chunks.translated_text:
**Exegetical Commentary on the *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void***

**Title:** *Exegetical Commentary on the Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*
Authored by Duan Jingshun of the Tang, with supplements by Chen Jingyuan of the Song. Two scrolls.
Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Unity*, Cavernous Spirit Division, Jade Instructions Category.

---

**Preface to the *Exegetical Commentary on the Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void***

Before the birth of Zhuangzi, the Way of Liezi had already flowed boundless and formless, suffusing the Great Void without trace or sound. Thus, his writings elucidated the profound obscurities of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, dissecting the roots of life and death, stripping away concealments and unraveling entanglements, lancing boils and draining abscesses. His words spoke of spontaneity without self-awareness, of non-action while allowing all things to follow their course. His phrasing ranged freely, like withered leaves and dry husks, riding the wind east and west, drifting and admonishing between heaven and earth without limit.

Later, Zhuangzi frequently cited his words in discourses, and thus the world came to speak of "Lao-Zhuang" rather than "Lao-Lie." This is because Zhuangzi harmonized differences into unity, his meaning threading through all, distinguishing hardness and whiteness while embracing both being and non-being.

In the past, Liezi dwelled in seclusion in Putian for forty years, yet none recognized him; he concealed his form among the common folk, and even the lord of the state knew him not—such was his heavenly obscurity. A man may possess the Way yet receive no praise; how could the Way be trivial? A book may contain principle yet seldom be acknowledged; how could it be coarse? This man, this book—profound and distant, returning with things to their source—how lofty it is!

From my youth, I delighted in reading this work, yet suffered from the lack of phonetic glosses and explanations to resolve my confusions. In later years, while wandering beneath the watery canopy of Siming at Tongbai on Mount Tiantai, I obtained two tattered scrolls, their titles faintly marked as *Exegetical Commentary on Liezi*. The paper and ink were decayed, unfit for leisurely perusal, so I hastily transcribed them. Much was lost to moths and decay, obliterated and fragmented, with four or five parts in ten missing. Yet at the end of the scroll was inscribed: *"Compiled by Yin Jingshun, Vice Magistrate of Dangtu County, Tang; transcribed by Mo Xizi of Mount Heng."* I roughly copied and stored it in my satchel.

Later, on Mount Qian, I found a handwritten copy of *Liezi* by the Tang Daoist Xu Lingfu, along with Lu Chongxuan’s commentary preserved in a private collection. Comparing these with the printed edition from the Directorate of Education during the Jingde era, I collated discrepancies, noting variants and assembling a record of errors and divergences in one scroll, appended to the commentary. Subsequently, I filled lacunae and restored omissions, recovering the original order.

Among the finest explanations by earlier scholars was the identification of *cheng* (程) as a variant name for *biao* (豹), which in ancient script comprises the two characters *tai* (泰) and *bing* (丙). Such erudition and breadth of knowledge! Any oversights or omissions await the emendations and insights of like-minded scholars.

Written on the ninth day of the ninth month, second year of the Xining era, by Bixuzi.

---

**Exegetical Commentary on the *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*, Scroll One***
Compiled by Yin Jingshun, Vice Magistrate of Dangtu County, Tang
Supplemented by Chen Jingyuan, Bixuzi

**New Catalogue of *Liezi***

Surname: Lie. Given name: Yukou, or alternatively Yukou.
Preceding Zhuangzi, hence Zhuangzi’s references to him.
At the beginning of the Tianbao era, by imperial decree, he was enfeoffed as the Perfected of the Unfathomable Void, and his work was retitled *Classic of the Unfathomable Void*, its name heading the eight chapters.
This edition was compiled by Liu Xiang, who selected twenty chapters, removed redundancies, and titled it *New Book*.
In the fourth year of the Jingde era of the Great Song, the title was augmented with "Perfect Virtue," becoming *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*.
The collator, Liu Xiang, styled Zizheng, was a descendant of Liu Jiao, Prince Yuan of Chu during the Han.
Thus was this book collated and annotated. May the teachings of its sounds and meanings be revered!

chunks.original_text: 经中与字多如此作。 臣参七南切。 刘向《管子新书目录》云：臣参书四十一篇。 校雠音酬。 校，谓两本相对，履校也。 条谓如仇，条报也。 除复扶又切。 以尽子忍切。 极也，下同。 及在新书有栈音剪。 谓虫蠹断灭也。 略作刬，又作前，皆与剪子同。 《周礼》有剪氏，掌除虫鱼蠹书。 杀青谓汗简刮去青皮也。 郑缪公音穆。 与鲁哀公同时。 迂音于。 诞徒旱切。 迂诞，疏远之大言也。 恢口回切。 诡孔委切。 恢诡，大怪异之言也。 推分符问切。 乘背音佩孝景汉帝，讳启。 亦颇普可切。 偶言音遇。
chunks.translated_text:
Within the text, the character "与" frequently appears in this form.

臣参 (chén cān): pronounced as "seven" in the southern pronunciation.

Liu Xiang’s *Catalogue of the New Book of Guanzi* states: "The *Book of Minister Can* comprises forty-one chapters."

校雠 (jiào chóu): pronounced as "chou."
校 refers to comparing two texts, verifying through collation.
雠 means "like an enemy," signifying reciprocal verification.

除复 (chú fù): pronounced as "fu" in the "you" rhyme.
以尽 (yǐ jìn): pronounced as "jin" in the "zhi" rhyme, meaning "to exhaust"; the same applies below.

In the *New Book*, there is 栈 (zhàn), pronounced as "jian."
This refers to damage or destruction by bookworms.
Abbreviated as 刬 or written as 前, both equivalent to 剪 (jiǎn).

The *Rites of Zhou* includes the office of 剪氏, responsible for eliminating insects, fish, and bookworms.

杀青 (shā qīng) refers to scraping away the green skin of bamboo slips after drying.

郑缪公 (Zhèng Mù Gōng): pronounced as "Mu."
Contemporary with Duke Ai of Lu.

迂 (yū): pronounced as "yu."
诞 (dàn): pronounced as "tan" in the "han" rhyme.
迂诞 (yū dàn) denotes grandiose, exaggerated speech.

恢 (huī): pronounced as "hui" in the "hui" rhyme.
诡 (guǐ): pronounced as "wei" in the "wei" rhyme.
恢诡 (huī guǐ) refers to wildly strange or fantastical language.

推分 (tuī fèn): pronounced as "fen" in the "wen" rhyme.
乘背 (chéng bèi): pronounced as "pei."

孝景 (Xiào Jǐng), Emperor of Han, avoided the personal name "启" (Qǐ).

亦颇 (yì pō): pronounced as "po" in the "ke" rhyme.
偶言 (ǒu yán): pronounced as "yu."
chunks.overlap_context:
chapters.
This edition was compiled by Liu Xiang, who selected twenty chapters, removed redundancies, and titled it *New Book*.
In the fourth year of the Jingde era of the Great Song, the title was augmented with "Perfect Virtue," becoming *Classic of Perfect Virtue of the Unfathomable Void*.
The collator, Liu Xiang, styled Zizheng, was a descendant of Liu Jiao, Prince Yuan of Chu during the Han.
Thus was this book collated and annotated. May the teachings of its sounds and meanings be revered!

chunks.original_text: 刘向《别录》云：偶言者，作人姓名，使相与语。 《史记》读为寓。 列传列传，经之类。 皆音去声。 昧死上时掌切。 永始汉成帝年号。 湛闻之张湛，字处度，东晋光禄勋。 注此真经，刘正舆音余，晋扬州刺史，名陶。 傅颖根名敷，北地人，晋丞相从事中郎。 并少诗照切。 始周姓王，张湛祖之舅。 从兄从，疾用切。 正宗王宏，字正宗，高平人。 晋尚书。 辅嗣王弼，字辅嗣，山阳人。 魏尚书郎。 皆好呼报切。 先悉荐切。 下同。 并卑正切。 仲宣王柴，字仲宣，山阳人。 魏侍中。 几将音祈。 近也。 总角《诗》云总角胸兮。 谓童子结发之时也。 及长丁丈切。 避难乃但切。 各称尺证切。 寇虏音鲁尽全子忍切。 料简音聊。 理也，量也。 唯赍音跻。 祖玄父咸子集传玄，字休奕，北地人。 着子书，一百二十篇，有集五十卷。 咸字长威，有集二十卷。 父子俱为晋司隶校尉，鹑觚侯。 仅有音觐。 少也。
chunks.translated_text:
Liu Xiang’s *Bie Lu* states: "偶言 (*ǒu yán*) refers to composing names of persons and making them converse with one another." The *Records of the Grand Historian* reads it as 寓 (*yù*). "列传 (*liè zhuàn*)" and "列传" are categories of the classics, both pronounced in the departing tone.

昧死 (*mèi sǐ*): pronounced as "shang" in the "zhang" rhyme.
永始 (*Yǒng Shǐ*): reign title of Emperor Cheng of Han.
湛 (*Zhāng Zhàn*), styled Chudu, was a *Guanglu Xun* of the Eastern Jin. He annotated this *True Classic*.
刘正舆 (*Liú Zhèngyú*), pronounced as "Yu," was a Jin Governor of Yangzhou, named Tao.
傅颖根 (*Fù Yǐnggēn*), named Fu, was a native of Beidi and served as *Congshi Zhonglang* to the Jin Chancellor.
并少 (*bìng shào*): pronounced as "zhao" in the "xiao" rhyme.
始 (*Shǐ*): the Zhou royal surname was Wang; Zhang Zhan’s grandfather was his maternal uncle.
从兄 (*cóng xiōng*): "从" is pronounced as "yong" in the "yong" rhyme.
正宗 (*Zhèngzōng*): Wang Hong, styled Zhengzong, was a native of Gaoping and served as a Jin *Shangshu*.
辅嗣 (*Fǔsì*): Wang Bi, styled Fusi, was a native of Shanyang and served as a *Shangshu Lang* of Wei.
皆好 (*jiē hào*): pronounced as "bao" in the "bao" rhyme.
先 (*xiān*): pronounced as "xian" in the "jian" rhyme; same below.
并卑 (*bìng bēi*): pronounced as "zheng" in the "zheng" rhyme.
仲宣 (*Zhòngxuān*): Wang Can, styled Zhongxuan, was a native of Shanyang and served as *Shizhong* of Wei.
几将 (*jī jiāng*): pronounced as "qi"; means "nearly."
总角 (*zǒng jiǎo*): The *Book of Songs* says, "总角胸兮." It refers to the time when a child’s hair is tied up.
及长 (*jí zhǎng*): "长" is pronounced as "zhang" in the "zhang" rhyme.
避难 (*bì nàn*): "难" is pronounced as "tan" in the "tan" rhyme.
各称 (*gè chēng*): "称" is pronounced as "zheng" in the "zheng" rhyme.
寇虏 (*kòu lǔ*): pronounced as "lu"; "尽" is pronounced as "jin" in the "ren" rhyme.
料简 (*liào jiǎn*): pronounced as "liao"; means "to arrange" or "to measure."
唯赍 (*wéi jī*): pronounced as "ji."
祖玄 (*Zǔ Xuán*): Fu Xuan, styled Xiuyi, was a native of Beidi. He composed *Zi Shu* in 120 pian and had a collected works of 50 juan.
咸 (*Xián*), styled Changwei, had a collected works of 20 juan. Father and son both served as Jin *Sili Xiaowei* and were enfeoffed as *Chungu Hou*.
仅有 (*jǐn yǒu*): pronounced as "jin"; means "few."

chunks.original_text: 比乱必利切。 复在扶又切。 着物直略切。 自丧息浪切。 。 生觉音教。 肆任而鸩切。 此例稍多，复以意取之。 往往与佛经相参犹云佛经往往与列子相参。 此为文者，辞语互陈也。 属辞音烛庄子名周，字子休，宋人也。 为梁漆园吏。 着书五十二篇，郭象合为三十三篇以注之。 天宝初，册为南华真人，其书曰。 南华真经。 经中往往有冲虚真人之语。 慎到赵人也。 先申韩，申韩称之。 着书四十二篇，其学本师黄老。 韩非韩之诸公子。 使秦，李斯害而杀之。 着书五十五篇，其学本师黄者。 尸子名狡，音绞，鲁人。 秦相商君师之。 鞅死后，逃入蜀。 着书二十篇。 淮南子刘安，汉武孙，淮南厉王长子也。 招致宾客，作《内书》，二十一篇，多真经之语。 又《外书》三十三篇，论《新语》《玄示》道家有王龟胎中《玄示经》四十卷。 又陈留韩祉作《玄示》八篇，演解五千文。 《指归》汉严遵，字君平，作《指归》十四篇，演解五千文。 天瑞第一 夫音符。
chunks.translated_text:
"Bǐ luàn" is pronounced as "bì lì." "Fù zài" is pronounced as "fú yòu." "Zhuó wù" is pronounced as "zhí lüè." "Zì sàng" is pronounced as "xī làng." "Shēng jué" is pronounced as "jiào." "Sì rèn" is pronounced as "ér zhèn."

Such examples are somewhat numerous, and one must again infer their meaning contextually. These often intermingle with Buddhist scriptures, just as it is said that Buddhist scriptures frequently intermingle with the *Liezi*. This is how writers compose their words, with phrases and expressions mutually presented.

"Shǔ cí" is pronounced as "zhú." *Zhuangzi*, named Zhou, styled Zixiu, was a native of Song. He served as the magistrate of Liang’s Qiyuan. He authored a work in fifty-two pian, which Guo Xiang later compiled into thirty-three pian and annotated. In the early Tianbao era, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the Perfected of Nanhua, and his work was titled the *True Scripture of Nanhua*. Within this scripture, there are often passages attributed to the Perfected of Chongxu.

Shen Dao was a native of Zhao. He preceded Shen Buhai and Han Fei, who both esteemed him. He authored a work in forty-two pian, and his learning was rooted in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi.

Han Fei was a prince of Han. He was sent to Qin, where Li Si plotted against and killed him. He authored a work in fifty-five pian, and his learning was also rooted in the teachings of the Yellow Emperor.

Shizi, named Jiao (pronounced *jiǎo*), was a native of Lu. He was the teacher of Shang Yang, the Chancellor of Qin. After Yang’s death, he fled to Shu and authored a work in twenty pian.

The *Huainanzi*, Liu An, was the grandson of Emperor Wu of Han and the eldest son of Liu Chang, the Prince Li of Huainan. He gathered retainers and composed the *Inner Book* in twenty-one pian, which contains many passages from the *True Scripture*. He also wrote the *Outer Book* in thirty-three pian, discussing the *New Discourses* and the *Xuan Shi*. Among Daoist works, there is the *Scripture of Xuan Shi in the Womb* in forty juan by Wang Gui of Chenliu. Additionally, Han Zhi of Chenliu authored the *Xuan Shi* in eight pian, offering an expanded exegesis of the *Five Thousand Character Text*.

The *Zhigui*: Yan Zun of Han, styled Junping, authored the *Zhigui* in fourteen pian, providing an expanded exegesis of the *Five Thousand Character Text*.

"Tiān Ruì" is the first chapter. "Fū" is pronounced as "fú."

chunks.original_text: 是发语之端，后更不音。 舛错昌兖切。 之分符问切。 下同。 子列子冠子氏上者，着其为师也。 郑圃音补。 园田，郑之薮泽也。 今在荣阳中牟县。 所谒谒，诸也。 人无或作亡。 同音无。 胝古视字也。 行无下孟切。 壶丘子林司马彪注，《南华真经》云：名林，郑人也。 尝语一本作诏。 诏告也。 伯昏瞀人莫侯切。 后伯昏无人者。 亦音谋。 告女音汝。 块然口对切。 而复扶又切。 往复依字音。 服后不音者，皆是入声。 不殆音待。 《黄帝书》黄帝，姓公孙，名轩辕，得长生之道，在位一百年。 按汉书艺文志有《黄帝书》四篇，《黄帝君臣》一篇，《黄帝铭》六篇与道经相类。 玄牝毗忍切。 无景音影。
chunks.translated_text:
This marks the beginning of the introductory phrase, and no further pronunciation guides follow. *Chuǎncuò* is pronounced as "chāngyǎn." *Zhī* is pronounced as "fùwèn"—the same applies below.

In *Liezi* and *Guanzi*, the honorific "zi" (Master) precedes the surname, signifying their status as teachers. The *Zhengpu* is pronounced as "bǔ." It refers to gardens and fields, the marshes and wetlands of Zheng, now located in Zhongmou County of present-day Rongyang.

*Suǒ yè* means "all." *Wú* may also be written as *wáng*, pronounced identically. *Zhī* is an ancient form of the character *shì* (to see). *Xíng* is pronounced as "mèng."

Huqiu Zilin—according to Sima Biao’s commentary, the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence* states: his name was Lin, a native of Zheng. *Yǔ* may also be written as *zhào*, meaning "to instruct" or "to inform." Bohun Maoren is pronounced as "mòhóu"—later instances of Bohun Wuren may also be read as *móu*. *Gào nǚ* means "to tell you." *Kuàirán* is pronounced as "kǒuduì." *Ér fù* is pronounced as "fúyòu," while *wǎngfù* retains its standard pronunciation.

Characters that are not annotated with pronunciation hereafter are all entering-tone words. *Bù dài* is pronounced as "dài."

The *Book of the Yellow Emperor*: The Yellow Emperor, surnamed Gongsun and named Xuanyuan, attained the Dao of longevity and reigned for a hundred years. According to the *Yiwen zhi* in the *Book of Han*, there are four pian of the *Book of the Yellow Emperor*, one pian of *The Yellow Emperor and His Ministers*, and six pian of *Inscriptions of the Yellow Emperor*, all of which resemble Daoist scriptures. *Xuánpìn* is pronounced as "pírěn." *Wú yǐng* is pronounced as "yǐng."

The *Zhigui*: Yan Zun of Han, styled Junping, authored the *Zhigui* in fourteen pian, providing an expanded exegesis of the *Five Thousand Character Text*.

chunks.original_text: 绵绵武延切。 存邪以遮切。 下同。 向秀音饷。 字子期，晋常待。 注《南华真经》二十八篇。 自知音智。 下同。 赡群时艳切。 不匮音馈。 曷也。 大易音太。 下同。 未见贤遍切。 注同。 之称尺证切。 下同。 易击胡计切。 混成胡本切。 浑音魂沦音沦。 下同。 相离力智切。 去也。 或作平声读。 近曰离，远曰别。 后以意求之也。 别明彼列切。 离散先汗切。 卷内同。 循之音旬。 易无形哷《淮南子》作形埒。 谓兆朕也。 《乾凿度》作形畔。 今从乎者转谓，误也。 易变而为一自一经九，大衍之数。 惚音忽。 怳况往切。 以数色主切。 乃复古乃字。 上为时掌切。 所倚於绮切。 天地所否蒲鄙切。 塞也。 造余七到切。 则阂音碍所属音烛。 素分符问切。 下名分形分同。 焘育音蹈。 覆也。 贞粹音邃系於音计。 尝呈示见也。 能膻式连切。 道论卢困切。 恃无音市。 名之弥正切。 与诏同。 响许两切。 光景音影。 食於道徒司马彪云； 徒，道旁也。 一本或作从。 髑髅音独娄。 攓音蹇逢音蓬。 蒿也。 拔也皮八切。 过养古卧切。 实当丁浪切。 种章勇切。 有几居岂切。 若鼃户瓜切。 虾蟆也。 为鹑音淳。 事见贤遍切。 《墨子》《墨子》曰：夫物或有久，或无久，始当无久化，若鼃为鸡也。 得水为音计。 司马彪云：万物虽有兆朕，得水润之，气乃相继而生也。 鼃蠙步田切。 司马彪云：物根在水土际。 布在水中，就水上视之，不见钞之可得，如张绵在水中矣。 楚人谓之蝇蠙之衣。 陵屯音豚。 阜也。 结处昌据切。 下同。 陵舄音昔。 一名泽舄，随燥湿之变也。 郁栖粪壤也。 乌足草名也。 蛴螬郭注《尔雅》，云：在木中。 今虽通名为蝎，所在异。 胡蝶音楪。 即蛱蝶也。 蛱，音颊。 胥也《师说》云：胥少也。 谓少去时也。 生灶下得熟气生若脱他括切。 郭注《尔雅》云：脱谓剥皮也。 音衢。 掇丁括切。
chunks.translated_text: Mianmian is pronounced as *wǔyán*. *Cúnxié* is pronounced as *yǐzhē*. The same below. Xiang Xiu is pronounced as *xiǎng*. His courtesy name was Zǐqī, and he served as a *chángdài* in the Jin dynasty. He annotated the twenty-eight *pian* of the *Nanhua Zhenjing*. He possessed profound understanding of phonology. The same below. *Shànqún* is pronounced as *shíyàn*. *Búkuì* is pronounced as *kuì*. *Héyě*. *Dàyì* is pronounced as *tàiyì*. The same below. *Wèijiànxián* is pronounced as *biàn*. The annotation is the same. *Zhīchēng* is pronounced as *chǐzhèng*. The same below. *Yì* is pronounced as *hùjì*. *Hùnchéng* is pronounced as *húběn*. *Hún* is pronounced as *hún*; *lún* is pronounced as *lún*. The same below. *Xiānglí* is pronounced as *lìzhì*. It means "to depart." Some read it in the level tone. Near separation is called *lí*, while distant separation is called *bié*. Later, one must seek its meaning. *Bié* is pronounced as *bǐliè*. *Lísàn* is pronounced as *xiānhàn*. The same within this *juàn*. *Xúnzhī* is pronounced as *xún*. *Yìwúxíng*: The *Huainanzi* writes it as *xíngliè*. It refers to signs and omens. The *Qiánzáo Dù* writes it as *xíngpàn*. Following *hū* as a turning particle is an error. *Yìbiàn érwéiyī*: From one through nine, the number of the *tài yǎn*. *Hū* is pronounced as *hū*. *Huǎng* is pronounced as *kuàngwǎng*. *Yǐshù sèzhǔ* is pronounced as *sèzhǔ*. *Nǎifù* is an archaic form of *nǎi*. *Shàngwéi* is pronounced as *shízhǎng*. *Suǒyǐ* is pronounced as *yúqǐ*. *Tiāndì suǒpǐ* is pronounced as *púbǐ*. It means "blocked." *Zào* is pronounced as *qīdào*. *Zéhé* is pronounced as *ài*; *suǒshǔ* is pronounced as *zhú*. *Sùfēn* is pronounced as *fúwèn*. The same below for *míngfèn* and *xíngfèn*. *Tāoyù* is pronounced as *dào*. It means "to cover." *Zhēncuì* is pronounced as *suì*; *xìyú* is pronounced as *jì*. It means "to present and be seen." *Néngshān* is pronounced as *shílián*. *Dàolùn* is pronounced as *lúkùn*. *Shìwú* is pronounced as *shì*. *Míngzhī* is pronounced as *mízhèng*. It is the same as *zhào*. *Xiǎng* is pronounced as *xǔliǎng*. *Guāngjǐng* is pronounced as *yǐng*. Sima Biao said: *Tú* means "the side of the Way." One version writes it as *cóng*. *Dúlóu* is pronounced as *dúlóu*. *Qiān* is pronounced as *jiǎn*; *féng* is pronounced as *péng*. It means "mugwort" or "to pull out." *Bá* is pronounced as *pībā*. *Guòyǎng* is pronounced as *gǔwò*. *Shídàng* is pronounced as *dīnglàng*. *Zhǒng* is pronounced as *zhāngyǒng*. *Yǒujī* is pronounced as *jūqǐ*. *Ruòwā* is pronounced as *hùguā*. It refers to a toad. *Wéichún* is pronounced as *chún*. *Shìjiànxián* is pronounced as *biàn*. The *Mozi* states: "Among things, some endure long, while others do not. At the beginning, transformation occurs without duration, as when a toad becomes a quail." *Dé shuǐ wéi* is pronounced as *jì*. Sima Biao said: "Though the myriad things have signs and omens, only when moistened by water does their *qi* continue and give rise to life." *Wāpín* is pronounced as *bùtián*. Sima Biao said: "The roots of things lie at the boundary of water and soil. Spread in water, when viewed from above, they cannot be grasped, like silk floss submerged in water." The people of Chu call it the "garment of the *yíngpín*." *Língtún* is pronounced as *tún*. It means "mound." *Jiéchù* is pronounced as *chāngjù*. The same below. *Língxì* is pronounced as *xī*. It is also called *zéxì*, changing with moisture and dryness. *Yùqī* refers to dung and soil. *Wūzú* is the name of a grass. *Qícáo*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "It dwells within wood." Though now commonly called a scorpion, its habitat differs. *Húdié* is pronounced as *dié*. It is the *jiádié*. *Jiá* is pronounced as *jiá*. *Xū*: The *Shī Shuō* states: "*Xū* means 'little.'" It refers to the brief time of departure. *Shēng zào xià dé shú qì shēng ruò tuō*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "*Tuō* means 'to peel.'" *Qú* is pronounced as *qú*. *Duō* is pronounced as *dīngkuò*.

ronounced as "dài."

The *Book of the Yellow Emperor*: The Yellow Emperor, surnamed Gongsun and named Xuanyuan, attained the Dao of longevity and reigned for a hundred years. According to the *Yiwen zhi* in the *Book of Han*, there are four pian of the *Book of the Yellow Emperor*, one pian of *The Yellow Emperor and His Ministers*, and six pian of *Inscriptions of the Yellow Emperor*, all of which resemble Daoist scriptures. *Xuánpìn* is pronounced as "pírěn." *Wú yǐng* is pronounced as "yǐng."
