chunks.original_text: 掇，虫名。 乾余胥之沫音末。 《南华真经》作骨。 李颐云：沬，口中汁也。 斯弥虫名，食酰许兮切。 苦酒，上蠛蠓也。 亦日酰鸡。 下伺。 颐辂上怡，下路。 黄軦音况。 颐軦。 黄軦，皆虫也。 九猷李云：九当作久。 久老也。 猷，虫名。 瞥茂谋二音。 茵音蚋。 小虫也，喜去乱飞。 腐音辅。 蠸音权，一音欢。 谓瓜中黄甲虫也。 地皋音高。 顾胤《汉书集解》云：如淤泥。 辅邻《说文》作磷，又作磷。 皆鬼火也。 《淮南子》云：血为磷也。 音吝。 鹞音濯。 之为鹯音毡鹯之为布毂木又作壳。 陆机《毛诗鸟兽疏》云：鹤似鹯，黄毛，鸡头，仓身，皆相似。 其飞急疾，取鸠鸽燕雀食之。 布谷，鴶鵴也，一名尸鸠，一名击谷，一名乘鸠，仲春雀。 鹞鹰鹯之化为鹞也。 音掬。 燕之为蛤音合。 《家语》云：冬则燕雀入海化为蛤。 燕或作雀。 《周书》云：雀入大水化为蛤。 田鼠之为鹑音淳。 与鼃化同。 《说文》云：鹑，鹞也。 《大戴礼》，三月田鼠化为鹌。 《周书》云：化驾。 郭注《尔雅》云：驾亦鹌也。 鹌，音谙。 驾音如。 瓜音朽。 老韭举有切。 为莞音官。 似蒲而圆，今之为席是也。 杨承庆《字统》：音阏。 。 一作苋，侯辨切。 转写误也。 老羭音俞。 牝羊也。 又黑羊也。 为猨音猿。 鱼卵来短切。 亶爰上蝉，下袁。 如狸力之切。 而有髦音毛。 垂发也。 牝毗忍切。 牡音某。 鶂五历切。 三苍云：鸧鶂也。 司马彪云：鸟子也。 眸子音谋。 名穉古稚字也。 蜂音丰。 司马彪云：稚蜂细股者，取桑虫祝之。 使似己之子也。 而孕以证切。
chunks.translated_text: The *qúduō* is the name of an insect. *Gān yúxū*’s foam is pronounced *mò*. The *Nanhua Zhenjing* writes it as "bone." Li Yi states: "*Mèi* is the juice in the mouth." *Sīmí* is the name of an insect that feeds on vinegar, pronounced *xǐ xī*. *Kǔjiǔ* is the upper *mièměng*. It is also called *xī jī*. The lower is *sì*. *Yí lù*: the upper is *yí*, the lower *lù*. The *huáng kuàng*, pronounced *kuàng*, and *yí kuàng* are all insects. *Jiǔ yóu*: Li states: "*Jiǔ* should be *jiǔ*, meaning 'long-lived.'" *Yóu* is the name of an insect. *Piē mào* has two pronunciations: *móu*. *Yīn*, pronounced *ruì*, is a small insect that delights in flying about in swarms. *Fǔ*, pronounced *fǔ*. The *quán*, pronounced *quán* or *huān*, refers to the yellow beetle in melons. *Dì gāo*, pronounced *gāo*: Gu Yin’s *Hanshu Jijie* states it is like mud. Fu Lin’s *Shuowen* writes it as *lín*, and also as *lìn*, both referring to ghostly fire. The *Huainanzi* states: "Blood becomes *lìn*." Pronounced *lìn*. The *yào*, pronounced *zhuó*, becomes the *zhān*, pronounced *zhān*. The *zhān* becomes the *bù gǔ* tree, also written as *ké*. Lu Ji’s *Maoshi Niaoshou Shu* states: "The crane resembles the *zhān*, with yellow feathers, a chicken’s head, and a gray body, all similar. It flies swiftly and preys on turtledoves, pigeons, swallows, and sparrows." The *bùgǔ* is the *jiájú*, also called *shī jiū*, *jī gǔ*, *chéng jiū*, and the "mid-spring sparrow." The *yào* hawk and *zhān* transform into the *yào*. Pronounced *jū*. The swallow becomes the clam, pronounced *gé*. The *Jia Yu* states: "In winter, swallows and sparrows enter the sea and transform into clams." *Yàn* may also be written as *què*. The *Zhou Shu* states: "Sparrows enter great waters and transform into clams." The field mouse becomes the quail, pronounced *chún*. This transformation is the same as that of the frog. The *Shuowen* states: "The quail is the *yào*." The *Da Dai Li* states: "In the third month, the field mouse transforms into the *ān*." The *Zhou Shu* states: "It transforms into the *jià*." Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "*Jià* is also the *ān*." *Ān*, pronounced *ān*; *jià*, pronounced *rú*. The *xiǔ guā*, pronounced *xiǔ*, is old leeks, pronounced *jǔ yǒu*. They become the *guān*, pronounced *guān*, which resembles bulrush but is round; it is what is now used to make mats. Yang Chengqing’s *Zitong* states it is pronounced *è*. It is also written as *xiàn*, pronounced *hóu biàn*, a scribal error. The old *yú*, pronounced *yú*, is a female sheep, or a black sheep. It becomes the *yuán*, pronounced *yuán*. Fish roe is pronounced *lái duǎn*. *Dǎn yuán*: the upper is *chán*, the lower *yuán*. It resembles the *lí*, pronounced *lì*, but has *máo*, pronounced *máo*, meaning hanging hair. The female is pronounced *pí rěn*; the male, *mǒu*. The *yì*, pronounced *wǔ lì*: The *San Cang* states it is the *cāng yì*. Sima Biao states it is the young of birds. The pupil is pronounced *móu*. *Zhì* is an ancient form of *zhì*. The bee, pronounced *fēng*: Sima Biao states that the young bee with slender legs takes the silkworm, prays over it, and makes it resemble its own offspring. It then becomes pregnant, pronounced *zhèng*.
chunks.overlap_context: is the name of a grass. *Qícáo*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "It dwells within wood." Though now commonly called a scorpion, its habitat differs. *Húdié* is pronounced as *dié*. It is the *jiádié*. *Jiá* is pronounced as *jiá*. *Xū*: The *Shī Shuō* states: "*Xū* means 'little.'" It refers to the brief time of departure. *Shēng zào xià dé shú qì shēng ruò tuō*: Guo’s annotation to the *Erya* states: "*Tuō* means 'to peel.'" *Qú* is pronounced as *qú*. *Duō* is pronounced as *dīngkuò*.

chunks.original_text: 好而呼报切。 后稷长丁丈切。 注同也。 臼水音舅，有莘疏臻切。 婴儿或作缨非。 汤相息亮切。 厥昭曾子云：孤藜一名厥昭，恒翔绕其木，不能离之。 《师说》云：孤藜，蜻蛉虫也。 蜻岭，音青零。 生乎湿失入切。 因蒸音证。 酰鸡蠛蚝也。 羊奚比音毗。 乎不笋音笋。 久竹生青宁《南华真经》从羊奚至青宁，连为一句。 司马彪云：羊奚，草名，根似燕菁，与久竹比合，皆生非类。 青宁，虫名也。 生程《尸子》云：程，中国谓之豹，越人谓之貘。 按《 尔雅》 熊虎陇其子豹。 豹，熊虎之子也。 《山海经》云：南山多模豹。 郭注云：貘是豹之白者。 豹即虎生，非类也。 据程是貘之别名也。 按貘似熊，毛又黄而黑有光泽者，模音陌。 马生人《搜神记》云：秦孝公时，有马生人。 刘向以为马祸。 生响许两切。 后同。 响应於证切。 不复扶又切。 之称尺证切。 偕终音皆料音聊。 终进音尽。 下同。 虚谟音莫。 故迭音篆不久音有。 不生者先有悉荐切。 下同。 而复扶又切。 画其胡参切。 计策也。 一本作尽。 於义不长。 精神者天之久音有。 下同。 作篆文与久字相类。 按《汉书》杨玉孙曰：精神者，天之有； 骨骸者，地之有。 玉孙常读此经。 今国子监本作分。 本较音角。 少壮寿照切。 下同。 老耄莫报切。 气飘音漂。 德殷正也。 一本作故。 与争音诤。 间古苋切。 隔也。 大山音泰。 乎郕音成。 鲁之邑名。 带索先各切。 为乐音络。 下同。 之别彼列切。 定分扶问切。 故复扶又切。 襁居两切。 保本或作衬褓。 《博物志》云：织缕为之，广八寸，长尺二，以约小儿於背上，林类音泪。 或本作颖者，误认。 底春都礼切。 被裘音备。 遗穗音遂。 故畦音携。 裙之居运切并歌蒲浪切。 下同。 谓旁畦而行。 彼叟西口切。 有试往讯之音信。 一本无有字。 之垄力踵切。 曾不音曾不辍丁劣切。 止也。 叩之丘候切。 而应於证切。 少不诗照切。 勤行下孟切。 下同。 长不丁文切。 下同。 何乐音洛。 能寿音受。 恶乌路切。 不愈音舆以告古沃切。 下章同。 卒然仓没切。 造极七到切。 去彼丘吕切。 许处昌据切。 於厌於艳切。 其圹音旷。 墓穴也。 荀卿有此篇。 睪如音皋宰如言如冢宰也。 坟如如坟墓也。 鬲如音历。 形如鼎又音隔。 伏焉荀卿作休焉。 乐天音洛。 下同。
chunks.translated_text:
Here the text unfolds thus:

*hào* is pronounced *hū bào*. Hou Ji is read *zhǎng dīng*. The note says "same as." *Jiù* is water, pronounced *shuǐ jiù*; *Yǒu shēn* is read *shū zhēn*. "Infant" is sometimes written *yīng*, which is incorrect. Tang’s minister is pronounced *xī liàng*. *Jué zhāo*: Master Zengzi says it is *gū lí*, also called *jué zhāo*, which constantly circles its tree and cannot leave it. The *Shī Shuō* states: *gū lí* is the dragonfly. *Qīng líng* is pronounced *qīng líng*. It is born in dampness, pronounced *shī shī*. Through steaming, pronounced *zhēng*. *Xī jī* are *miè hào*. *Yáng xī* is read *bǐ*. *Hū bù* is bamboo shoot, pronounced *sǔn*. For long, bamboo gives birth to *qīng níng*—the *Nán Huá Zhēn Jīng* takes "from *yáng xī* to *qīng níng*" as one phrase. Sima Biao says: *Yáng xī* is a plant whose root resembles *yàn jīng*; when paired with old bamboo, they grow as unlike kinds. *Qīng níng* is the name of an insect.

*Shēng chéng*: The *Shī Zǐ* says: In the Central States it is called *bào*; the people of Yue call it *mò*. According to the *Ěr Yǎ*, the young of bear and tiger is *bào*. *Bào* is the offspring of bear and tiger. The *Shān Hǎi Jīng* says: In the southern mountains there are many *mó bào*. Guo’s note says: *Mò* is the white *bào*. *Bào* is born of tiger, an unlike kind. Thus *chéng* is another name for *mò*. Now *mò* resembles a bear, its fur yellow-black and lustrous—*mó* is pronounced *mò*. "Horse gives birth to man": The *Sōu Shén Jì* says: In the time of Duke Xiao of Qin, a horse gave birth to a man. Liu Xiang took it as a horse omen.

*Shēng xiǎng* is pronounced *xǔ liǎng*. Later the same. *Xiǎng yìng* is pronounced *yū zhèng*. "No longer" is read *fú yòu*. *Zhī chēng* is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. "Together to the end" is read *xié zhōng*; *liào* is pronounced *liáo*. "Advancing to the end" is read *zhōng jìn*. Below the same. *Xū mó* is pronounced *mò*. "Thus alternating" is read *dié*; "not long" is pronounced *bù jiǔ*. "Those not born" are first pronounced *xī jiàn*. Below the same. "And again" is read *fú yòu*. "Mark its" is pronounced *hú cān*—meaning strategy. One version writes "exhaust." This does not extend the meaning.

"That of spirit is Heaven’s *jiǔ*" is pronounced *yǒu*. Below the same. Written in seal script, it resembles the character for "long." According to the *Hàn Shū*, Yang Yùsūn said: "That of spirit is Heaven’s *yǒu*; that of bones and frame is Earth’s *yǒu*." Yùsūn often read this scripture. Now the Guozijian edition writes *fēn*. The root is pronounced *jiǎo*.

"Youth and strength" is read *shòu zhào*. Below the same. "Old and infirm" is pronounced *mào bào*. *Qì* drifts, pronounced *piāo*. *Dé* is flourishing, pronounced *yīn zhèng*. One version writes "thus." "Contend" is pronounced *zhēng*. *Jiàn* is pronounced *gǔ xiàn*—meaning separation. "Great mountain" is pronounced *tài*. *Hū chéng* is pronounced *chéng*—a city of Lu. "With rope" is pronounced *xiān gè*. "For joy" is read *lè*. Below the same. "Its distinction" is pronounced *bǐ liè*. "Fixed share" is read *fú wèn*. "Thus again" is read *fú yòu*. *Qiǎng* is pronounced *jū liǎng*. "Protect" originally was written *chèn bǎo*. The *Bó Wù Zhì* says: It is woven of thread, eight inches wide, twelve inches long, used to bind the infant to the back—*lín lèi* is pronounced *lèi*. Some write *yǐng*, a misrecognition.

"Base" is pronounced *dū lǐ*. "Wearing furs" is read *bèi*. "Forgotten grain" is pronounced *suì*. "Thus the furrow" is read *xī*. "Skirt" is pronounced *jū yùn*; *pú làng* is read *pú làng*. Below the same. It means walking beside the furrow. "That old man" is pronounced *xī kǒu*. "Have you tried going to ask him?" is read *yǒu shì wǎng xùn zhī*. One version omits "have." "His ridge" is pronounced *lǒng*. "Never" is read *céng bù chuò*—*dīng liè* means "to stop." "Knock on it" is pronounced *kòu zhī*. And it responds, pronounced *yū zhèng*. "Youth does not" is read *shào bù shī zhào*. "Diligent practice" is pronounced *qín xíng*; below the same, *xià mèng*. "Age does not" is read *zhǎng bù dīng wén*. Below the same. "What joy" is pronounced *hé lè*. "Can long life" is read *néng shòu*. "Dislike" is pronounced *wù*. "Not better" is read *bù yù*—*yǐ gào* is pronounced *gǔ wò*. The next chapter the same. "Suddenly" is pronounced *cāng mò*. "Reaching the limit" is read *zào jí*. "Leave that" is pronounced *qū bǐ*. "Permitted place" is read *xǔ chǔ*. "In loathing" is pronounced *yū yàn*. "Its grave" is read *qì kuàng*—meaning tomb pit. Xun Qing has this chapter.

*Yì rú* is pronounced *gāo*; *zǎi rú* means "like the prime minister." *Fén rú* means "like a grave mound." *Lì rú* is pronounced *lì*—its shape like a tripod, also pronounced *gé*. "Resting here" is written by Xun Qing as "resting here." "Joy of Heaven" is pronounced *lè*. Below the same.

The *yì*, pronounced *wǔ lì*: The *San Cang* states it is the *cāng yì*. Sima Biao states it is the young of birds. The pupil is pronounced *móu*. *Zhì* is an ancient form of *zhì*. The bee, pronounced *fēng*: Sima Biao states that the young bee with slender legs takes the silkworm, prays over it, and makes it resemble its own offspring. It then becomes pregnant, pronounced *zhèng*.

chunks.original_text: 去丘吕切。 离力智切。 昧然音妹。 之惫蒲界切。 疲也。 之佚音逸。 晏子齐大夫晏婴。 乐生音洛。 恶死鸟路切。 慎行下孟切。 无厌一盐切。 之徼音叫。 人才音哉。 下同。 种贤世音重形。 生名誉余据切。 跨张口花切。 知已音以。 所去丘吕切。 注同。 为寤音悟。 去彼丘吕切。 破音毁。 亏丧息浪切。 粥音育。 熊周文王师，封於楚，着子书二十二篇。 亡已音无以。 操七刀切。 随世音生。 下同。 省上声。 进音尽。 所瞩音烛。 一本作瞻。 自世音生。 杞音起。 国系本云：殷汤封夏后于杞。 周又封之。 今在陈留雍丘县。 武德年曾置杞州地是也。 崩隧音坠。 星宿音秀。 下同。 胜音升。
chunks.translated_text: "Leave that" is pronounced *qū bǐ*. "Separate" is read *lí*. "Dimly" is pronounced *mèi rán*. *Zhī bèi* is read *pú jiè*—meaning fatigue. *Zhī yì* is pronounced *yì*. Yanzi was a great minister of Qi, Yan Ying. "Joy of life" is pronounced *lè*. "Dislike death" is read *wù*. "Prudent conduct" is pronounced *shèn xíng*. "No satiation" is read *wú yàn*. *Zhī jiǎo* is pronounced *jiào*. "Human talent" is read *rén cái*. Below the same. "Lineage of worthies" is pronounced *zhǒng xián shì*. "Born to fame" is read *shēng míng yù*. "Straddle" is pronounced *kuà*. "Know oneself" is read *zhī jǐ*. "That which is left" is pronounced *suǒ qù*—the annotation same as above. "Awakening" is read *wù*. "Leave that" is pronounced *qù bǐ*. "Shatter" is read *pò huǐ*. "Loss and ruin" is pronounced *kuī sàng*. "Congee" is read *zhōu*. Xiong was the teacher of King Wen of Zhou, enfeoffed in Chu, and authored twenty-two chapters in the *Zi Shu*. "Gone already" is pronounced *wú yǐ*. "Grasp" is read *cāo*. "Follow the world" is pronounced *suí shì*. Below the same. "Reflect" is read in the upper tone. "Advance" is pronounced *jìn*. "That which is gazed upon" is read *suǒ zhǔ*—one version writes *瞻 (zhān)*. "From the world" is pronounced *zì shì*. Qi is read *qǐ*. The *Guo Xi Ben* states: "King Tang of Yin enfeoffed the Xia successor in Qi. The Zhou later enfeoffed it again. Today it lies in Yongqiu County of Chenliu, where the *Wude* era once established Qi Prefecture." "Collapse" is read *bēng suì*. "Constellations" are pronounced *xīng xiù*. Below the same. "Triumph" is read *shèng*.

chunks.original_text: 中伤丁仲切。 块口对切。 充塞苏则切。 躇音除。 步跐音此。 蹈徒到切。 四字皆践踏之貌。 人舍音释。 下同。 长庐子《史记》云：楚有长庐子。 《汉书》云：长庐子着书九篇，属道家流。 虹睨音红倪。 之最子外切。 大远音泰。 偕全音皆。 之见贤徧切。 何处昌据切。 舜问乎丞谓辅弼疑丞之官。 一本作烝。 有夫音符。 重柱用切。 下同。 蜕音税。 复扶又切。 向氏音响。 大壤如掌切。 又作复。 施及以智切。 延也。 亡不音无。 下同。 以脏音臧。 先居悉荐切。 曰嘻音熙。 衰痛之声。 吾盗天地之时利句绝。 之滂普郎切。 筑音竹。 吾垣音袁。 植时职切。 鳖并列切。 施尸智切。 罔文两切。 过东郭音戈。 一作遇字。 离力智切。 仞而音刃。 称尺证切。 复扶又切。 为吾于伪切。 藏才浪切。 大虚音泰。 吝良刃切。 所厝音措。 黄帝第二 养正音性。 燋然音焦。 肌色一作颜色。 皯古早切。 黣音每诸书无此字。
chunks.translated_text:
"Injury" is read *dīng zhòng*. "Clod" is pronounced *kuài*. "Filled and blocked" is read *sū zé*. "Tread" is pronounced *chú*. "Step falteringly" is read *bù cǐ*. "Trample" is pronounced *tú dào*. These four words all describe the appearance of treading.

"Human dwelling" is read *rén shè*. Below the same.

Changlu Zi: The *Records of the Historian* states: "There was a Changlu Zi in Chu." The *Book of Han* states: "Changlu Zi authored nine chapters, belonging to the Daoist school."

"Rainbow" is read *hóng nì*. "To the utmost" is pronounced *zhī zuì*. "Great distance" is read *dà yuǎn*. "Together complete" is pronounced *xié quán*. "To see" is read *zhī xiàn*. "Where" is pronounced *chǎng jù*.

Shun asked Yu Cheng (a term for an assisting minister; one version writes *zhēng*). "There is" is read *yǒu fū*. "Heavy pillar" is pronounced *zhòng zhù*. Below the same. "Molt" is read *tuì*. "Return" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Xiang clan" is read *xiàng shì*. "Great earth" is pronounced *rú zhǎng*. One version writes *復 (fù)*. "Extend" is read *yǐ zhì*—meaning "to prolong."

"Without fail" is read *wáng bù*. Below the same. "With organs" is pronounced *yǐ zàng*. "First reside" is read *xiān jū*. "Said 'Alas'" is pronounced *yuē xī*—the sound of grief and sorrow. "I steal the timely benefits of Heaven and Earth" ends the sentence.

"Flow abundantly" is read *zhī pāng*. "Build" is pronounced *zhú*. "My wall" is read *wú yuán*. "Plant" is pronounced *shí zhí*. "Turtle" is read *biē*. "Extend" is pronounced *shī zhì*. "Net" is read *wǎng wén*. "Pass Dongguo" is read *guò dōng guō*—one version writes *遇 (yù)*. "Separate" is pronounced *lí*. "Ren (unit of measure)" is read *rèn ér*. "Weigh" is pronounced *chēng*. "Return" is read *fú yòu*. "For me" is pronounced *wéi wú*. "Store" is read *cáng*. "Great void" is pronounced *dà xū*. "Stingy" is read *lìn*. "Place" is pronounced *suǒ cuò*.

**Yellow Emperor, Second Chapter**
"Nurture the true" is read *yǎng zhèng*. "Scorched" is pronounced *jiāo rán*. "Complexion" is written as *肌色 (jī sè)*—one version writes *颜色 (yán sè)*. "Wrinkled" is read *gǎn*. *Měi* (黣) has no entry in other texts.
chunks.overlap_context: tone. "Advance" is pronounced *jìn*. "That which is gazed upon" is read *suǒ zhǔ*—one version writes *瞻 (zhān)*. "From the world" is pronounced *zì shì*. Qi is read *qǐ*. The *Guo Xi Ben* states: "King Tang of Yin enfeoffed the Xia successor in Qi. The Zhou later enfeoffed it again. Today it lies in Yongqiu County of Chenliu, where the *Wude* era once established Qi Prefecture." "Collapse" is read *bēng suì*. "Constellations" are pronounced *xīng xiù*. Below the same. "Triumph" is read *shèng*.

chunks.original_text: 埤苍作□同，音每，谓木伤雨而生黑斑点也。 皯黣，亦然也。 不治直吏切。 下致治同。 进治音尽。 赞曰音叹。 过淫音深。 舍宫音舍。 去直丘吕切。 钟县音玄。 间居音闲。 齐心音斋。 下同。 弇州音奄。 几千居岂切。 无帅所类切。 或作师。 长丁文切。 师长，首主也。 嗜欲常二切。 亲已音纪。 知背音佩。 斫挞音酌。 挞，打也。 指擿音倜搔也。 无痟音消。 痒余两切。 痟痒，谓疼痒也。 《周礼》春时有痛首疾，夏时有痒疥疾。 郑玄云：痟，酸削也。 《说文》：云：酸疼痛也见周贤遍切。 不碍五盖切。 雷霆音廷。
chunks.translated_text:
"Pīcāng" writes □ as the same character, pronounced *měi*, referring to trees damaged by rain that develop black speckles. *Gǎn* and *měi* are likewise.

"Not govern" is pronounced *zhí lì*. Below, "bring order" is the same. "Advance governance" is pronounced *jìn*. "Eulogy" is read *tàn*. "Excessive indulgence" is pronounced *shēn*. "Abandon the palace" is read *shě*. "Depart" is pronounced *zhí qiū lǚ*. "Bell suspension" is read *xuán*. "Dwell in seclusion" is pronounced *xián*. "Unite the heart" is read *zhāi*—same below. "Yǎnzhōu" is pronounced *yǎn*. "*Jī* (几)" is read *jū qǐ*. "Without leader" is pronounced *shuài suǒ lèi*—one version writes *师 (shī)*. "Elder" is pronounced *dīng wén*. "Teacher and elder" means the head and master.

"Desire" is pronounced *cháng èr*. "Intimacy" is read *jǐ*. "Know the back" is pronounced *pèi*. "Hew and strike" is read *zhuó*. "*Tà* (挞)" means to beat. "Point and scratch" is pronounced *tì sāo*. "Without *xiāo*" is read *xiāo*. "Itch" is pronounced *yú liǎng*. "*Xiāo* and itch" refer to pain and itching. The *Rites of Zhou* states: in spring, there is the ailment of head pain; in summer, there are the ailments of itching and scabies. Zheng Xuan says: "*Xiāo* means sour and emaciated." The *Shuowen* states: "Sourness is pain." Pronounced *zhōu xián biàn*.

"Not obstruct" is pronounced *wǔ gài*. "Thunder" is read *tíng*.

**Yellow Emperor, Second Chapter**
"Nurture the true" is read *yǎng zhèng*. "Scorched" is pronounced *jiāo rán*. "Complexion" is written as *肌色 (jī sè)*—one version writes *颜色 (yán sè)*. "Wrinkled" is read *gǎn*. *Měi* (黣) has no entry in other texts.

chunks.original_text: 不滑音骨。 不踬音致。 怡然与之切。 大音泰。 山稽音鸡《汉书》云：大山稽，黄帝师也。 帝相息亮切。 疲而睡句绝。 二十有八年一本作三十有八年。 大治直吏切。 几若音祈。 假音遐。 号之户刀切。 列姑射音夜。 山在海河洲中。 《山海经》曰：姑射国在海中，西南环之，从国。 南水行百里，曰姑射之山，又西南行三百八十里，曰姑射山，郭云：河水所经海上也，言遥望诸姑射山，行列在海河之问也。 按《西域传》：黄河东注蒲昌海，潜行地下，入中国蒲昌海。 一名盐泽，在交河郡。 见山贤遍切。 上有神人此章与《山海经》略同。 吸风许及切。 岂复扶又切。 渊泉上字读为深字。 自粹音邃。 不偎乌恢切。 爱也。 不爱不偎不爱，，谓或隐或见。 《山海经》曰：北海之隅，其人水居。 偎爱，隐偎也。 《字林》云：偎仿佛见不审也。 愿音愿。 殷口角切。 无愆本又作骞，去言切。 常钧音均。 札伤侧八切。 郑众注。 《周礼》云：越人名死为札。 《左传》曰：人不夭札。 疵才移切。 病也。 厉音例。 郑众注《周礼》云：厉，风气不和之疾也。 灵向音响。 进音尽。
chunks.translated_text:
"Unsmooth" is pronounced *bù gǔ*. "Not stumble" is read *bù zhì*. "Cheerful" is pronounced *yí rán yǔ zhī qiè*. "Great" is read *dà*. "Mountain *jī*" is pronounced *shān jī*. The *Book of Han* states: "Great Mountain *Jī* was the teacher of the Yellow Emperor." "*Dì Xiāng*" is pronounced *xī liàng*. "Weary and sleep" forms a complete phrase.

Twenty-eight years—one version writes thirty-eight years. "Great governance" is pronounced *dà zhì*. "Almost like" is read *jī ruò*. "Borrow" is pronounced *jiǎ*. "Cry out" is read *hào zhī hù dāo qiè*. "Mountain of Liegu Ye" is pronounced *liè gū yè*. The mountain lies amid the sea and rivers. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "The state of Guye lies in the sea; to its west and south, it is encircled by the state. Sailing southward a hundred *li*, one reaches Mount Guye; proceeding another three hundred eighty *li* southwest, one reaches Mount Guye." Guo Pu notes: "It is where the river waters traverse the sea, speaking of gazing afar at the various Guye mountains, arrayed between the sea and rivers."

According to the *Account of the Western Regions*: "The Yellow River flows eastward into the Puchang Sea, then courses underground to enter the Central States." The Puchang Sea is also called the Salt Marsh, located in Jiaohé Prefecture. "Appear" is pronounced *xiàn shān xián biàn*.

Above dwell divine beings—this passage is largely the same as the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. "Inhale wind" is pronounced *xī fēng xǔ jí qiè*. "How could" is read *qǐ fù*. The first character of "deep spring" is read as "deep." "Pure" is pronounced *zì suì*. "Not cling" is read *bù wēi wū huī qiè*. "Love" also. "Not love, not cling" means sometimes hidden, sometimes visible. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "At the northern sea’s edge, its people dwell in water." "*Wēi* and love" mean concealed affection. The *Character Forest* states: "*Wēi* means vaguely seen, not clearly."

"Wish" is pronounced *yuàn*. "Abundant" is read *yǐn kǒu jiǎo qiè*. "Without fault" is originally written as *qiān*, pronounced *qù yán qiè*. "Constant balance" is read *cháng jūn*. "Premature death" is pronounced *zhá shāng cè bā qiè*. Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "The Yue people call death *zhá*." The *Zuozhuan* says: "People do not die prematurely." "Flaw" is pronounced *cī cái yí qiè*. "Illness" also. "Epidemic" is read *lì*. Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "*Lì* is illness caused by disharmonious wind and qi." "Spirit" is pronounced *líng xiàng*. "Advance" is read *jìn*.

The *Rites of Zhou* states: in spring, there is the ailment of head pain; in summer, there are the ailments of itching and scabies. Zheng Xuan says: "*Xiāo* means sour and emaciated." The *Shuowen* states: "Sourness is pain." Pronounced *zhōu xián biàn*.

"Not obstruct" is pronounced *wǔ gài*. "Thunder" is read *tíng*.

chunks.original_text: 下同。 泠然青零。 寇称尺证切。 数色主切。 下同。 不省息井切。 因闲音闲。 蕲音祈。 怼音坠。 怨也。 又不与命一本无与字。 女音汝。 曩章载乃朗切。 章载，字载，则一本作章戴。 有憾胡绀切。 脱然土活切。 此乎本又作于。 姬音居。 女音汝。 眄音□。 斜□。 从心音纵。 下同。 庚音更，居行切。 益也。 下同。 於匿一本作已。 道契苦计切。 横去声，下同。 纵放也。 未造七到切。 所倚於绮切。 干音乾。 壳口角切。 曾音层未。 浃时子协切。 可几音冀。 甚怍音昨。 屏息屏气似不息也。 复言扶又切。 关尹关令尹喜，字公度，着书九篇。 潜行或作渐，亦音潜。 不空一本作窒，塞也。 为阂音碍。 不栗音栗。 列音例。 姬音居。 鱼音吾。 语鱼据切。 女音汝。 相远于万切。 之造音作臧祚切。 注同。 者焉於虔切。 深音淫。 见贤遍切。 养其气一本作真其气。 造七到切。 至也。
chunks.translated_text:
Below, the same applies.

Cool and verdant, drifting down.

*Kòu* is pronounced *chǐ zhèng qiè*. *Shù* is read *sè zhǔ qiè*. Below, the same applies.

"Not perceiving" is read *bù xǐng xī jǐng qiè*. "By means of leisure" is pronounced *yīn xián*. *Qí* is read *qí*. *Duì* is pronounced *zhuì*, meaning "resentment." Alternatively, "not with fate"—one version omits the character *with*. *Nǚ* is read *rǔ*. *Nǎng zhāng zǎi* is pronounced *nǎi lǎng qiè*. *Zhāng zǎi* is the given name *Zǎi*; another version writes it as *Zhāng Dài*. "Regret" is read *hàn hú gàn qiè*. "Released" is pronounced *tuō rán tǔ huó qiè*. Here, *hū* is alternatively written as *yú*. *Jī* is read *jū*. *Nǚ* is pronounced *rǔ*. *Miǎn* is read *□*, meaning "sidelong glance." *Cóng xīn* is pronounced *zòng*, meaning "indulgence." Below, the same applies. *Gēng* is read *gēng*, pronounced *jū xíng qiè*, meaning "increase." Below, the same applies. *Yū nì* is alternatively written as *yǐ*. "Dao alignment" is read *dào qì kǔ jì qiè*. *Héng* is read in the departing tone; below, the same applies, meaning "unrestrained." "Not yet attained" is pronounced *wèi zào qī dào qiè*. "That which is relied upon" is read *suǒ yǐ yū qǐ qiè*. *Gān* is pronounced *qián*. *Ké* is read *kǒu jiǎo qiè*. *Zēng* is pronounced *céng wèi*. *Jiā* is read *shí zǐ xié qiè*. "Possible" is pronounced *kě jī*. "Greatly ashamed" is read *shèn zuò*. "Holding breath" means to restrain breathing as if not breathing. "Repeating" is pronounced *fú yòu qiè*. *Guān Yǐn* refers to *Guān Lìng Yǐn Xǐ*, styled *Gōng Dù*, who authored nine scrolls. "Concealed movement" is alternatively written as *jiàn*, also pronounced *qián*. "Not empty" is alternatively written as *zhì*, meaning "blocked." "Obstruction" is read *wéi hé*. "Not trembling" is pronounced *bù lì*. *Liè* is read *lì*. *Jī* is pronounced *jū*. *Yú* is read *wú*. "Speech" is pronounced *yǔ yú jù qiè*. *Nǚ* is read *rǔ*. "Far apart" is pronounced *xiāng yuǎn yú wàn qiè*. "Attainment" is read *zhī zào zāng zuò qiè*; the annotation is the same. "Herein" is pronounced *zhě yān yú qián qiè*. "Profound" is read *yín*. "Perceiving worth" is pronounced *jiàn xián biàn qiè*. "Nurturing one’s *qi*" is alternatively written as "preserving one’s true *qi*." "Attainment" is read *zào qī dào qiè*, meaning "to reach."

Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "The Yue people call death *zhá*." The *Zuozhuan* says: "People do not die prematurely." "Flaw" is pronounced *cī cái yí qiè*. "Illness" also. "Epidemic" is read *lì*. Zheng Zhong’s annotation to the *Rites of Zhou* states: "*Lì* is illness caused by disharmonious wind and qi." "Spirit" is pronounced *líng xiàng*. "Advance" is read *jìn*.

chunks.original_text: 无音绤。 闲也。 之队音坠。 乘亦食陵切。 遌物音忤。 遇也。 一本作□，心不欲见而晃曰□，於义颇迂。 《庄子》亦作□。 不折之涉切。 不窥去随切。 为伯于伪切。 无人莫侯切。 下并同。 穷镝音的。 措杯必回切。 肘竹九切。 摘矢音的。 本作镝。 复扶又切。 杳音踏。 寓音遇。 敏捷疾叶切。 象人木偶人形曰象人。 逡七旬切。 二分垂谓足二分悬垂在外。 至踵音肿。 挥斥音尺。 郭象云：挥斥，犹放纵也。 又曰：挥斥，奋迅也。 怵丑律切。 有徇目音荀。 何承天纂云：吴人呼瞬目为徇目。 中也丁仲切。 殆矣夫一本作始矣夫。 偏肥皮美切。 按《说文》、《字林》并作□，又作圯。 皆毁也。 字从其省。 侔音谋。 齐也。 於朝音潮。 相凌一本作相击。 介意音界。 副也。 称也。 垧外古萤切。 田叟西口切。 先悉荐切。 窘奇陨切。 困也。 荷胡可切。 畚音本。 蒉。
chunks.translated_text:
"Wú" is pronounced *xì*. Means "leisurely."

"Zhī" is pronounced *zhuì* when referring to falling.

"Chéng" is also pronounced *shí líng*.

"È wù" is pronounced *wǔ*. Means "to encounter." An alternative character is □, meaning "to avert one’s gaze when the heart does not wish to see," though this interpretation is somewhat forced. *Zhuāngzǐ* also uses □.

"Not breaking" is pronounced *zhī shè*.

"Not peeping" is pronounced *qù suí*.

"To act as lord" is pronounced *yú wěi*.

"No one" is pronounced *mò hóu*. The following instances are the same.

"Qióng dí" is pronounced *dí*.

"Cuò bēi" is pronounced *bì*.

"Elbow" is pronounced *zhú jiǔ*.

"Nock of an arrow" is pronounced *dí*. Originally written as *dí*.

"Fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*.

"Yǎo" is pronounced *tà*.

"Yù" is pronounced *yù*.

"Mǐn jié" is pronounced *jí yè*.

"Xiàng rén" refers to wooden puppets shaped like humans.

"Qūn" is pronounced *qī xún*.

"Èr fēn chuí" means the feet dangle with two parts exposed.

"To the heels" is pronounced *zhǒng*.

"Huī chì" is pronounced *chǐ*. Guo Xiang comments: "Huī chì means to be unrestrained." He also says: "Huī chì means to be vigorous and swift."

"Chù" is pronounced *chǒu lǜ*.

"Yǒu xùn mù" is pronounced *xún*. He Chengtian’s *Zuan* states: "The people of Wu call blinking *xùn mù*."

"To hit the mark" is pronounced *dīng zhòng*.

"Dài yǐ fú" is alternatively written as "shǐ yǐ fú."

"Piān féi" is pronounced *pí měi*.

According to the *Shuōwén* and *Zìlín*, both use □ or *yí*. All mean "to destroy." The character is an abbreviated form.

"Móu" is pronounced *móu*. Means "equal."

"Yú cháo" is pronounced *cháo*.

"Xiāng líng" is alternatively written as "xiāng jī."

"Jiè yì" is pronounced *jiè*. Means "to assist" or "to match."

"Shǎng" is pronounced *wài gǔ yíng*.

"Tián sǒu" is pronounced *xī kǒu*.

"Xiān" is pronounced *xī jiàn*.

"Jiǒng" is pronounced *qí yǔn*. Means "distressed."

"Hè" is pronounced *hú kě*.

"Běn" is pronounced *běn*.

"Kuì" is pronounced *kuì*.

"Attainment" is read *zhī zào zāng zuò qiè*; the annotation is the same. "Herein" is pronounced *zhě yān yú qián qiè*. "Profound" is read *yín*. "Perceiving worth" is pronounced *jiàn xián biàn qiè*. "Nurturing one’s *qi*" is alternatively written as "preserving one’s true *qi*." "Attainment" is read *zào qī dào qiè*, meaning "to reach."

chunks.original_text: 笼也。 阔视苦括切。 远也，广也。 眲之奴草切。 《方言》：扬越之闲，凡人相轻侮以为无知谓眲。 眲，耳目不相信也。 欺诒音待。 《方言》：相欺。 本作给。 挡故广切。 《方言》：今江东人亦名推为挡。 又肯晃。 搥打也。 蒲结切。 《方言》：凡相推搏曰。 又扶毕切。 推击也。 挨乌骇切。 推也。 抌丁感切。 《方言》：击背也。 一本作抗，违拒也。 亡所音无。 愠容於问切。 技渠奇切。 单音丹。 尽也。 惫於蒲界切。 疲也。 俱升一本作俱乘。 乘，登也。 漫言莫汗切。 散也。 偿百音赏。 飞鸟一本作飞凫。 扬余亮切。 犹颩物从风也。 骫骨音肌。 按骫是古委字。 《说文》云：骨，曲直也。 於义颇迂。 无音毁。
chunks.translated_text:
"Lóng" means "to cage."

"Kuò shì" is pronounced *kǔ kuò*. Means "to gaze afar," "vast," or "expansive."

"Nè" is pronounced *nú cǎo*. According to the *Fangyan*: In the regions of Yang and Yue, when people belittle or mock others as ignorant, they call it *nè*. *Nè* means that the ears and eyes do not trust.

"Qī yí" is pronounced *dài*. According to the *Fangyan*: "to deceive one another." Originally written as *gěi*.

"Dǎng" is pronounced *gù guǎng*. According to the *Fangyan*: Today, people in Jiangdong also call pushing *dǎng*.

Also pronounced *kěn huǎng*. Means "to beat" or "to strike."

"Pú" is pronounced *pú jié*. According to the *Fangyan*: In general, pushing and grappling are called *pú*.

Also pronounced *fú bì*. Means "to push and strike."

"Āi" is pronounced *wū hài*. Means "to push."

"Dǎn" is pronounced *dīng gǎn*. According to the *Fangyan*: "to strike the back." Alternatively written as *kàng*, meaning "to resist" or "to oppose."

"Wáng suǒ" is pronounced *wú*. Means "nowhere."

"Yùn róng" is pronounced *yú wèn*. Means "an angry countenance."

"Jì" is pronounced *qú qí*.

"Dān" is pronounced *dān*. Means "exhausted."

"Bèi" is pronounced *yú pú jiè*. Means "fatigued."

"Jù shēng" is alternatively written as "jù chéng." *Chéng* means "to ascend."

"Màn yán" is pronounced *mò hàn*. Means "scattered" or "diffuse."

"Cháng bǎi" is pronounced *shǎng*. "Fēi fú" is alternatively written as "fēi níu."

"Yáng" is pronounced *yú liàng*. Means "like the swaying of things in the wind."

"Wěi gǔ" is pronounced *jī*. Note: *wěi* is the ancient form of *wěi* (委). The *Shuowen* states: "Of bones, bent or straight." The meaning here is somewhat forced.

"Wú" is pronounced *huǐ*.

chunks.original_text: 偶然五口切。 未巨大也。 一本作讵。 因复扶又切。 之淫音深。 隈乌恢切。 水曲也。 一本作隅。 泳音咏。 潜行水中也。 水底都礼切。 众昉分两切。 或作放。 难色乃汗切。 埃不漫为句埃一本作焕。 吾亡音无。 近去声。 誉音余。 唯恐诚之之不至至之之不行行之之不及一本无至之之不行一句。 怛然丁达切。 惊也。 危险音崄。 识之音志。 周宣王名靖，厉王子也。 牧正养禽兽之长也。 梁鸯音央。 委於伪切。 食音嗣。 下食虎同。 雕鹗音雕锷。 无不柔驯者松伦切。 顺也。 一本无驯字。 孳音兹。 又音字。 尾孳尾，牝牡相生也。 乳化日孳，交接曰尾。 搏噬音博逝。 毛丘园姓毛，名丘园也。 一本作圉，鱼吕切。 传受之一本无受字。 为其于伪切。 下同。 碎之一本作决之。 其侪助皆切。 广泽本又作旷。 操七刀切。 下同。 能游浮水曰游。 数能色据切。 术也。 注同。

"Wēi" is pronounced *wū huī*. Means "a bend in the water." Alternatively written as *yú*.

"Shuǐ dǐ" is pronounced *dū lǐ*.

"Zhòng fǎng" is pronounced *fēn liǎng*. Alternatively written as *fàng*.

chunks.original_text: 擢舟直孝切。 一本作惧。 恐字误。 而谡所六切。 《庄子》作便。 能骛音木。 鸭也。 一本作矜字误曰□音衣。 与□同，叹声也。 玩其五贯切。 习也。 道与音余。 且为于伪切。 恶往音乌。 闲音闲。 瓦抠抠，探也。 以手藏物，探而取之曰抠。 亦曰藏彄。 《风土记》云：腊日欲祭之后，叟妪儿童为彄之戏。 辛氏《三秦记》汉钩弋夫人手拳，时人效之，因名为藏钩也。 彄，口侯切。 《庄子》作枢。 钩银铜为之。 惮待汗切。 殙音昏。 《方言》曰：迷殙也。 所要於遥切。 愈重音庾。 益也。 拱本作拙。 吕梁在今彭城郡。 《尔雅》曰：石绝水曰梁。 并流音傍。 《史记》《汉书》：傍，海傍河。 皆作并。 而承音拯。 《方言》：出溺为承。 诸家直作拯，又作撜。 棠行音塘。 下同。 道之音导。 下道之同。 郭璞注《穆天子传》云：道从也。 承子音拯。 曰亡音无。 本无此亡字。 齐司马云：齐，汨水。 如磨齐也。 汩古忽切。 涌波也。 郭象云：洄伏而涌出者，汩也。 痀於禹切。 偻音缕。
chunks.translated_text:
"Zhuó zhōu" is pronounced *zhí xiào*. One version writes it as *jù*, an error for the character *kǒng*.

"Ér sù" is pronounced *suǒ liù*. *Zhuāngzi* writes it as *biàn*.

"Néng wù" is pronounced *mù*, meaning "duck." One version erroneously writes it as *jīn*.

"Yǔ □ tóng" — *□* is pronounced *yī*, a sighing sound.

"Wàn" is pronounced *wǔ guàn*, meaning "to practice."

"Dào yǔ" is pronounced *yú*.

"Qiě wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*.

"Wū wǎng" is pronounced *wū*.

"Xián" is pronounced *xián*.

"Wǎ kōu" — *kōu* means "to probe." To conceal an object in the hand and retrieve it by probing is called *kōu*. It is also called *cáng kōu*. *Fēngtǔ Jì* states: "After the sacrifices on the La festival, elders and children play the *kōu* game." Xīn Shì’s *Sān Qín Jì* records: "Lady Gōuyì of the Han had clenched fists, and people imitated her, hence the name *cáng gōu*." *Kōu* is pronounced *kǒu hóu*. *Zhuāngzi* writes it as *shū*.

The hook is made of silver and bronze.

"Dàn" is pronounced *dài hàn*.

"Hūn" is pronounced *hūn*. *Fāngyán* states: "confusion and *hūn*."

"Suǒ yào" is pronounced *yú yáo*.

"Yù zhòng" is pronounced *yǔ*. It means "to increase."

The original text writes *gǒng* as *zhuō*.

Lǚliáng is located in present-day Pángchéng Prefecture. *Ěryǎ* states: "A rock that cuts off water is called a *liáng*."

"Bìng liú" is pronounced *páng*.

*Shǐjì* and *Hànshū* write *bàng* ("beside") as *bìng* ("alongside") in phrases such as "beside the sea" and "along the river."

"Ér chéng" is pronounced *zhěng*. *Fāngyán* states: "*chéng* means to rescue from drowning." Some versions write it directly as *zhěng* or *zhěng*.

"Táng" is pronounced *táng* in *táng xíng*. The same pronunciation applies below.

"Dào zhī" is pronounced *dǎo*. The same pronunciation applies below. Guō Pú’s annotation to *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn* states: "*dào* means to follow."

"Chéng zǐ" is pronounced *zhěng*.

"Yuē wáng" is pronounced *wú*. The original text lacks this *wáng* character.

Sīmǎ of Qí states: "Qí refers to the Gǔ River, like grinding and *qí*." *Gǔ* is pronounced *gǔ hū*, meaning "surging waves." Guō Xiàng states: "That which swirls beneath and surges forth is *gǔ*."

"Jū" is pronounced *yǔ*. *Lǚ* is pronounced *lǚ*.

chunks.original_text: 痀偻，背曲疾也。 承鼂音条。 一本作蜩。 蝉也。 掇都括切。 拾取也。 累古累字。 垸音丸。 司马云：谓累丸於竿头也。 锱铢音淄殊。 蜩音调。 吾处身也一本作无身也。 厥株驹厥，本或作橛同。 其月切。 《说文》作橛，木本也。 李颐云：厥，竖也。 株驹，亦枯树本也。 驹音俱。 崔撰音佺。 清河人也，晋议郎，注《南华真经》内外二十七篇。 槁木空好切。 曰女音汝。 逢衣《礼记儒行篇》曰：丘少居鲁，衣逢掖之衣。 长居宋，冠章甫之冠。 郑玄注云：逢，犹大也，谓大掖之衣。 向秀曰：儒服宽而长大者。 有好呼报切。 沤音鸥。 鸟水鹗也。 今江湖畔形色似白鸽而群飞者是也。 百住音数。 汝取来一本作可取来。
chunks.translated_text:
"Jū lǚ" refers to a hunched back, a spinal deformity.

"Chéng cháo" is pronounced *tiáo*. One version writes it as *tiáo*, meaning "cicada."

"Duō" is pronounced *duō kuò*, meaning "to pick up."

"Lěi" is the original form of the character *lěi*.

"Yuàn" is pronounced *wán*. Sīmǎ states: "It refers to piling pellets atop a pole."

"Zī zhū" is pronounced *zī shū*.

"Tiáo" is pronounced *tiáo*.

"Wú chǔ shēn" ("I dwell in the body")—one version writes it as "wú shēn" ("without a body").

"Jué zhū jū"—*jué* is sometimes written as *jué* (identical in meaning). It is pronounced *qí yuè*. The *Shuōwén* writes it as *jué*, meaning "the base of a tree." Lǐ Yí states: "*Jué* means upright." *Zhū jū* also refers to the stump of a withered tree. *Jū* is pronounced *jū*.

"Cuī zhuàn" is pronounced *quán*. He was a man of Qīnghé, a Discussant of the Jin dynasty, who annotated the twenty-seven inner and outer chapters of the *Nanhua Zhenjing*.

"Gǎo mù" is pronounced *hǎo qiē*.

"Yuē nǚ" is pronounced *rǔ*.

"Féng yī"—The *Lǐjì*’s "Rúxíng" chapter states: "In his youth, Confucius lived in Lu, wearing robes with wide sleeves. Later, he resided in Song, donning the *zhāngfǔ* cap." Zhèng Xuán’s annotation says: "*Féng* means 'large,' referring to robes with broad sleeves." Xiàng Xiù states: "Confucian robes are loose and long."

"Yǒu" is pronounced *hū bào*.

"Ōu" is pronounced *ōu*, referring to the osprey, a water bird. Those seen today by rivers and lakes—white as doves and flying in flocks—are of this kind.

"Bǎi zhù" is pronounced *shù*.

"Rǔ qǔ lái" ("you take and come")—one version writes it as "kě qǔ lái" ("you may take and come").
chunks.overlap_context:
zhī" is pronounced *dǎo*. The same pronunciation applies below. Guō Pú’s annotation to *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn* states: "*dào* means to follow."

"Chéng zǐ" is pronounced *zhěng*.

"Yuē wáng" is pronounced *wú*. The original text lacks this *wáng* character.

Sīmǎ of Qí states: "Qí refers to the Gǔ River, like grinding and *qí*." *Gǔ* is pronounced *gǔ hū*, meaning "surging waves." Guō Xiàng states: "That which swirls beneath and surges forth is *gǔ*."

"Jū" is pronounced *yǔ*. *Lǚ* is pronounced *lǚ*.

chunks.original_text: 去言丘吕切。 齐在诣切。 忤音悟。 骇谐楷切。 下同。 赵襄子名无恤，简子之子也。 率徒所律也。 畋音田。 藉在夜切。 花而振切。 在下曰藉，草不剪曰花。 燔音烦。 烧也。 烬疲刃切。 上下时掌切。 留之力救切。 谓宿。 留而视之也。 窍口吊切。 向音向。 刳音枯。 去丘吕切。 有暇本又作假，亦音暇字。 大说音悦。 强其两切。 着直略切。 挂音卦。 碍本作碍。 颠都年切。 坠也。 偏音篇。 神巫男曰觋，女曰巫。 颜师古曰：巫觋亦通称季咸姓季，名咸，郑人也。 避一本作弃。 喜许记切。

chunks.original_text: 壶子列子师也。 又过音戈。 无其文诸家本作既，於义不长。 道与音余。 奚卵来短切。 司马云：汝受训未熟，故未成。 若众雌无雄者，则无卵也。 和胡卧切。 抗口浪切。 或作亢。 音同。 相悉亮切。 视之音视。 向吾一本作庸吾。 下同。 嘻音熙。 湿灰司马云：气如湿灰。 罪本作萌。 震音震。 不止崔撰云：不震不止，如动不动也。 量音亮。 灰本作全。 功见贤遍切。 机发於踵许慎注《淮南子》云：机发不旋踵。 齐侧皆切。 下同。 大音泰朕直引切。 兆也。 鲵音倪。 桓胡官切。 盘桓也。 一本作旋，谓盘旋也。 之潘音盘。 本作蟠。 水之溘洞之溘。 今作蟠。 恐写之误。 为渊鲵，大鱼也。 桓，盘桓也。 蟠，徊流也。 此言大鱼盘桓其水，蟠洄而成深泉。 《南华真经》作审。 梁简文云：蟠，聚也。 滥水咸上声。 《尔雅》云：水涌出也。 沃水乌仆切。 水泉从上溜下也。 氿水音轨。 水泉从傍出也。 雍水音拥。 河水决出复还入也。 汧水音牵。 水不流行也。 肥水水所出异为肥也。 洄音回。 易以豉切。 舍之音舍。 澹徒滥切。 泊音魄。 自失而走丧失精神而走。 猗於危切。 移委移至顺之貌。 泛芳剑切。 茅《庄子》作茅。 音颓。 靡崔撰石：逊伏也。 为其于伪切。 爨七玩切。 食音嗣。 下同。 狶虚岂切。 楚人呼猪作稀。 适音的。 雕琢持衮切。 本作琢。 份然音纷。 而封哉一本作戎。 音哉。 恶乎音乌。 馈求位切。 饷也。 惊己音纪。 谓惊其自失也。 下处己。 同音。 不解音蟹。 向秀曰：未能悬解。 谍音牒。 便辟婢亦切。 尊长丁丈切。 而子西切。 食羹音嗣。 无多余之赢音盈。 一本无无字。 而知音智。 保汝保，附也。 屦九遇切。 关西呼履谓之屦。 敦杖音顿。 蹙之子六切。 乎颐音怡。 有间少时也。 宾本作傧。 导也。 必忍切。 提屦音蹄屦。 一本作履。 徒跣先典切。 暨其器切。 至也。 当丁浪切。 背音佩。 焉於虔切。 先悉荐切。
chunks.translated_text:
Master Huzi was Liezi’s teacher.

"Yòu" is pronounced *gū*.

Some versions read *jì* ("already") instead of *wú* ("lacking"), but this does not improve the meaning.

"Dào" is pronounced *yú*.

"Xī" is pronounced *lái duǎn*. Sima Biao notes: "You have not yet mastered the teachings, so they remain unformed." As with a flock of hens without a rooster, there are no eggs.

"Hé" is pronounced *hú wò*.

"Kàng" is pronounced *kǒu làng*. Some versions write it as *kàng*, with the same pronunciation.

"Xiāng" is pronounced *xī liàng*.

"Shì" is pronounced *shì*.

"Xiàng wú" in some versions is written as *yōng wú*, with the same meaning below.

"Xī" is pronounced *xī*.

"Shī huī": Sima Biao notes: "Qi like damp ashes."

"Zhī pān" is pronounced *pán*. Originally written as *pán*.

"Water’s *kè*": The character *kè* here is the same as in *kètòng*. Now written as *pán*.

This refers to the deep-pool *ní*, a great fish. *Huán* means to linger; *pán* means to coil in the current. This describes how the great fish lingers in the water, coiling and swirling to form a deep spring. The *Nanhua Zhenjing* writes it as *shěn*.

Liang Jianwen states: "*Pán* means to gather."

"Làn" in *làn shuǐ* is pronounced with the upper tone. The *Erya* states: "Water gushing forth."

"Yōng" in *yōng shuǐ* is pronounced *yōng*, meaning "river water bursting forth and then returning."

"Qiān" in *qiān shuǐ* is pronounced *qiān*, meaning "water that does not flow."

"Féi" in *féi shuǐ* refers to water whose source is distinct, making it rich.

"Cù" is pronounced *zǐ liù*.

chunks.original_text: 摇而本身一本作摇而才本性。 易以豉切。 觉音教。 杨朱解在第七篇。 之沛音贝。 邀於於宵切。 抄也，遮也。 中道道中。 仰天本作印，亦音仰。 以女音汝。 能去丘吕切。 矜夸口瓜切。 进涫音管《庄子》作盥。 漱音瘐。 巾栉壮乙切。 脱履本作屦。 向音向。 不间音闲。 下同。 睢睢许唯切。 盱盱音吁。 《说文》云：盱，仰目也。 《苍颉篇》云：盱，张目貌。 高诱注《淮南子》云：睢盱，视听貌。 蹴子六切。 炀音杨。 司马云：对火曰炀。 《淮南子》云：富人衣纂锦，贫人炀灶口。 不恶乌路切。 过宋音戈。

chunks.original_text: 而去丘吕切。 之行下孟切。 亦本作易。 以致切。 亡音无。 鬻本作粥。 余六切。 倚於绮切。 趣章趋。 傅翼音附。 庖音匏。 牺许宜切。 女娲音瓜。 庖牺女娲，皆古天子。 臆行音亿。 曼音万。 鴳乌葛切。 鼻上也。 颔胡感切。 相息亮切。 鹄步音鹤。 鸢肩音缘。 鹰啄许秽切。 几音异。 阪蒲板切。 泉在上谷。 帅音率。 熊罴音碑。 貙丑俱切。 雕鹖音雕曷。 一本作鹗。 旗帜音炽自熊罴皆猛兽勇斗者也。 而人不知接之之道一本无人字。 行则户刚切。 大古音泰。 介氏音界。 数数音朔。 六畜朽又切。 解音蟹。 注同。 之长张丈切。 蜎许缘切。 蠕而兖切。 魑丑知切。 魅音媚。 虫蛾《尔雅》云：有足曰虫，无足曰蛾。 一本作虫蚁。 狙公七余切养狙公也。 好养呼报切。 解音蟹。 驯音唇。 芋音序。 橡子也。 能鄙相笼一本作智鄙相笼。 名实未亏一本作若实未亏也。 纪消子姓纪，名消，或作消。 所景切。 为于伪切。

chunks.original_text: 影向音响。 李颐云：应响鸣顾影行。 迅峻信二音。 一本作速。 惠盎阿浪切。 见贤遍切。 蹀足音牒。 謦口顶切。 欬音慨。 所说音悦。 下同。 刺之七亦切。 弗中丁仲切。 下同。 欢然音欢。 墨翟音狄。 宋大夫也，在孔子后，着书七十一篇。 崇孝尊鬼，强本节用，亦救世之难。 有攻守之术。 为长张丈切。 竟音境。 说如字。 又音税。 服寡人也一本作晓寡人也。 周穆王第三一曰化本 俛仰音免。 之觉音教。 视瞬音舜。 怳况往切。 惚音忽。 周穆王名满，昭王子也。 化幻胡办切。 贯音官。 穿也。 隧音坠。 不碍音碍。 腥音星。 蝼音楼。 而不可飨音享。 《周礼□天官》内飨腥不可食者，马黑脊而般臂。 郑玄云：般臂，毛自有文也。 蝼蛄臭，今读者宜依《周礼》。 飨食，按隋秘书王邵《读书记》云：蝼蛄，古本多作女旁者。 《方言》亦同。 飨音邕，般音班。 膻恶音膻。 乃古乃字。 为之于伪切。 赭音者。 赤色。 垩音恶。 白土也。 五府《周礼》：太府掌九贡九职之货贿，王府掌金玉玩好。 内府主良货贿，外府主泉藏，膳府主四时食物者也。 终南山名。 在京兆。
chunks.translated_text:
"Yǐng xiàng" is pronounced *yìng xiǎng*. Li Yi states: responding to echoes and moving while gazing at one’s shadow.

"Xùn jùn" is pronounced *xùn* or *jùn*. In some versions, it is written as *sù*.

"Huì àng" is pronounced *ā làng qiè*.

"Jiàn xián" is pronounced *biàn qiè*.

"Dié zú" is pronounced *dié*.

"Qǐng" is pronounced *kǒu dǐng qiè*.

"Kài" is pronounced *kǎi*.

"Suǒ shuō" is pronounced *yuè*. The same applies below.

"Cì zhī" is pronounced *qī yì qiè*.

"Fú zhòng" is pronounced *dīng zhòng qiè*. The same applies below.

"Huān rán" is pronounced *huān*.

"Mò Dí" is pronounced *Dí*. A grandee of Song, postdating Confucius, who authored seventy-one pian. He revered filial piety, honored spirits, strengthened fundamentals, and practiced frugality, thus remedying the world’s crises. He possessed arts of attack and defense.

"Wéi" is pronounced *zhāng zhàng qiè*.

"Jìng" is pronounced *jìng*.

"Shuō" is read as the character itself, or pronounced *shuì*.

"Fú guǎ rén yě" in some versions is written as *xiǎo guǎ rén yě*.

**Third Pian: Huà Běn**

"Fǔ yǎng" is pronounced *miǎn*.

"Zhī jué" is pronounced *jiào*.

"Shì shùn" is pronounced *shùn*.

"Huǎng" is pronounced *kuàng wǎng qiè*.

"Hū" is pronounced *hū*.

King Mu of Zhou was named Mǎn, son of King Zhao.

"Huà huàn" is pronounced *hú bàn qiè*.

"Guàn" is pronounced *guān*, meaning to pierce.

"Suì" is pronounced *zhuì*.

"Bù ài" is pronounced *ài*.

"Xīng" is pronounced *xīng*.

"Lóu" is pronounced *lóu*, and it cannot be offered as *xiǎng*. The *Rites of Zhou: Tiānguān* states: "For internal *xiǎng*, the inedible includes horses with black spines and patterned forelegs." Zheng Xuan notes: "*Bān* forelegs refer to fur with natural markings." The stench of mole crickets—modern readers should follow the *Rites of Zhou*. *Xiǎng shí*: According to Wang Shao’s *Dúshū Jì* in the Sui dynasty’s Imperial Library, "mole cricket" was often written with the "woman" radical in ancient texts, and the *Fāngyán* concurs. *Xiǎng* is pronounced *yōng*, *bān* is pronounced *bān*.

"Shān è" is pronounced *shān*.

"Nǎi" is the ancient form of *nǎi*.

"Wéi zhī" is pronounced *yú wěi qiè*.

"Zhě" is pronounced *zhě*, meaning the color red.

"È" is pronounced *è*, meaning white clay.

**Five Treasuries**: The *Rites of Zhou* states: The Grand Treasury oversees the nine tributes and nine duties’ goods and wealth; the Royal Treasury manages gold, jade, and precious curios; the Inner Treasury holds fine goods and wealth; the Outer Treasury stores coinage; and the Provisions Treasury oversees the four seasons’ foods.

**Zhōngnán**: A mountain name, located in Jingzhao.

chunks.original_text: 蛾媌音茅。 好而轻者谓之蛾。 自关而东河齐之间谓之媌。 或谓之妖。 靡曼音万。 正娥音俄。 笄音鸡。 珥音饵。 填也。 晃上垂玉以塞耳也。 琐他见切。 衣於既切。 细谷音斛。 曳音裔。 齐纨《范子》云：白执素出齐鲁。 几居岂切。 谒请也。 袪音墟。 上时掌切。 暨见器切。 广乐音岳。 注同。 秦缪音穆。 甚乐音洛。 累块口对切。 积苏樵人。 人复扶又切。 之处昌据切。 眩音县。 黛音代。 芷音止。 莹鸟定切。 又音茎。 九招本作韶。 市昭切。 以乐音洛。 不舍音释。 亡音无。 悸其季切。 丧息浪切。 陨音陨。 落也。 向音向。 昲扶贵切。 《方言》：昲乾物也。 又音沸。 三月而复为句。 一本作不复。 在觉音教。 曩乃朗切。 王闲音闲。 恒有谓习其常存也。 一本无有字。 摸音谟。 不恤思律切。 治乱直吏切。 骏音俊。 乘实证切。 下同。 嗣音华。 骝音留。 绿耳皆八骏名。 骖七南切。 赤骥音异。 白牺音义。 《史记》曰：造父为穆王得骅骝、绿耳、赤骥、白牺之马。 御以游巡，往见西王母，乐而忘归。 与《 穆天子传》 略同。 郭璞注云：皆毛色以为名也。 后有渠黄踰踰盗骊山子为八骏也。 造七到切。 父音甫。
chunks.translated_text:
"É miáo" is pronounced *máo*. The graceful and delicate are called *é*. East of the Pass, in the regions of Hé and Qí, they are called *miáo*, or sometimes *yāo*.

"Mǐ màn" is pronounced *wàn*. "Zhēng é" is pronounced *é*.

"Jī" is pronounced *jī*. "Ěr" is pronounced *ěr*, meaning "to plug." Bright jade hangs down to block the ears.

"Suǒ" is pronounced *tā jiàn qiè*. "Yī" is pronounced *yū jì qiè*. "Xì gǔ" is pronounced *hú*. "Yè" is pronounced *yì*.

The *Fánzǐ* states of *Qí wán*: "White silk of purity comes from Qí and Lǔ."

"Jī" is pronounced *jū qǐ qiè*, meaning "to request an audience." "Qū" is pronounced *qū*. "Shàng" is pronounced *shí zhǎng qiè*. "Jì" is pronounced *jiàn qì qiè*.

"Guǎng yuè" is pronounced *yuè* (note identical).

"Qín Miào" is pronounced *Mù*. "Shèn lè" is pronounced *Luò*.

"Lěi kuài" is pronounced *kǒu duì qiè*. "Jī sū" refers to firewood gatherers.

"Rén fù" is pronounced *fú yòu qiè*. "Zhī chù" is pronounced *chāng jù qiè*.

"Xuàn" is pronounced *xiàn*. "Dài" is pronounced *dài*. "Zhǐ" is pronounced *zhǐ*.

"Yíng" is pronounced *niǎo dìng qiè*, or alternatively *jīng*.

The *Jiǔ zhāo* originally wrote *Sháo*. "Shì" is pronounced *zhāo qiè*. "Yǐ lè" is pronounced *Luò*. "Bù shě" is pronounced *shì*. "Wáng" is pronounced *wú*.

"Jì" is pronounced *qí jì qiè*. "Sàng" is pronounced *xī làng qiè*. "Yǔn" is pronounced *yǔn*, meaning "to fall."

"Xiàng" is pronounced *xiàng*. "Fèi" is pronounced *fú guì qiè*. The *Fāngyán* states: *Fèi* means to dry things. It is also pronounced *fèi*.

"Sān yuè ér fù" forms a sentence. One version reads *bù fù*.

"Zài jué" is pronounced *jiào*. "Nǎng" is pronounced *nǎi lǎng qiè*.

"Wáng xián" is pronounced *xián*. "Héng yǒu" means to cultivate constancy in its presence. One version omits the character *yǒu*.

"Mō" is pronounced *mó*. "Bù xù" is pronounced *sī lǜ qiè*. "Zhì luàn" is pronounced *zhí lì qiè*.

"Jùn" is pronounced *jùn*. "Chéng" is pronounced *shí zhèng qiè* (same below).

"Sì" is pronounced *huá*. "Liú" is pronounced *liú*. *Lǜ ěr* are two of the Eight Steeds’ names.

"Cān" is pronounced *qī nán qiè*. "Chì jì" is pronounced *yì*. "Bái xī" is pronounced *yì*.

The *Shǐjì* states: "Zào Fù obtained for King Mù the horses *Huá liú*, *Lǜ ěr*, *Chì jì*, and *Bái xī*. Driving them on his travels, he visited the Queen Mother of the West and, delighted, forgot to return." This account aligns roughly with the *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn*. Guō Pú’s commentary notes: "All are named for their coat colors." Later, *Qú huáng*, *Yú yú*, *Dào lí*, and *Shān zǐ* were also counted among the Eight Steeds.

"Zào" is pronounced *qī dào qiè*. "Fù" is pronounced *fǔ*.
chunks.overlap_context:
ed *yú wěi qiè*.

"Zhě" is pronounced *zhě*, meaning the color red.

"È" is pronounced *è*, meaning white clay.

**Five Treasuries**: The *Rites of Zhou* states: The Grand Treasury oversees the nine tributes and nine duties’ goods and wealth; the Royal Treasury manages gold, jade, and precious curios; the Inner Treasury holds fine goods and wealth; the Outer Treasury stores coinage; and the Provisions Treasury oversees the four seasons’ foods.

**Zhōngnán**: A mountain name, located in Jingzhao.

chunks.original_text: 为御《史记》 云：周穆王乘骅骝、绿耳，使造父为御，日行千里。 □音泰。 篆作裔。 音丙。 《石经》作风，《字林》云：隐作面。 本作音。 上齐下合，於义无取焉。 为右《淮南子》云：钳且泰丙之御也，除辔衔，弃鞭策。 高誧云：皆古之得道善御也。 钳，其炎切。 且，子余切。 盗骊力移切。 盗骊，即荀子之纤离者也。 柏夭於表切。 郭璞云：柏夭，人姓名。 巨搜音渠搜。 西戎国名。 以饮於禁切。 之湩竹用切。 以洗先礼切。 二乘实证切。 昆仑音昆论。 之阿赤水之阳《山海经》云：流沙之滨，赤水之后，黑水之前，有大山名昆仑之丘，有人穴处，名曰西王母也。 之□古丘字。 黄帝之宫陆贾《新语》云：黄帝巡游四海，登昆仑山，起宫望於其上。 以诒音怡传也。 遂宾于西王母《河图玉版》云：西王母居昆仑山。 《纪年》云：穆王十七年，西征见西王母，宾于昭宫。 为于伪切。 王和胡卧切。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Shǐjì* states: "King Mu of Zhou rode *Huá liú* and *Lǜ ěr*, with Zào Fù as his charioteer, covering a thousand *lǐ* in a day." □ is pronounced *tài*. In seal script, it is written as *yì*.  is pronounced *bǐng*. The *Stone Classics* render it as *fēng*, while the *Zìlín* notes: "The hidden form resembles *miàn*." Originally written as . The upper part aligns, the lower converges, yet this bears no relevance to the meaning.

As for the right-hand passage, the *Huáinánzǐ* states: "The charioteers Qián Qiě and Tài Bǐng removed the bridle and bit, discarding the whip and goad." Gāo Yòu comments: "All were ancient masters of the Dao skilled in charioteering." *Qián* is pronounced *qí yán qiè*. *Qiě* is pronounced *zǐ yú qiè*. *Dào lí* is pronounced *lì yí qiè*. *Dào lí* refers to the *Xiān lí* mentioned in the *Xúnzǐ*. *Bǎi yāo* is pronounced *yú biǎo qiè*. Guō Pú notes: "*Bǎi yāo* is a person’s name." *Jù sōu* is pronounced *qú sōu*. A state of the Western Róng. *Yǐ yǐn* is pronounced *yú jìn qiè*. *Zhī dòng* is pronounced *zhú yòng qiè*. *Yǐ xǐ* is pronounced *xiān lǐ qiè*. *Èr chéng* is pronounced *shí zhèng qiè*. *Kūnlún* is pronounced *kūn lún*. *Zhī ē chì shuǐ zhī yáng*: The *Shānhǎi Jīng* states: "By the shores of the Flowing Sands, beyond the Red Waters and before the Black Waters, stands a great mountain called the Kunlun Mound, where cave-dwelling people reside, known as the Queen Mother of the West." *Zhī* □ is an ancient form of *qiū*. *Huángdì zhī gōng*: Lù Jiǎ’s *Xīn Yǔ* states: "The Yellow Emperor traveled the four seas, ascended Kunlun Mountain, and built a palace to gaze from its summit." *Yǐ yí* is pronounced *yí*, meaning "to transmit." *Suì bīn yú Xī Wángmǔ*: The *Hétú Yùbǎn* states: "The Queen Mother of the West dwells on Kunlun Mountain." The *Jìnián* records: "In the seventeenth year of his reign, King Mu marched west, met the Queen Mother of the West, and was received as a guest at the Bright Palace." *Wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi qiè*. *Wáng* is pronounced *hú wò qiè*."

ronounced *yì*.

The *Shǐjì* states: "Zào Fù obtained for King Mù the horses *Huá liú*, *Lǜ ěr*, *Chì jì*, and *Bái xī*. Driving them on his travels, he visited the Queen Mother of the West and, delighted, forgot to return." This account aligns roughly with the *Mù Tiānzǐ Zhuàn*. Guō Pú’s commentary notes: "All are named for their coat colors." Later, *Qú huáng*, *Yú yú*, *Dào lí*, and *Shān zǐ* were also counted among the Eight Steeds.

"Zào" is pronounced *qī dào qiè*. "Fù" is pronounced *fǔ*.

chunks.original_text: 弇音奄。 万行行读为里。 於于音呜呼。 又作乎。 追数色句切。 责也。 王几音岂。 之乐音洛。 假音遐。 考成子一本作老成子。 着书十八篇。 室屏必郢切。 老聃吐蓝切。 愤薄房吻切。 而复扶又切。 淫思音深。 幡音翻。 校音绞。 顾野王读作翻交四时。 蒸烁音铄。 水澒音洪。 不着陟虑切。 而已音以。 为之于伪切。 觉有音教。 义见贤遍切。 曰丧息浪切。 曰乐音洛。 曰蘁音愕。 曰寤音悟。 所怛丁达切。 难谲音决。 则濡音儒。 燔音烦。 如悦切。 抗则或作亢。 藉带慈夜切。 造极七到切。 几虚音岂。 南嵎与隅同。 古莽莫朗切。 亡辩音无。 下同。 跨河苦化切。 之分符问切。 阜落音妇。 常燠音郁。 相藉音陵。 大治音持。 趣役音趋。 下同。 呻呼音申吟。 下同。 昏惫蒲介切。 昔昔夜夜也。 游燕音宴。 观古乱切。 其乐音洛。 觉音教。 下同。 啽吾南切。 呓音诣。 啽呓，□吟并寐语也。 恶焉乌路切。 思虑音四。 少间病差也。 相□音夸。 御而音讶。 迎也。 毙之音币。 诸隍音黄。 无水池也。 以蕉与樵切。 不胜音升。 不厌音惬。 又於艳切。 士师掌五禁之法者。 仞人一本作认。 曰嘻音熙。 将复扶又切。 国相息亮切。 邪直似遮切。 或作邪真。 今亡音无。 且恂音荀。 信也。 华子胡化切。 病忘音望。 不记事也。 阖室胡腊切。 毒之毒，苦也。 蓍龟音尸。 情匿眤力切。
chunks.translated_text: Yǎn is pronounced *yǎn*. *Wàn xíng* is read as *lǐ*. *Yú* is pronounced *wū hū*; also written as *hū*. *Zhuī shǔ* is pronounced *sè jù*, meaning "to reproach." *Wáng jī* is pronounced *qǐ*. *Zhī lè* is pronounced *luò*. *Jiǎ* is pronounced *xiá*. *Kǎo Chéngzǐ* in one version is *Lǎo Chéngzǐ*. He authored eighteen scrolls. *Shì píng* is pronounced *bǐng*. *Lǎo Dān* is pronounced *tǔ lán*. *Fèn bó* is pronounced *fáng wěn*. *Ér fù* is pronounced *fú yòu*. *Yín sī* is pronounced *shēn*. *Fān* is pronounced *fān*. *Jiào* is pronounced *jiǎo*. Gù Yěwáng reads it as *fān jiāo sì shí*. *Zhēng shuò* is pronounced *shuò*. *Shuǐ hòng* is pronounced *hóng*. *Bù zhuó* is pronounced *zhù lǜ*. *Ér yǐ* is pronounced *yǐ*. *Wéi zhī* is pronounced *yú wěi*. *Jué yǒu* is pronounced *jiào*. *Yì jiàn* is pronounced *xián biàn*. *Yuē sàng* is pronounced *xī làng*. *Yuē lè* is pronounced *luò*. *Yuē wù* is pronounced *è*. *Yuē wù* is pronounced *wù*. *Suǒ dá* is pronounced *dīng dá*. *Nán jué* is pronounced *jué*. *Zé rú* is pronounced *rú*. *Fán* is pronounced *fán*. *Yù* is pronounced *rù yuè*. *Kàng* is sometimes written as *kàng*. *Jiè dài* is pronounced *cí yè*. *Zào jí* is pronounced *qī dào*. *Jī xū* is pronounced *qǐ*. *Nán yú* is the same as *yú*. *Gǔ mǎng* is pronounced *mò lǎng*. *Wáng biàn* is pronounced *wú*; the same below. *Kuà hé* is pronounced *kǔ huà*. *Zhī fēn* is pronounced *fú*. *Fù luò* is pronounced *fù*. *Cháng yù* is pronounced *yù*. *Xiāng jiè* is pronounced *líng*. *Dà zhì* is pronounced *chí*. *Qū yì* is pronounced *qū*; the same below. *Shēn hū* is pronounced *shēn yín*; the same below. *Hūn bèi* is pronounced *pú jiè*. *Xī* means "night." *Yóu yàn* is pronounced *yàn*. *Guān* is pronounced *gǔ luàn*. *Qí lè* is pronounced *luò*. *Jué* is pronounced *jiào*; the same below. *Án* is pronounced *wú nán*. *Yì* is pronounced *yì*. *Án yì* and *□ yín* both refer to sleep-talking. *Wù yān* is pronounced *wū lù*. *Sī lǜ* is pronounced *sì*. *Shǎo jiàn* means "recovery from illness." *Xiāng □* is pronounced *kuā*. *Yù ér* is pronounced *yà*, meaning "to welcome." *Bì zhī* is pronounced *bì*. *Zhū huáng* is pronounced *huáng*, referring to moats without water. *Yǐ jiāo* is pronounced *yǔ qiáo*. *Bù shèng* is pronounced *shēng*. *Bù yàn* is pronounced *qiè*, or *yù yàn*. *Shì shī* refers to officials in charge of the five prohibitions. *Rèn rén* in one version is *rèn*. *Yuē xī* is pronounced *xī*. *Jiāng fù* is pronounced *fú yòu*. *Guó xiàng* is pronounced *xī liàng*. *Xié zhí* is pronounced *sì zhē*, sometimes written as *xié zhēn*. *Jīn wáng* is pronounced *wú*. *Qiě xún* is pronounced *xún*, meaning "trustworthy." *Huá zǐ* is pronounced *hú huà*. *Bìng wàng* is pronounced *wàng*, meaning "forgetfulness, unable to recall matters." *Hé shì* is pronounced *hú là*. *Dú zhī dú* means "bitterness." *Shī guī* is pronounced *shī*. *Qíng nì* is pronounced *nì lì*.

The *Jìnián* records: "In the seventeenth year of his reign, King Mu marched west, met the Queen Mother of the West, and was received as a guest at the Bright Palace." *Wéi* is pronounced *yú wěi qiè*. *Wáng* is pronounced *hú wò qiè*."

chunks.original_text: 泊尔音魄。 鉴音鉴。 自拯蒸上声，本作极。 行无下孟切。 狂辟音僻。 疚音救。 痾音阿府藏才浪切。 脉诊止忍切。 其瘳丑鸠切。 然吾之方密为句。 从之音纵。 绝思音四。 操戈七刀切。 往数色主切。 哀乐音洛。 好呼报切。 恶乌路切。 可复扶又切。 妙当丁浪切。 一本作赏。 逢氏音庞。 子少诗照切。 迷罔文两切。 过陈音戈。 乡使音向。 哀乐音洛。 之邮音尤。 焉能於虔切。 遄归士缘切。 辩争音诤。 长於张丈切。 过晋音戈。 诳之九况切。 愀然七小切。 喟然丘愧切。 涓然音泫。 胡犬、胡绢二切。 自禁音金。 哑然乌陌切。 给若音待。 欺也。 更微少也。 作彻者误。 仲尼第四一曰极智 去情丘吕切。 一本作忘。 仲尼鲁国曲阜县人，颜氏祷尼丘山生，因名字仲尼。 周灵王二十一年庚戍岁生。 间居音闲。 子贡端木赐，卫人，字子贡，利口巧辞。 颜回鲁人，字子渊。 援琴音袁。 独乐音洛。 之分符问切。 下同。 愀然七小切。 有间怅然变色少时。 意夹音狭。 一本作失。 亡变音忘。 一本作止。 曩吾乃朗切。 礼乐音岳。 下同。 遗来唯季切。 既治直吏切。 治乱。 下同。 不舍音舍。 无阂音碍。 将为干伪切。 欲捐音缘。 聘鲁匹正切。 仿髴芳味切。 之量音亮。 其称尺证切。 下同。 泊然音魄。 下同。 亢仓子音庚桑，名楚。 《史记》作亢仓子。 贾逵《姚氏英览》云：吴郡有庚桑姓，称为士族。 传之又专切。 唯然唯癸切。
chunks.translated_text:
"Bó ěr" is pronounced *pò*. "Jiàn" is pronounced *jiàn*. "Zì zhěng" is pronounced *zhēng* (rising tone), originally written as *jí*. "Xíng wú" is pronounced *xià mèng*. "Kuáng pì" is pronounced *pì*. "Jiù" is pronounced *jiù*. "Ē" is pronounced *ā*; "fǔ zàng cái" is pronounced *làng*. "Mài zhěn" is pronounced *zhǐ rěn*. "Qí chōu" is pronounced *chǒu jiū*. "Rán wú zhī fāng mì" forms a sentence. "Cóng zhī" is pronounced *zòng*. "Jué sī" is pronounced *sì*. "Cāo gē" is pronounced *qī dāo*. "Wǎng shù" is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. "Āi yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Hǎo" is pronounced *hū bào*. "Wù" is pronounced *wū lù*. "Kě fù" is pronounced *fú yòu*. "Miào dāng" is pronounced *dīng làng*, or in one version, *shǎng*. "Péng shì" is pronounced *páng*. "Zǐ shào" is pronounced *shī zhào*. "Mí wǎng" is pronounced *wén liǎng*. "Guò chén" is pronounced *gē*. "Xiāng shǐ" is pronounced *xiàng*. "Āi yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Zhī yóu" is pronounced *yóu*. "Yān néng" is pronounced *yú qián*. "Chuán guī" is pronounced *shì yuán*. "Biàn zhēng" is pronounced *zhèng*. "Zhǎng yú" is pronounced *zhāng zhàng*. "Guò jìn" is pronounced *gē*. "Kuáng zhī" is pronounced *jiǔ kuàng*. "Qiǎo rán" is pronounced *qī xiǎo*. "Kuì rán" is pronounced *qiū kuì*. "Juān rán" is pronounced *xuàn*. "Hú quǎn" and "hú juàn" are both pronounced *èr qiè*. "Zì jìn" is pronounced *jīn*. "Yǎ rán" is pronounced *wū mò*. "Gěi ruò" is pronounced *dài*, meaning "to deceive." "Gèng" means "slight, minor"; those who write it as *chè* are mistaken.

"Zhòng Ní dì sì" reads *jí zhì*. "Qù qíng" is pronounced *qiū lǚ*, or in one version, *wàng*. Zhongni was a native of Qufu County in the state of Lu, born on Mount Niqiu of the Yan clan, hence his name and style, Zhongni. He was born in the twenty-first year of King Ling of Zhou, the *gēngxū* year. "Jiān jū" is pronounced *xián*. Zigong was Duanmu Ci, a native of Wei, styled Zigong, known for his eloquence and skill in speech. Yan Hui was a native of Lu, styled Ziyuan. "Yuán qín" is pronounced *yuán*. "Dú yuè" is pronounced *luò*. "Zhī fēn" is pronounced *fú wèn*; the same below. "Qiǎo rán" is pronounced *qī xiǎo*. "Yǒu jiān" means "after a short while, his countenance changed for a time." "Yì jiá" is pronounced *xiá*, or in one version, *shī*. "Wáng biàn" is pronounced *wàng*, or in one version, *zhǐ*. "Nǎng wú" is pronounced *nǎi lǎng*. "Lǐ yuè" is pronounced *yuè*; the same below. "Yí lái" is pronounced *wéi jì*. "Jì zhì" is pronounced *zhí lì*. "Zhì luàn" is the same below. "Bù shě" is pronounced *shě*. "Wú hé" is pronounced *ài*. "Jiāng wéi" is pronounced *gān wěi*. "Yù juān" is pronounced *yuán*. "Pìn lǔ" is pronounced *pǐ zhèng*. "Fǎng fú" is pronounced *fāng fèi*. "Zhī liàng" is pronounced *liàng*. "Qí chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*; the same below. "Bó rán" is pronounced *pò*; the same below. "Kàng Cāngzǐ" is pronounced *Gēng Sāng*, named Chu. The *Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as *Kàng Cāngzǐ*. Jia Kui’s *Yao Shi Ying Lan* states: "In Wu Commandery, there is a clan named Gengsang, regarded as a scholarly family." "Chuán zhī" is pronounced *zhuān*. "Wéi rán" is pronounced *wéi guǐ*.
chunks.overlap_context: *Yuē xī* is pronounced *xī*. *Jiāng fù* is pronounced *fú yòu*. *Guó xiàng* is pronounced *xī liàng*. *Xié zhí* is pronounced *sì zhē*, sometimes written as *xié zhēn*. *Jīn wáng* is pronounced *wú*. *Qiě xún* is pronounced *xún*, meaning "trustworthy." *Huá zǐ* is pronounced *hú huà*. *Bìng wàng* is pronounced *wàng*, meaning "forgetfulness, unable to recall matters." *Hé shì* is pronounced *hú là*. *Dú zhī dú* means "bitterness." *Shī guī* is pronounced *shī*. *Qíng nì* is pronounced *nì lì*.

chunks.original_text: 眉睫音接。 唯豁火活切。 有分扶问切。 六藏徂浪切。 心、肺、肝、脾、肾，谓之五藏。 今六藏者，为肾有两，藏其左为肾，右为命门，命门者，谓神之所舍也。 男子以藏精，女子以系胞。 其炁与肾通，故言藏有六也。 商大音太。 宰商，宋国也。 宋都商丘，故二名焉。 大宰，官名。 示见贤徧切。 简朴片角切。 不治直吏切。 下治之同。 强其两切。 为干为切。 得徧与遍同。 崇崛焦勿切。 浩芒音茫。 嘿然音墨。 吾语鱼据切。 讷奴忽切。 一行下孟切。 不贰贰疑也。 同要一遥切。 瞥人莫侠切。 乃居一本作反居。 曰数色主切。 料简音聊。 无惕他历切。 阅音悦。 欺魄片各切。 《字书》作欺颣。 人面丑也。 类片各切。 形丧息浪切。 思虑音四。 未行户郎切。 衎衎口汗切。 在雄一本作存雄。 駴与骇同。 进知音尽。 能离力智切。 之称尺证切。 一眄音面。 斜视也。 从心音纵横心去声。 外进音尽。 以重柱用切。 好游呼报切。 下同。
chunks.translated_text: "Méi jié" is pronounced *jiē*. "Wéi huò" is pronounced *huǒ huó*. "Yǒu fèn" is pronounced *fú wèn*. "Liù zàng" is pronounced *cú làng*. The heart, lungs, liver, spleen, and kidneys are called the five *zàng*. Now, the six *zàng* refer to the kidneys being two: the left is called the kidney, and the right is called the *Mingmen* (Gate of Life), which is where the spirit resides. In men, it stores essence; in women, it connects to the womb. Its *qi* communicates with the kidneys, hence it is said there are six *zàng*. "Shāng dà" is pronounced *tài*. "Zǎi Shāng" refers to the state of Song. The capital of Song was Shangqiu, hence the two names. "Dà zǎi" is an official title. "Shì" is pronounced *xiàn biàn*. "Jiǎn pǔ" is pronounced *piàn jué*. "Bù zhì" is pronounced *zhí lì*; the same below for "zhì". "Qiǎng" is pronounced *qiǎng*. "Wéi" is pronounced *wéi*. "Dé biàn" is the same as *biàn*. "Chóng jué" is pronounced *jiāo wù*. "Hào máng" is pronounced *máng*. "Mò rán" is pronounced *mò*. "Wú yǔ" is pronounced *yú jù*. "Nè" is pronounced *nú hū*. "Yī xíng" is pronounced *xià mèng*. "Bù èr" means unwavering resolve. "Tóng yào" is pronounced *yī yáo*. "Piē" is pronounced *mò xiá*. "Nǎi jū" has an alternate version reading *fǎn jū*. "Yuē shù" is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. "Liào jiǎn" is pronounced *liáo*. "Wú tì" is pronounced *tā lì*. "Yuè" is pronounced *yuè*. "Qī pò" is pronounced *piàn gè*; the *Character Book* writes it as *qī lèi*, meaning facial ugliness. "Lèi" is pronounced *piàn gè*. "Xíng sàng" is pronounced *xī làng*. "Sī lǜ" is pronounced *sì*. "Wèi xíng" is pronounced *hù láng*. "Kàn kàn" is pronounced *kǒu hàn*. "Zài xióng" has an alternate version reading *cún xióng*. "Hài" is the same as *hài*. "Jìn zhī" is pronounced *jìn*. "Néng lí" is pronounced *lì zhì*. "Zhī chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. "Yī miǎn" is pronounced *miàn*, meaning a sidelong glance. "Cóng xīn" is pronounced *zòng* (with *xīn* in the departing tone). "Wài jìn" is pronounced *jìn*. "Yǐ zhòng" is pronounced *zhù yòng*. "Hào yóu" is pronounced *hū bào*; the same below.
chunks.overlap_context: pronounced *pǐ zhèng*. "Fǎng fú" is pronounced *fāng fèi*. "Zhī liàng" is pronounced *liàng*. "Qí chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*; the same below. "Bó rán" is pronounced *pò*; the same below. "Kàng Cāngzǐ" is pronounced *Gēng Sāng*, named Chu. The *Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as *Kàng Cāngzǐ*. Jia Kui’s *Yao Shi Ying Lan* states: "In Wu Commandery, there is a clan named Gengsang, regarded as a scholarly family." "Chuán zhī" is pronounced *zhuān*. "Wéi rán" is pronounced *wéi guǐ*.

chunks.original_text: 之乐音洛。 零悴疾醉切。 者鲜息浅切。 不知务内观一本作不如观。 古乱切。 下同。 谛视也。 口窊乌瓜切。 温蒸音证。 自匿尼力切。 者难乃旦切。 故重柱用切。 所视音视。 文挚音至。 文挚，六国时人，尝医齐威王或云春秋时宋国良医也，曾治齐文王，使文王怒而病愈。 所听平声。 凡此众疾一本作众庶，非是。 哀乐音洛。 背明音佩。 文挚后向明而望之一本文挚，下加从及自字者，皆非也。 之分符问切。 由死而生不幸也本多无不字，观上下文於理有阙，故特添之。 失中丁仲切。 将眇亡少切。 先睹音睹。 闻蚋而锐切。 淄音淹。 渑音乘。 淄水出鲁郡莱芜县，渑水西自北海郡千乘县界，流至寿光县，二水相合。 《说符》篇曰：淄渑之合，易牙尝之。 难别彼列切。 下同。
chunks.translated_text:
"Zhī lè" is pronounced *luò*. "Líng cuì" is pronounced *jí zuì*. "Zhě" is pronounced *xī qiǎn*. "Bù zhī wù nèi guān" has an alternate version reading *bù rú guān*. "Gǔ" is pronounced *luàn*; the same below. It means to scrutinize. "Kǒu wā" is pronounced *wū guā*. "Wēn zhēng" is pronounced *zhèng*. "Zì nì" is pronounced *ní lì*. "Zhě" is pronounced *nán nǎi dàn*. "Gù" is pronounced *zhù yòng*. "Suǒ shì" is pronounced *shì*. "Wén zhì" is pronounced *zhì*.

Wen Zhi was a man of the Warring States period, though some say he was a skilled physician of the State of Song during the Spring and Autumn period. He once treated King Wei of Qi—or King Wen of Qi—by provoking the king’s anger to cure his illness.

"Suǒ tīng" is read in the level tone. "Fán cǐ zhòng jí" has an alternate version reading *zhòng shù*, which is incorrect. "Āi lè" is pronounced *luò*. "Bèi míng" is pronounced *pèi*. In later texts, Wen Zhi faces the light to gaze—versions adding *cóng* (from), *jí* (and), or *zì* (self) are all incorrect.

"Zhī fèn" is pronounced *fú wèn*. "Yóu sǐ ér shēng bù xìng yě" originally lacked the character *bù* (not), but judging from the context, it is logically incomplete, so it has been added here. "Shī zhōng" is pronounced *dīng zhòng*. "Jiāng miǎo" is pronounced *wáng shǎo*. "Xiān dǔ" is pronounced *dǔ*. "Wén ruì" is pronounced *ér kuì*. "Zī" is pronounced *yān*. "Miǎn" is pronounced *shèng*.

The Zī River rises in Laiwu County, Lu Commandery, while the Miǎn River flows westward from the borders of Qiancheng County in Beihai Commandery to Shouguang County, where the two rivers converge. The *Shuō Fú* chapter states: "The blending of the Zī and Miǎn is as indistinguishable as Yi Ya’s palate." "Nán bié" is pronounced *bǐ liè*; the same below.

"Jìn zhī" is pronounced *jìn*. "Néng lí" is pronounced *lì zhì*. "Zhī chēng" is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*. "Yī miǎn" is pronounced *miàn*, meaning a sidelong glance. "Cóng xīn" is pronounced *zòng* (with *xīn* in the departing tone). "Wài jìn" is pronounced *jìn*. "Yǐ zhòng" is pronounced *zhù yòng*. "Hào yóu" is pronounced *hū bào*; the same below.

chunks.original_text: 将僵音姜。 先亟去吏切。 《方言》：亟，受也。 犇佚音奔逸。 仆也音赴。 可渝音俞。 亢与抗同。 要造七到切。 后还音旋。 郑之圃泽圃田也。 在中牟县。 有治直吏切。 行过音戈。 邓析音锡。 为若于伪切。 相嘲张交切。 调徒吊切。 所愿知也知，一本作如。 养养上余亮切，下如字。 长幼张丈切。 牢藉本作箝，侧战切。 牢，牲牢也，圈也。 箝，谓以竹木围绕。 又刺也。 《周礼□鳖人》以时簎鱼鳖蜃也。 又《国语》云：罗籍鱼也。 《庄子》云：以临牢栅。 李颐云：牢，豕室也，栅木之也。 文字难异，其意同也。 籍音栅。 庖厨音匏。 从者才用切。 无相息亮切。 而知音智。 下以意求之。 并为于伪切。 下以意求之。 无好呼报切。 无恶乌路切。 荀粲七汗切。 傅嘏音贾。 志局衢足切。 公仪伯堂溪公公仪堂溪，氏也，皆周贤士。 懦夫乃玩切。 女之音汝。
chunks.translated_text:
"Jiāng jiāng" is pronounced *jiāng*. "Xiān jí" is pronounced *qù lì*; the *Fangyan* states: "*Jí* means to receive." "Bēn yì" is pronounced *bēn yì*. "Pū yě" is pronounced *fù*. "Kě yú" is pronounced *yú*. "Kàng" is the same as *kàng*. "Yào zào" is pronounced *qī dào*. "Hòu huán" is pronounced *xuán*. The marsh of Zheng is Pǔtián; it is located in Zhongmu County.

"Yǒu zhì" is pronounced *zhí*. "Xíng guò" is pronounced *gē*. "Dèng Xī" is pronounced *xī*. "Wéi ruò" is pronounced *yú wěi*. "Xiāng cháo" is pronounced *zhāng jiāo*. "Diào" is pronounced *tiáo*. "Suǒ yuàn zhī yě" — *zhī* is in one version written as *rú*. "Yǎng" (first instance) is pronounced *yú liàng*; (second instance) is read as written. "Zhǎng yòu" is pronounced *zhāng zhàng*. "Láo" originally written as *qián*, pronounced *cè zhàn*. *Láo* refers to animal pens or enclosures; *qián* means to surround with bamboo or wood, or to stab. The *Rites of Zhou · Bièrén* states: "They catch fish, turtles, and clams at the proper time." The *Guoyu* also says: "They net and trap fish." The *Zhuangzi* states: "To overlook the animal pens." Li Yi comments: "*Láo* is a pigsty, fenced with wood." Though the characters differ, their meaning is the same. "Jí" is pronounced *zhà*. "Páo chú" is pronounced *páo*. "Cóng zhě" is pronounced *cái yòng*. "Wú xiāng xī" is pronounced *xī liàng*. "Ér zhī" is pronounced *zhì*. Below: "seek it with intention." "Bìng wéi" is pronounced *yú wěi*. Below: "seek it with intention." "Wú hào" is pronounced *hū bào*. "Wú wù" is pronounced *wū lù*. "Xún Cān" is pronounced *qī hàn*. "Fù Gǔ" is pronounced *jiǎ*. "Zhì jú" is pronounced *qú zú*. "Gōngyí Bó" and "Tángxī Gōng" — *Gōngyí* and *Tángxī* are surnames; both were worthy gentlemen of Zhou. "Nuò fū" is pronounced *nǎo wàn*. "Nǚ zhī" is pronounced *rǔ*.

chunks.original_text: 能折之舌切。 春蠡音终。 一曰蝗也。 之股音古。 能裂或作分字。 犀兕徐子切。 曳音裔犹憾户暗切。 不窥去随切。 所易以豉切。 下同。 舆薪音余。 撞钟宅红切。 雷霆音亭。 一家一本作一道，於义不长。 子牟莫侯切。 好与呼报切。 不恤虽律切。 子舆音余。 行无下孟切。 不中丁仲切。 漫音万。 衍以战切。 韩檀不安切。 肄之戈二切。 肄习也。 桓团大端切。 之囿音又。 之诒音待。 欺也。 下同。 后镞作木切。 中丁仲切。 下及注同。 相属音烛。 注同。 矢造七到切。 着直略切。 下同。 堋音朋。 复扶又切。 下同。 所凑七豆切。 逢蒙薄江切。 乌号户羔切。 綦卫音其。 《史记》云：綦国之竹。 晋灼曰：卫之苑多竹莜。 射食弋切。 矢末一本作来。

"诒" is pronounced *dài*. It means to deceive. Below, the same. "镞" is pronounced *mù*. "中" is pronounced *zhòng*. Below and in the annotation, the same. "相属" is pronounced *zhǔ*. The annotation is the same. "矢造" is pronounced *qī dào*. "着" is pronounced *zhí lüè*. Below, the same. "堋" is pronounced *péng*. "复" is pronounced *fú yòu*. Below, the same. Jin Zhu says: "The gardens of Wei abound with bamboo and *yao*." "射" is pronounced *yì*. The end of the arrow is also written as "来."

chunks.original_text: 眸子莫侯切。 而眶音匡。 不睫本作，目瞬也。 下同。 ，且洽切。 矢隧音坠。 强弩其两切。 能撒一本作穿。 鲁缟古老切。 与音余。 人掷直炙切。 之分符问切。 差跌音蹉经。 语张鱼据切。 焉得於虔切。 故借子亦切。 见在贤徧切。 孤犊音独。 胜言音升。 可解音蟹。 下同。 公孙龙平原君之客，字子秉，赵人。 之呜一本作公孙龙於马。 并注无，异於鸣，亦作无异於马。 云马者，白马论之义也。 云鸣者，但鸣而无理趣。 取错仪则长矣。 余窍口吊切。 秽穴也。 余日人质切。 尧治天下为句。 欲治直吏切。 治欤，治名，治道同。 道洽本作合。 外朝音朝。 禅时战切。 □古畴字。 直留切。 谁也。 泛然芳剑切。 无系音计。 其应音应。 道亡音无。 违物一本作道不违物。 亡情本作忘。 发无知一本作废无知。 下作废无能。 虽无为而非理也一本漏为字。 冲虚至德真经释文卷上竟 冲虚至德真经释文卷下
chunks.translated_text:
The pupil is pronounced *mò hóu*. The eye socket is pronounced *kuāng*. "不睫" was originally written as "", meaning the blinking of the eye. Below, the same. "" is pronounced *qià*. The arrow’s path is pronounced *zhuì*. A strong crossbow is pronounced *qí liǎng*. "撒" is also written as "穿". "鲁缟" is pronounced *gǔ lǎo*. "与" is pronounced *yú*. "掷" is pronounced *zhí zhì*. "分" is pronounced *fú*. "符" is pronounced *wèn*. "差跌" is pronounced *cuō jīng*. "语张" is pronounced *yú jù*. "焉得" is pronounced *yú qián*. "故借" is pronounced *zǐ yì*. "见在" is pronounced *xián biàn*. "孤犊" is pronounced *dú*. "胜言" is pronounced *shēng*. "可解" is pronounced *xiè*. Below, the same.

Gongsun Long was a retainer of Lord Pingyuan, styled Zibing, a native of Zhao. "之呜" is also written as "公孙龙於马". The annotation omits "无", differing from "鸣", and is also written as "无异於马". "云马" refers to the meaning of the *White Horse Discourse*. "云鸣" means merely to cry out without reason or principle. The error in taking the wrong standard would be great indeed.

"余窍" is pronounced *kǒu diào*, meaning a filthy orifice. "余日" is pronounced *rén zhì*. "尧治天下" forms a phrase. "欲治" is pronounced *zhí lì*. "治欤" refers to the name of governance; "治道" is the same. "道洽" was originally written as "合". "外朝" is pronounced *cháo*. "禅" is pronounced *shàn*. "□" is the ancient form of "畴", pronounced *zhí liú*, meaning "who". "泛然" is pronounced *fāng jiàn*. "无系" is pronounced *jì*. "其应" is pronounced *yìng*. "道亡" is pronounced *wú*. "违物" is also written as "道不违物". "亡情" was originally written as "忘". "发无知" is also written as "废无知". Below, it is written as "废无能". Though it is non-action, it is not contrary to principle—one version omits the character "为".

*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume One* concludes.
*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume Two* begins.

Jin Zhu says: "The gardens of Wei abound with bamboo and *yao*." "射" is pronounced *yì*. The end of the arrow is also written as "来."

chunks.original_text: 唐当涂县丞殷敬顺撰 碧虚子陈景元补遗 汤问第五 齐所才细切。 殷汤殷汤，姓于，或履，字天乙。 夏革音棘。 夏棘，字子棘，为阳大夫。 混茫音忙。 今恶音乌。 下同。 必复扶又切。 下同。 故重柱用切。 下同。 画然音获。 一本作尽。 齐州《尔雅》云：距齐以南，戴口为丹穴，北戴斗极为空桐。 距去也。 齐，中也。 东行至营今之柳城，古之营州，东行至海是也。 西行至豳与邠同。 四海四荒四极《尔雅》云：九夷八狄七戒六蛮，谓之四海。 觚竹、北户、西王母。 日下谓之四荒，东秦、远西、郊国、南濮。 铅此、祝、栗谓之四极。 义见贤遍切。 大虚音泰。 下同。 笼罩陟孝切。 亦焉於虔切。 下同。 知及一本作及，恐字误。 豁视呼括切。 无垠音银。 下同。 一本作限。 皆拘音俱。 桎梏音质谷。 自解音蟹。 刳斫音枯。 夸大口花切。 聃他甘切。 老子名。 周庄子名。 女娲氏音瓜。 古天子。 风姓。 断鳌音短邀。 具后释。 共音恭。 工氏古帝王。 颛顼音专旭。 虙音伏。 羲许宜切。 水潦音老。 渤海今乐安郡。 大壑《山海经》云：东海之外有大壑。 归墟或作归塘。 八弦音宏。 岱舆音余。 贠峤渠庙切。 山锐而高也。 方壶一曰方丈。 瀛洲音盈。 蓬莱《史记》曰：方丈、瀛洲、篷莱，此三神山在渤海中，盖尝有至者，诸仙人及不死之药皆在焉。 未至，望之如云。 欲到，即引而去。
chunks.translated_text:
Master Yin Jingshun of Dangtu County, Tang Dynasty, compiled; Chen Jingyuan of Bixu supplemented omissions.

*Tang Asks, Fifth Chapter*

"Qi" is pronounced *cái xì*. "Yin Tang" (Tang of Yin): surname Zi, or Lü, style Tianyi. "Xia Ji" is pronounced *jí*. Xia Ji, style Ziji, was a grandee of Yang. "Hun mang" is pronounced *máng*. "Wu" (evil) is pronounced *wū* below, the same. "Bi fu" is pronounced *fú yòu* below, the same. "Chong zhu" is pronounced *zhù yòng* below, the same. "Hua ran" is pronounced *huò*; one version writes "exhausted." *Erya* of Qi State states: south of Qi, wearing the sun is called Danxue; north of it, wearing the Dipper and Pole is called Kongtong. "Ju" means "to distance." "Qi" means "center." Eastward to Ying—present-day Liucheng, ancient Yingzhou—eastward to the sea. Westward to Bin, also written as "邠." "Four Seas, Four Wastes, Four Poles": *Erya* states: the Nine Yi, Eight Di, Seven Jie, Six Man are called the Four Seas. Guzhu, Beihu, Xiwangmu; "sun’s descent" refers to the Four Wastes: Dongqin, Yuanxi, Jiaoguo, Nanpu. Yanci, Zhu, Li are called the Four Poles.

"Yi" is pronounced *xiàn biàn*. "Da xu" is pronounced *tài* below, the same. "Long zhao" is pronounced *zhào xiào*. "Yi yan" is pronounced *yú qián* below, the same. "Zhi ji" is written as "ji" in one version; likely a character error. "Huo shi" is pronounced *hū kuò*. "Wu yin" is pronounced *yín* below, the same; one version writes "limit." "Jie ju" is pronounced *jū*. "Zhi gu" is pronounced *zhì gǔ*. "Zi jie" is pronounced *xiè*. "Ku zhuo" is pronounced *kū*. "Kua da" is pronounced *kǒu huā*. "Dan" is pronounced *tā gān*; the name of Laozi. "Zhou" is the name of Zhuangzi. "Nü Wa Shi" is pronounced *guā*; an ancient Son of Heaven, of the Feng clan. "Duan Ao" is pronounced *duàn āo*; explained later. "Gong" is pronounced *gōng*. "Gong Shi" was an ancient emperor. "Zhuan Xu" is pronounced *zhuān xù*. "Fu" is pronounced *fú*. "Xi" is pronounced *xǔ yí*. "Shui lao" is pronounced *lǎo*. "Bo Hai" is present-day Le’an Prefecture. "Da he": *Shanhaijing* states: beyond the Eastern Sea lies a great abyss. "Gui xu" is also written as "Gui tang." "Ba xian" is pronounced *hóng*. "Dai yu" is pronounced *yú*. "Yun qiao" is pronounced *qú miào*; mountains sharp and towering. "Fang hu" is also called Fangzhang. "Ying zhou" is pronounced *yíng*. "Peng lai": *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Fangzhang, Yingzhou, Penglai—these three divine mountains lie in the Bohai Sea. Some have reached them; immortals and the elixir of death reside there. Before arrival, they appear like clouds; when approached, they recede.
chunks.overlap_context:
pronounced *jì*. "其应" is pronounced *yìng*. "道亡" is pronounced *wú*. "违物" is also written as "道不违物". "亡情" was originally written as "忘". "发无知" is also written as "废无知". Below, it is written as "废无能". Though it is non-action, it is not contrary to principle—one version omits the character "为".

*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume One* concludes.
*Explanatory Notes on the True Scripture of Perfect Virtue and Utmost Emptiness, Volume Two* begins.

chunks.original_text: 终莫能至。 周犯一本作范围字，一本作周旋字。 纯音淳。 缟古老切。 珠玕音干。 可数色主切。 注同。 连着直略切。 波上时掌切。 暂峙直里切。 仙圣毒之毒，病之。 禺强与隅同。 《神仙传》：北方之神名禺强，号曰玄冥子。 《山海经》曰：大荒之中，有神，人面乌身，名曰禺强。 《筒文》云：此海神也。 巨鳌《列仙传》云：巨鳌戴蓬莱山而抃沧海之中。 《玄中记》云：即巨鳌也。 三番音翻。 更代也。 盈数色主切。 步一本作千。 钓一本作钩。 而趣音趋。 灼其音酌。 以数所据切。 算计也。 又钻杻官切。 鲲鹏音昆朋。 蚊蚋音文芮。 蚤虱音早瑟。 帝冯音愤。 浸减子禁切。 一本作侵。 使阨乌卖切。 僬侥国音僬尧。 短人国名也。 《 史记》 云：憔侥氏三尺，短之至也。 韦昭曰：僬侥，西南蛮之别名也。 案《括地志》在大秦国西北。 至伏羲神农时有国人犹数千丈一本作数十丈。 事见贤篇切。 下同。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet none could ever reach them.

"Zhou Fan" is also written as *fan wei* (范围) or *zhou xuan* (周旋). "Chun" is pronounced *chún*. "Gao" is pronounced *gǔ lǎo*. "Zhu gan" is pronounced *gān*. "Ke" (可) is pronounced *shǔ* (数), meaning "to count"; the annotation is the same. "Lian zhuo" is pronounced *zhí lüè*. "Bo shang" is pronounced *shí zhǎng*. "Zan zhi" is pronounced *zhí lǐ*. "Xian sheng du zhi" (仙圣毒之): *du* (毒) means "to afflict."

"Yu Qiang" is pronounced the same as *yu* (隅). *Shenxian Zhuan* states: the northern deity is named Yu Qiang, styled Xuánmíngzǐ. *Shanhaijing* says: in the great wilderness, there is a spirit with a human face and a crow’s body, called Yu Qiang. *Tongwen* notes: this is the sea god.

"Ju Ao": *Liexian Zhuan* states: the giant turtle bore Mount Penglai upon its back and danced in the midst of the deep. *Xuanzhong Ji* says: this is the giant turtle. "San fan" is pronounced *fān*, meaning "to alternate." "Ying shu" is pronounced *shǔ* (数), meaning "full measure." "Bu" is also written as *qian* (千). "Diao" is also written as *gou* (钩). "Er qu" is pronounced *qū*. "Zhuo qi" is pronounced *zhuó*. "Yi shu" is pronounced *shù*, meaning "to calculate." "You zuan" is pronounced *niǔ guān*.

"Kun Peng" is pronounced *kūn péng*. "Wen rui" is pronounced *wén ruì*. "Zao shi" is pronounced *zǎo sè*. "Di Feng" is pronounced *fèn*. "Jin jian" is pronounced *zǐ jìn*; also written as *qin* (侵). "Shi e" is pronounced *wū mài*. "Jiao Yao Guo" is pronounced *jiāo yáo*; the name of a land of short people. *Records of the Grand Historian* states: the Jiao Yao people stand three feet tall, the shortest of all. Wei Zhao says: Jiao Yao is another name for the southwestern barbarians. According to *Kuodi Zhi*, it lies northwest of Da Qin. By the eras of Fuxi and Shennong, the people of this land were still several thousand *zhang* tall—elsewhere written as several tens of *zhang*. For details, see *Xian Pian* (贤篇); the annotation below is the same.

"Peng lai": *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Fangzhang, Yingzhou, Penglai—these three divine mountains lie in the Bohai Sea. Some have reached them; immortals and the elixir of death reside there. Before arrival, they appear like clouds; when approached, they recede.

chunks.original_text: 诤人音争。 《山海经》曰：东海之外，有小人，名曰诤人冥灵木名也，生江南。 以叶生为春，叶落为秋。 大椿丑伦切。 木名也，一名瞬。 菌芝其阴切。 崔撰云：粪上生芝也，朝生暮死。 简文云：欻生芝。 蠓莫孔切。 蚋音芮。 谓蠛蠓，蚊蚋也。 二者小飞虫也。 终发之北一本作终北之北。 溟海《十洲记》云：水黑色谓溟海。 广数上古旷切，下色主切。 长称尺证切。 下同。 为鲲鲸鱼也。 鹏步登切。 虽语鱼据切。 名之弥正切。 与铭同。 志之记之也。 么虫亡果切。 《字书》云：么，小也。 焦螟音名。 蚊睫音接。 拭音式。 眦在诣切。 目际也。 除倚切。 俞师旷皆古之聪耳人也。 擿耳音惕。 俛首音免。 空桐《史记》云：黄帝至于河，登空桐之山。 今在澧泉郡。 砰然普耕切。
chunks.translated_text:
"Contentious person" is pronounced *zhēng rén*. *The Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: beyond the Eastern Sea, there are small people called "contentious ones"; also the name of the *Mingling* tree, which grows south of the Yangtze. Its leaves sprout in spring and fall in autumn.

"Great *chun*" is pronounced *chǒu lún*. A tree name, also called *shùn*.

"*Jūnzhī*" is pronounced *qí yīn*. Cui Zhuan says: the *zhī* grows on dung, appearing at dawn and dying by dusk. Emperor Jianwen says: the *zhī* springs forth suddenly.

"*Měng*" is pronounced *mò kǒng*; "*ruì*" is pronounced *ruì*. These refer to *mièměng* and *wénruì*, both small flying insects.

North of *Zhongfa*—elsewhere written as north of *Zhongbei*—lies the *Ming Sea*. *Records of the Ten Continents* states: waters of black color are called the *Ming Sea*. Its vastness is pronounced *shàng gǔ kuàng*, *xià sè zhǔ*; its length is pronounced *chǐ zhèng*—the same below. It is the domain of the *kūn* and whale.

"*Peng*" is pronounced *bù dēng*; "*suī*" is pronounced *yǔ jù*; "*míng*" is pronounced *mí zhèng*, identical to *ming* (铭), meaning "to record and inscribe."

"*Yāo* insect" is pronounced *wáng guǒ*. *The Character Book* states: *yāo* means small.

"*Jiāomíng*" is pronounced *míng*; "*wénjié*" is pronounced *jiē*; "*shì*" is pronounced *shì*; "*zì*" is pronounced *zài yì*, referring to the corners of the eyes.

"*Chú*" is pronounced *chú yǐ*. Yu and Shi Kuang were men of ancient times with keen hearing.

"*Tī* ear" is pronounced *tì*; "*fǔ* head" is pronounced *miǎn*.

*Kongtong*: *Records of the Grand Historian* states: the Yellow Emperor, reaching the river, ascended Mount Kongtong. It now lies in Liquan Prefecture.

"*Pēng* sound" is pronounced *pǔ gēng*.
chunks.overlap_context: unced *jiāo yáo*; the name of a land of short people. *Records of the Grand Historian* states: the Jiao Yao people stand three feet tall, the shortest of all. Wei Zhao says: Jiao Yao is another name for the southwestern barbarians. According to *Kuodi Zhi*, it lies northwest of Da Qin. By the eras of Fuxi and Shennong, the people of this land were still several thousand *zhang* tall—elsewhere written as several tens of *zhang*. For details, see *Xian Pian* (贤篇); the annotation below is the same.
